Best Knizia, I've played.

RATING: 9
I've fallen in love with Knizia's simple, player-driven games, and Tigris and Euphrates is no exception. Of all of them, this one seems like the game with the most meat in the strategy. Samurai is great, but T&E appears to offer a depth that may even rival chess. Maybe I'm exaggerating, but I'm very much looking forward to learning this game deeply, and it may one day become a perfect 10 game for me (we'll see as my relationship with it develops).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Knizia's classic abstract strategy game has never been a favourite of mine. The design is brilliant in its elegant simplicity, but despite the simple rules there is a very deep strategy game hiding beneath the ugly surface and the steep and long learning curve. Many people, myself included, just aren't interested enough to suffer through the painful stage of "learning by losing" to care for finding it. casual gamers should avoid this game like the plague. 

The balanced scoring is typical for a Knizia design and works well, but the main problems are still "the rich get richer" and the luck of the tile draw that can really screw you over, especially in conjunction with the warfare mechanism. 

Aesthetically it's also very poor, but that is trivial. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A deceptively heavy, but wonderful game that unfolds like an onion with each successive play. Knizia's best. It's really a masterpiece.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An extremely strategic and brain burning Euro. 
Some consider it a bit bland and it is certainly on the more abstract side of things, but I don't find it bland at all - the main theme of the game - the ebb and flow of the ancient civilisations on the banks of the Tigris and Euphrates comes out really well in this game, and the strategies are deep and engaging. Better yet, it is highly playable as a two player game which most Euros aren't, and that is a big plus because I am not sure about the downtime and the AP that will be exhibited with more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

My friend tells me that after three or four plays in a row, and lot of incredible depth and ease of play opens up. I'm not sure I have the stamina for such an experience, but I can see why people would want to do so.

This is clearly one of Knizia's best.

RATING: 9
Only a couple of plays so far, but I love this game. This is very tight, tense, competitive strategy game. Every move each person makes matters and can dramatically shift the game. The players drastically affect the game.  One game I played had every monument come out, the other one didn't have a single one get built. On the other hand, it had far more wars. I love the elegance and uniqueness of this game.

9/20/17 - Update upon 8 plays. Still love this game, very enjoyable.

RATING: 8
Simple rules make this an easy game to introduce new players, but the strategy can be subtle. Limited actions make the game run smoothly, yet not so limited as to deny interesting decisions. However, despite how well-crafted the game is, I don't find much desire to bring this to the table. It may just be a problem with my play group, who I feel are a bit passive with this game, but even the more interactive sessions feel a bit dry and underwhelming. I definitely love the victory point system and the fact that your points are hidden.

Update (12/07): After gently pushing my group in a more aggresive direction, the game became much more interesting and fun. 7->8
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I believe T&E to be the ideal game, sitting somewhere between conquest and german mechanisms.

If you play tactical battle games (such as Risk), you'll notive that games tend to last for may too long. Units are generally numerous and fights are usually dice fests.
All the more, if you play with 3 or more persons, player eliminations tend to occur before the end of the game.
Tigris & Euphrates provides you with the benefits of territorial conquest without those drawbacks.
It allows a better pace through a subtile tile placement mechanism which replaces troops moves and offers a score system with which you can "loose a battle without loosing the war".
If we consider the conflict resolution system, through tiles in hand, it favors deduction and instinctive play, in opposition to cold calculations.
Those conflicts, which are almost "games within the game" are considered very carefully by all players because they have the bitter taste of sand for those who lose them and a wonderful flavor for those who win and for who the supremacy is revealed on the board.
With practice, you can better estimate your chances of winnong and better "read" the board and your opponents placements. T&E really develops itself through extensive play. You can improve your tactical skills and practice the art of bluffing, which sometimes allow to deal properly with a poor hand of tiles.
At last, the game materials are splendid with those large wooden leader disks at the "color" of each of the player. Between the two versions of the game (german / american), i'm entirely for the older version which distinguishes by its sobriety and the easy-to-read board and tiles.

Among the blames set on the game, there is its difficulty which makes it a proper game for experienced players only, a lack of them (regularly argued) and the luck factor (the importance of the "red" color).
If it's true that T&E cannot fit everyone's needs, the other criticisms are, to my point of view, untrue. Reiner Knizia said, on Geekspeak, that the theme of civilisation raising and falling was at the very origin of the game. It is true that the game is very much streamlined but it was made towards improving the flow of the game and keep a certain simplicity. It does not hurt the joy of playing.
At last, variety rules within the tiles in hand and statistically improbable situations do occur. Those elements provide length of play to the game. As games are played, you have to adapt to your hand as much as to the board and seek the advantages of both. All the more, monuments and treasure provide solutions to deal with the luck of the draw.

If I only had to make one statement against the game, it would be related to the turn order. As proved on the BGG interface, first persons to play have a double advantage of choosing their starting location and of being potentially able to play more than other players.
This small drawback is the price to be paid for a very good game and it is up to the players at the table to remember it and compensate favor of destiny.

RATING: 10

It's a simple enough premise, but has very deep strategy and is too dry for most of my gaming partners. Ultimately, there came a point in my collecting, where I knew I needed a copy of this game for my collection to feel adequate - it's so weighty and significant a title. I don't suppose I will find other players for it often, but it is nice to have. The physical game looks beautiful too.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
1 play / 4 players

LIKE: Strategic gameplay with many choices on how to try to strengthen your position on an ever changing map. I like how the conflict is different than a war game, it's based on tiles, but then after a conflict the tiles clear out offering opportunities for other players. The lesser-of-four point system is a great mechanism, it forces players to push for different colored points at different times in the game.

DISLIKE: Big plans can go awry with one simple catastrophe tile, quickly changing the state of the board, which means the game can feel tactical over strategical. The tiles drawn can be random, also stalling strategies. The game can get a little long from analyzing the board state each turn. 

OVERALL: Very good game, a true classic. It is an aggressive game, and can be debilitating, but players know this going in. Also helpful to know is how different combos in the spacial puzzle can be good or bad, because new players should not unknowingly be leaving opportunities for experienced players early in the game.

It feels like Samurai, but I like this a bit more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is one of those games that has rightfully earned its place in the top 10 games of all time. True the theme is weak (although I think it's not all that bad really), but the system is so simple and so deep - it's really wonderfully assembled. The lowest score of your set of scores wins, so you have to carefully balance all opportunities. An experienced player will definitely trounce a new player and equally skilled opponents will almost certainly be determined by the luck of the draw. Still, no doubt this game is smart and thinky. Wonderful!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is clearly a game of great depth and is chock full of tactical play.  I'm not so sure about Strategy - sure there is some, but the game can be so fluid that in any one or two rounds tactics seem more prevalent. I was expecting the game to be 100% non-linear, but actually this is not quite the case.  Players can become entrenched within match-winning Kingdoms.  Ok, so this can be nulified, but there was more of that type of play than I'd been led to expect.

It is clear that monuments are incredibly powerful and that late eternal conflicts launched from a powerful base can swing games that are quite even up to that point. A lucky draw of tiles at exactly the right time can be a big blow to your opponent. 

It's certainly heavyish and not the first game I'd pull out for two hours of fun and social-interplay, but it's a good brain-burner and I can see it will take some time to become competent at.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
*Rating based on one play.

This was a game on my "gaming bucket list" that I wanted to play once based on its reputation.  I found the game decent enough, but it's not one that grabbed me.  This game seems to be considered a heavy Euro, and I'd say that is true based more on the wide decision space the game provides than on the complexity of the rules, which is more of a mid-weight in my opinion.

It was certainly my experience in my one play with two other newbies to the game that you need to play this game several times to really know what you are doing in it.  We all made some bad tactical blunders in the game that, with more experience, we may have known to avoid.  That said, I don't know that I enjoyed it enough to give it that kind of attention.

Pros/Cons
+Mechanically solid game without too many rules exceptions.  It has definitely aged well over the last two decades.
+Has some interesting mechanics, like the different colors of victory points and needing to balance them to win.
+Highly skill-based.  The better, more experienced player should win this game most of the time.

=Very cutthroat and confrontational.

-Very thin on theme.  It is a Knizia game after all.
-The combat mechanism of using tiles from hand feels quite random for a strategy game of this type.
-Overstays its welcome.  We finished our game in about 2 hours, which felt too long.

Overall, this is a game that I recognize as being a quality design, but one that just doesn't hold much interest for me.  I'm glad I played it once, but don't know that I'll ever feel the desire to play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game "feels" like a classic boardgame, such as chess or backgammon, in terms of abstract strategy. On the plus side, it means that the fun is not based on novelty, and should therefore have nearly infinite replayability. The downside is that it can be a little dry and intimidating for some. However, definitely appeals to me, it successfully scales from 2-4 players and I have a challenging, tense game every time! The relative importance of red tiles, and the terrible effect of not having any in hand, can be perceived as a game balance flaw... but not eough to keep me from giving this one a very high rating

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Have played a few times now and feel it's too luck driven on what tiles you draw which would be fine if the game was half as long as it is or there was a way to manage being short of one area but the scoring is based on a balance of all colours so being weak in one area cannot be compensated elsewhere, although there are treasures and monuments they are hotly contested.

The obscure nature of what is a "good" action often means that players of different mindsets create odd games where several people think they are taking their best action but its not necessarily true or maybe it is, it's too obscure. Often one or two players get left to their own devices and win or people not paying attention to who needs what colours creates a problem if you don't control someone's weakest area and allow them to run away with the game

The hidden scoring adds to this problem as the colours are taken openly so it's possible to keep track but the game is complex enough that you need to focus on your own strategy quite a lot without enough time to focus on what other players are scoring. It would probably be a better game with open scoring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
As with the best games, elegant with simple mechanisms.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Solid strategic fun.  Yes, there's randomness in the blind tile choosing, but it's all where you play them.  Screwing over people is fun here.  The game takes a few plays to get the hang of.  In fact, it wasn't immediately apparent that it would work well as a 2 player game, as one person had a tendency to win by a lot.  But about the 3rd or 4th time we played, it became more even as we explored the strategies.  Yes, the theme is only there to help try and explain the rules, as it's mostly abstract.  

Bump to 10.  After many plays here on the geek, I'd play this at the drop of a hat.  Or a hint.  Or an invitation.  I love this game.

But for a good, thought-filled evening, this will frequently be pulled out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is one of the better Eurogames I have ever played.  Granted, I am not a Eurogamer, so take it with a grain of salt, but I have often bemoaned the lack of direct interaction, the lack of randomness, the lack of theme, and the lack of conflict in Euros.  In other words, I like Ameritrash.

This game is not tight thematically, but to its credit, it is not a boring multi-player solitaire puzzle with pre-programmed moves.  The tiles give you randomness and you have conflict.

I have heard some hate this because you are at the mercy of your tile draw.  That is Eurogamer squawking worthy of mockery, as the wargamer in me knows you cry havoc and let loose the dogs of war.  The dice gods love you and the dice gods hate you.  You balance the risk and you take your chances.  That is what makes a game great.  There is an action to dump tiles, so you are not forever screwed.  You play the hand dealt to you.

Bravo, Knizia.  You made a beauty!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It is a well design game, external and internal conflicts are a bit difficult to grasp at the beginning, but like anything else once you play this game enough.  easy to master !!!

RATING: 9
Fun area control game, with luck-of-the-draw elements.  Not really grasping strategy yet, but I enjoyed playing.  Making the most of your tile draws seems key, along with knowing when to attack someone else just to set them back.    The four players in this game largely played to raise their own scores and only attack others when it was their own best move, without a lot of catastrophe tokens hitting the board.

Would definitely play again!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have to concede I had this game all wrong. 

There is a barrier to entry - while there are many great PERSONAL reviews, not many are able to really articulate what you need to do to be able to be a competent player. 

However, once you GET it, it really is amazing. I haven't had an epiphany for a while, but T+E really floored me. Effectively, it's a game where there are ten things that are possible, three of them are happening at any one time, and you have to judge how your existing placements and hand composition can take advantage of one or two of them. Learning how quickly dismiss the first five of those things is key - definitely give this game two or three games before judging - it's earned it. 


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played only very few games so far but the mechanisms seem very well developed and the theme is still visible under the somewhat abstract surface. Excellent design effort.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
STRATEGY

Draw and place tiles to build your ancient civilization. Place your leaders and tiles to create conflict. 

This is really an "abstract" heavy thinker's game.  The potential for analysis paralysis is high, as the sheer number of choices, tactics, and strategies a player can use is overwhelming. I think this is a game that will take several repeat plays to begin to fully appreciate the complexity and subtlety.

The manual is a model in clarity. 

Read my first session report at: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/664271/te-virgins-learn-the-game

Recommended with 2-4 players (best 4). 90 mins.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another modern classic, a game where you place one of four different coloured tiles or a monument every turn and score points for each. You have four leader matching those colours and you only gain points if a route can be traced to those leaders. If two leaders of the same colour fight it out players can add tile from their hadn to assist the fight. Only one can gain control of a set of tiles. Its quite hard to explain here, and equally hard to teach, but again - your patience is well rewarded by this game.

Trade Info: I have played this copy once. It is the old edition with one sided board and none of the modular expansions. It's a great game, but my copy will never get played and everyone I would play it with owns their own copy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
PLayed a bunch of times on tablet, curious about actual table top experience

RATING: 8
Great game. Need to buy another copy. Knizia's classic.
Very agressive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So, I actually think that Tigris & Euphrates is very much like Samurai, only T&E is more complex and interactive. I can see myself pleasantly enjoying back-to-back games of Samurai and T&E - just need one more strong Knizia game to make it a trio! 

I do find the scoring logic to be much less confusing in T&E, where each player's single lowest number of cubes out of 4 types counts as the end game scoring. The highest amount of the lowest number of cubes is the winner - if there is a tie, then the second lowest number of cubes are compared (with the higher amount going to the winner). 

UPDATE: Played this again and still love it! Even though I did poorly in the beginning while I got used to the rules, I picked up in the end to not lose badly. 2015 UPDATE: I may consider reassessing this game... Haven't played it for years...

RATING: 7.5

I give it a 7.5 instead of 8 because I haven't played it yet with 4 players, when, I'm sure, i will be able to see the whole potential of the game. No dice rolling: the player must calculate his/her movement. Leaders: they are the core of the game. Changing position of one of them in the right moment of the game can change the course of a game!

RATING: 10
Blood will flow once more in the Tigris and Euphrates! The rivers will be red, green, blue or black, covered with the remains of the men felled by internal strife and external wars.

 This is a mind blowing game of strategy. A little bit dependent on the draw of the tiles but overall it is very much a strategy game where you have to opportunistic about who you attack, when you attack and how you attack.

Newbs will suffer from headaches for hours afterwards.

RATING: 10
Az eddigi legjobb játék, amivel találkoztam.
Első ránézésre talán túl bonyolultnak tűnhetnek a szabályok, de néhány játék után rá lehet érezni az ízére. Végtelen számú kombinációs lehetőség, komoly stratégia jellemzik. Újabb és újabb partik szükségesek ahhoz, hogy igazi mélységét megtapasztaljuk.
Vannak akik szerint túlságosan magas a szerencse szerepe a játékban (lapkahúzás a zsákból - vannak akik ezt a zsákból húzást is egy ovis módszernek tartják), de szerintem nem vészes. A változatos, kiszámíthatatlan játékhoz ennyi kell.
Nem nevezhető gyors játéknak. Sőt, "gondolkodós" játékosokkal nagyon hosszúra is nyúlhat. Hármasban a legjobb, de szerintem ketten és négyen is jól játszható.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
A simple map of the Fertile Crescent pitches players against each other as regents and warlords of the Ancient Near East, vying for contol of influence between their Kings, Priests, Farmers, and Merchants. Everyone lays down their tiles and slowly accrues strength in their various leaders, but connecting any one small kingdom to another where like rival leaders are present sparks war. Leaders can infiltrate other kingdoms for political assassination, and multiple treasures can further bolster influence.

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
What appears to be a dull, tile-laying semi-abstract game is, in fact, a brutal, clever, and barely-manageable series of Rube Goldberg-esque see-saw mechanisms whereby players want to accrue as many points of influence (VP) by bolstering their leaders, but where a single tile laid can either trigger war, revolution, the erection of great points-spewing monuments, or outright catastrophe. This is a game where everyone at the table feels clever all the time, and you can admire the amazing nuance to each move by way of when to infiltrate your opponents' kingdoms, when to peacefully coexist in their territory with different leaders than are present there, when to build or control monuments--which immediately cripples your related influence strength!--, and when to cloister what little security you have to wait for others to tear each other to pieces. Then, at the game's conclusion, the category of influence in which you have the LOWEST amount is your final score. So much jockeying for position and course-correction. The interpersonal and tactical tension is without boundary. 

Not a Eurogame. Not a Wargame. Not an Abstract. A Masterpiece.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
This is game easily played poorly. "I get points from wars? Let's wage war!" or "I get points from monuments? Let's build monuments!" are easy lines of thinking to indulge, when in isolation, they are disastrous. The balance of this game rests with the players, and it's easy to either misunderstand or disregard that and end up with a landslide win where you didn't expect it.

[hr]
11/16/17 EDIT: I'm moving this from 8 to 10. Like Puerto Rico, this game deserves a rating bump on my part. It's sublime. It's unparalleled. The interaction and choices are astounding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
If this an example how Fantasy Flight's Euro Classics line will proceed in the future, I am overjoyed. One of Reiner Knizia's best games, laying tiles and leader pawns and then claiming victory points. Seems simple on the surface, but there is quite a lot to this, and the various revolts and wars you can initiate create a lot of direct player conflict over the scarce victory points. I like the rules for the Monuments, and there are several other variants also included with the box. Components look good, I am happy to finally have this in my possession and it's a classic for a good reason.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.6
Brilliant game, deservedly a classic. Even after five games, I'm not entirely certain how strong the luck factor affects everything, but it certainly seems quite manageable. However, it's really easy for an inexperienced (or very unlucky?) player to get locked out at a crucial stage, and this can be quite frustrating. Finding a way to turn the game around when it seems you're way behind, is frequently possible, though - and the Knizia-scoring makes you always overestimate how well everyone else is doing.

RATING: 7.5

It trully deserves a perfect 10 from me as it has everything I expect of a good game: the right length, the right player interaction and, of course, the right balance between strategy and luck (much more strategy than luck, but still enough luck to make it a game and not a puzzle).

UPDATE: I still like this gam very much, but it's rules can get a little fuzzy from time to time, and it certainly won't appease everyone in a gaming group.

UPDATE: My head hurts if I play seriously, and the only time I tried to play relaxed it just wasn't fun. A greatly designed game, but it's just not that much of a fun game anymore. Down to a 7.5.

RATING: 9.1
I love this game.  It is so difficult to find players in my area though.  For some reason most people have an unbelievably difficult time understanding Internal and External Conflicts and the ramifications of such.  I know people that I have played with at least 4 times that still can't see the difference and get stuck on my they can't just take the treasure cube.

I know that once someone gets it, they get it and enjoy playing, but it's the "getting" part that is the hurdle.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After a player understands a few key concepts (kingdoms, conflicts, and scoring) this game seems really quite simple.  

While the mechanics may be easy to understand, the variety of strategies that are available make this game quite a brain-burner.

A single session of T&E is filled with tough choices.  There are so many wonderfully tense situations that will have you wishing for "one more action" each turn.

I also really like the way the landscape can shift dramatically in the course of a turn.  Small kingdoms merge to become sprawling giants and crumble in the wake of titanic battles only to rise from the ashes once more.

Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
+ Simple rules
+ Elegant design
+ Deep (lots of tactics)
+ Plays fine with 2 (variant with smaller board), 3 or 4

- You need to know the mechanics in order to enjoy this game
- Compared to present-day boardgames, E&T can look a bit dull

House rule: players are allowed to finish the last round because otherwise players 1 & 2  have an advantage (better start position + 1 turn more) over players 3 & 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Nos, nagyon vártam a Knizia legbonyolultabbjaként beharangozott játékot, egyik nagy reménységem volt az előzetes nyomozás alapján. És nem csalódtam benne! Ahogy egy játszma alapján nem szabad temetni egy játékot, úgy az egekbe magasztalni sem illik, most mégis ez utóbbira készülök:)
A játék valóban bonyolult, a komplexitását a szabályok sokasága adja. A finomabb lehetőségekkel együtt egy körben közel 10 lényegesen különböző cselekedetet hajthatunk végre, ráadásul akár kétszer egymás után is. Szerintem a teljesen veszettnek tűnő partiban is lehet kiutat találni, annyi féle a lehetőség. Ha az ellenfél birodalma túl nagyra nő, ketté lehet vágni, ha túl sok épületet épít, akkor meg lehet támadni, mert legyengül. És ha már a támadásnál tartunk: az egyik legkonfrontatívabb játék, amivel valaha játszottam! Persze biztos, lehet egy ideig békésen egymás mellett játszani, de előbb-utóbb betelik a tábla, és muszáj lesz konfliktust generálni. Aki nem szereti a szívatást, az kerülje el ezt a játékot, mert Kniziához képest meglepő módon harciasra sikerült. 
A játék fő kritikájaként azt olvastam, hogy túl absztakt, elvont. Ha valaki olifántokra vár, az biztos csalódni fog, de szerintem nem túl absztarkt.
A területfoglalós típusban, de talán az összes általam ismert játék közül is az egyik legjobb. Egyaránt ösztönöz terjeszkedésre (a kincsek megszerzése csak így lehetséges), építésre (pontok szerzése így hatékonyabb), és konfliktusra (kevés lehetséges épület van, kevés kincs, és az ellenfélnek törvényszerűen van gyenge pontja, szinte lehetetlen mindent egyszerre kivédeni).
Nekem a Pegasus kiadás van meg, amiben szerencsére benne van a 4 civilizációs épület (ez a haladó verzióhoz kell, mi ezt játszottuk). A Ziggurat kieg nincs benne, de azt elvileg az alapkészlettel is lehet játszani.
A játék pontozásáról még nem szóltam: tisztára, mint a Genialban (a leggyengébb pontunk alapján alakul a sorrend, hiába vagyunk összességében fölényesen elsők, attól még lehetünk utolsók a gyenge láncszemünk miatt), csak ebben a játékban nagyobbat üt. Főleg, hogy nem látjuk menet közben egymás pontjait, és vannak joker pontok is.
Jellegében elég nagy hasonlóságot mutat a játék a Reef Encounter-rel, ez utóbbi szerzőjének gyanítom, hogy a Tigris az egyik kedvence... A téma különlegesebb a Reef Encounterben, de szerintem a Tigris a jobb játék, pedig nekem amaz is tetszik. Ha már itt tartunk, ez a legrégebbi lapkalepakolós játék, amit ismerek, majd még nyomozok, volt-e korábban ilyesmi.
A tábla 2 oldala 2 külön pályát tartalmaz, ez plusz pont, viszont a tábla a vágásnál kicsit sérülékenynek tűnik.
Remélem semmit sem hagytam ki, mindenkinek ajánlom a játékot!!
Nagyon szívesen játszom vele, de csak ha pihent vagyok, szabálymagyarázattal együtt 3 óra fölött volt nekünk.
Csak azért sorolom a Caylus és a Power Grid mögé, mert itt nagyobb a szerencse szerepe (a lapkák húzása miatt, bár azok lecserélhetők). Gondolkodtam, hogy az eddig általam legjobban kedvelt Knziza játéknál, az Amun-re-nél jobb-e. Az Amun-re az egyik leginkább egyben lévő játék, amiben minden kis részlet Egyiptomra utal, minden mindennel összefügg, és tele van egyedi mechanizmussal. A Tigrisnek más az erénye: olyan bonyolult, hogy ötletem sincs 1 parti után, van-e nyerő stratégia. Tehát nehéz őket összehasonlítani, most a Tigrisre szavazok.
---
Pörgősen játszva másfél óra alatt lemehet...
---
Miért nincs kompenzálva a kezdővel szemben a többi játékos?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

... es ami meg ennel is nagyobb baki, es teljesen egyenlotlen felteteleket teremt ...

De ezek ellenere sem tudnek ra soha nemet mondani...
Hibai ellenere - az egyik legnagyobb!

The new version (Pegasus) - "7"
Az uj szabalyok (pl.istallo) bevezetese szamora csak rontott a helyzeten.

Az uj MayFair kiadas nagyon szepre sikeredett!

RATING: 7.5
Feb-17-2008
The first time I played the game it was a 2-player game and someone else was teaching it to me.  Today is the first time I played this as a 4-player game.  I actually enjoyed it even though there is quite a bit direct conflict.  I did not feel like I was getting ganged up on or feeling out of the game if I lost conflicts here and there.  One of the players thought there was a significant advantage for going first.  I am not sure I agree with her.  My biggest worry at the moment are the tile draws and just losing the conflicts.  I am looking forward to playing it more.  I am rating it a 7.5 because I think it is a good game but I am not sure if I should add it to my collection.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I've played this a few times over the years and each time I feel like I learn something new about the game. It's incredibly deep. From a pure game play standpoint, the game is easily an 8 or above. If everyone involved knows the game well, T&E is simply brilliant and tense. 

However, it plays so abstractly that passable strategies are not immediately apparent, and only start developing after you've played a few times. This makes introducing players to Tigris & Euphrates a bit difficult. If you do decide to take the plunge and teach one or two players, those players are likely to need hand-holding throughout the first game or two. Even deciding what to do on your turn is informed by knowing the strategy, so the first couple of games with players new to T&E can be terrible experiences. I rarely choose this as a game to teach for that reason. I'd easily rather teach Vinhos to people than T&E. In view of those drawbacks, the game, despite its brilliance, rarely gets played in its physical form (I do play the app quite regularly, though). These criticisms are similar to lots of heavier games (e.g., see my comments for Brass: Lancashire), but T&E suffers in comparison to those games because of its abstract nature. Also, due to its conflict-based game play, T&E is a much more chaotic experience than other "heavy" strategy games. That chaos may be a plus or a minus for individual players.

It doesn't play great at 2 and is best at 4. If you had a consistent group of 4, you could play this game for years and I expect it would still be fresh. This might be good as a chess replacement for a family of 4 with two intelligent children. However, most of my gaming is done with 2 (kid's way too young) and I don't have the willingness to devote a large chunk of my gaming time to mastering this classic game. 

Update, Sept 2017: OK. This game is some sort of pleasant earwig. I keep thinking about it, even if I haven't played it for a few weeks/months. I'll bump this rating up to better reflect the strength of its design, as opposed to how often I'll play it. If I was rating this solely on its mechanisms, it would be a 9 to 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Unique and clever scoring system for a "simple" tile-laying game.  There is a little something missing somewhere in the end game; the evidence being the fact that screens are required to conceal the points you have scored so far.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Board Game! Double scenario edition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent. Only two actions per turn, and only four (?) types of actions to choose from, but each action has many choices. Heavy interaction between players.  Can be very intense to figure out how to spend your two actions because each play is important.  The scoring method is genius and works so well because of the inter-relation between tile-play, leaders, and the two types of conflicts.  Perhaps most important, the theme of building cities really stands out.  Cities are easy to take externally when they're small, but when they get large the fighting must be internal.

Hard to compare with other games, but I feel that I have more options with T&E than with Puerto Rico. Very difficult to understand the first game or two.  The end conditions and the balance of importance on the artifacts are also brilliant.  Going for artifacts tends to stretch out cities and make them vulnerable to catastrophes and then external conflicts, while making monuments makes cities more valuable while making them weaker against external conflicts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Was that abstract?

RATING: 9.5
FAVORITE EURO GAME

2-4 Players (Best: 4) / 90 Min / Weight: 3.53

RATING: 6
Playing Tigris is sort of like playing a Gipf game... except that it features a random tile draw and supports up to 4 players.  I also think of Tigris as a gamer's version of Scrabble.  Anyway, I highly enjoy Tigris 50% of the time for it often can get really intense and exciting.  However, Tigris can also turn out to be highly frustrating and dull.  It largely depends on the random tile draw.  I will probably never turn down a game of Tigris for each session has the potential to be an outstanding gaming experience worthy of the BBG Top Ten.  However, I have had plenty of bad sessions in which one player was unable to draw enough Red Tiles in order to stay competitive.

RATING: 9
The game is good.  It makes you think through every move and a couple after.  You have the opportunity to plan ahead, but also have to keep an open mind as conflicts can quickly change the face of the game.

The conflicts, monument building and treasures can be confusing at the beginning of the game but after a couple plays everything makes sense.  The end of game scoring makes it necessary to build in all areas of the game as your lowest score is the one that counts towards the win.  

Update: I do only play it on bgg now, but I can't seem to get enough of it and it deserves a near perfect rating.

RATING: 7
A game with a fascinating mechanism which takes a while to grasp. Like Lowenherz and El Grande it's quite an abstract shuffling of colored counters across the board. The theme isn't important at all and in this case it feels especially pasted-on. What is important is gaining insight in the dynamics of how the different groups of colors work together. 
In the end I found this game too mathematic - as much fun as filling out an excel sheet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent heavy game from the man Knizia. Plays well with 2-4, but my friend and i prefer 2 since there is more control. Nightmare to teach this one, but the rewards of learning it become apparent on every play. You wouldnt want all stratagies to become transparent on first play anyway would you?

RATING: 9
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1998[/b]

[i]Posted: 1/31/06, Rated: 8[/i]
{2P: 8, 3P: 9, 4P: 7}

I feel like I'm committing some form of BGG heresy by not giving this game a rating of "10."  The reputation that this game enjoys makes learning it seem daunting.  I strongly recommend playing a game or two online, with people that will take the time to explain the basic moves. After your first game, rules that once seemed fidgety melt away, leaving streamlined elegance.

And for the most part, this game is extremely enjoyable.  Somehow the classic Knizia trademark of "too many things to do, too little time to do them" is ever-present, while only having two actions per turn.  It's delightfully agonizing, as I keep wishing for [i]just one more action[/i], that I can never have.  Position play factors in heavily, so playing the board also is important.

However, the luck of the draw also plays a significant factor, and can undo the strongest play.  I've had a virtually impenetrable location undone by someone who drew five tiles of the same color (red), and was able to displace a leader in a crucial position.  The old adage about losing the war for want of a nail could be said about [i]Tigris & Euphrates,[/i] only for the want of a Temple.

[i]Tigris & Euphrates[/i] plays decently with two, shines with three, and is a nerve-wracking madhouse with four.  The starting positions may as well be marked on the board.  It is a wonderful game, and I do enjoy playing it, even if my enthusiasm can be doused by lucky draws.

[i]Updated: 2/7/09, Rated: 9[/i]
{2P: 10, 3P: 9, 4P: 8}

Like a fine wine, [i]Tigris & Euphrates[/i] has gotten better with age and experience.  Side note: the analogy [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_wine#Early_history]appears to be appropriate[/url].  After acquiring some perspective on game mechanics by playing many other titles, I was surprised by how refreshingly elegant these rules really are.  My old "complaint" about lacking Temple tiles can be mitigated somewhat through strategic development: provide more support for your leaders while limiting the "attach points" for your opponents.  

An external conflict provides more of a challenge to defend against, since you typically can't be evenly strong in all four colors.  Even if you are building evenly, your opponent can load up in one color to gain an advantage.  Tile draws can still make the difference in any conflict, but that fact adds tension to the game.

I'm now a solid fan of [i]Tigris & Euphrates[/i].  The only reason it doesn't deserve a "10" is that I believe the quality of the gameplay tapers off as more players are added.  Still, I will play this game at every opportunity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
At first glance I was very skeptical to this one. It did take some explaning before I got a soft grasp of the tactics of the game. The goal is to collect as many goods as you can. This can be done by your own production or through hotsile takeovers of nearby kingdoms. The goods have 4 colors and you may only count your score by the color you have least in. This is where the game gets very tactical. You may easily get massive amounts in one color but to win it all you have to have the most divided among them.

By looking at picture or the board it is very difficult to understand how it is played but in short each square you place on the board adjecent to a kingdom with one of your leaders (the wooden circles with symbols) will grant you 1 good of the color of the placed tile. But only.., and this is important, if you have a leader of that color in the chosen kingdom. (Or the black leader which is universal for all colors but red) 

There are exceptions in the rules which makes it hard to play the first time but after having played it once it is quite easy to grasp and play again. The hardest part really is to figure out a good tactic where you stay out of hostile attacks from your enemies but in turn can make hostile attacks on them to have the advantage. 

If given the chance this game will prove fun with your friends and the element of attacks is a big bonus to the gameplay and makes the game a whole lot more interesting but also alot more unpredictable.

This works great even with 3 players which I find is often the poorest number of persons to play in most games for them to stay fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tigris & Euphrates is a slightly odd game. It was apparently designed with its theme in mind, yet is very abstract. It uses colors in a way which forces players to bend their minds a bit. It is a Eurogame, but has no roles, buildings, etc. and quite a lot of direct player interaction. And it is wonderful.

The (very abstracted) gameplay matches the theme very well (obviously not the actions, but the [i]ideas[/i] and the overall picture), as kingdoms rise and fall and different dynasties compete for influence in all sectors of life. The game strikes a very good balance between long-term strategic planning and short-term tactical play. Players can form a vision for what they might want to do with their leaders and kingdoms, but must be flexible in defending against (or initiating!) conflicts with other leaders. The scoring system is very clever and helps balance the game without any artificial mechanisms (e.g., Power Grid), and the game-end conditions allow players some influence over ending the game when it is most advantageous. 

Tigris & Euphrates does a great job of incorporating chance (through the tile draw) but allowing players different ways to mitigate bad luck: a player can build a monument with excess tiles of a single color to gain tiles of a needed color, build up strength in one color in the short term to focus on other colors later (as a short-term deficit in one color means other players are more likely to be gaining points in that color at present, and later in the game they may not compete as strongly for that color [e.g., from monuments]), discard the extras in a conflict (a key strategic point, and the reason the 'English variant' should be avoided), or if necessary use an action to swap tiles. It isn't hard to find games where chance determines a player's fortune. In Tigris & Euphrates, chance influences what a player can (or must) do in the short term, but does not dictate his play. 

More than other recent Eurogames, Tigris and Euphrates allows for concealed plans and subtle play within the rigidly defined structure. Perhaps it comes from the game's spatial nature (something not present in most Eurogames, at least to this extent). It is possible to feint, to build up a kingdom and prepare for conflict, only to move away at the last minute to focus elsewhere. This feels like a game of chess in which a player focuses strength on one area of the board, forcing his opponent to commit more resources to the defense, only to calmly switch his focus elsewhere, knowing that he has gained enough of an advantage by forcing his opponent to react to the threat of conflict, and that the [i]actual[/i] conflict is not necessary. (Perhaps this is overstating it a touch, but still the point stands.)

I recognize that Tigris & Euphrates is a bit too abstract, too confrontational, too dry for some, but I think it is wonderful. The game lacks the thematic feel of other Eurogames (e.g., "I'm a builder this turn!" or "I'm the captain -- all goods aboard!" in Puerto Rico), but in return players are granted great flexibility in playing the game, which can sometimes be lacking in the more thematic games. In my mind, this is a welcome trade-off -- not that I don't enjoy more 'typical' Eurogames (quite the contrary!), but I find Tigris & Euphrates' strengths to be far more than enough compensation for its abstract nature. 

In my mind, this is a modern classic. Simply wonderful. (2012-03)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Excellent Production quality. Get someone to explain the rules first time out to avoid the headache of the written rules. Subsequent games have shown how deep the strategies are with this one.

Without doubt this is a strategic masterpiece with so much scope and flexibility. 4 player game is much faster.

2nd edition adds a new board and new buildings. After one play it seems an excellent addition to a superb game.

Reduced rating to 8.5. The tile distribution can greatly help or hinder you and some games will always be an uphill struggle and never be a contender as a result. It no longer deserves a 9 as a result. 

Time marches on and I become more disenchanted with the fact that the lottery of the tile draw is a factor that you can do nothing to adjust. Most games will have a pivotal swing where a shortage of a specific colour will ruin a players game plan and chances of winning. Telling me that this evens out with multiple plays does not excuse the heavy injection of luck for a game that has never been played twice in the same evening in my experience.

On the cusp of selling/ trading.....and sold

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tags: 1stTier, TandE

I think this is my favorite sort of "thinking" game after Go.  This, Acquire, and Reef Encounter all share similar mechanics with different tweaks that give each their own flavor.  
  
The civilization theme really does go well with this game, from a historical perspective.  Actually, I'd say that "history of civilization" is the theme here.  The icons, tile types, etc. all follow Campbell's (of Journey of the Hero fame) description of the growth and history of the river valley, right down to temple support of leaders.
  
That said, this game is surprisingly fun on its own terms; not too heavy, while offering various possibilities for strategy.
  
I keep this game around because it's a tile laying game of the type of which I'm fond.  Non-gamers ready to move onto something more complex---or who are already there---seem to like this game a lot.  Growing your cities and civilization, engaging in conflict---civilization video games basically boil down to this goal, and T&E gives you that without getting excessivly complex.  I also like the Knizia scoring mechanic---both through the leaders and through needing to balance out your scores in each color---and I do like the theme.  I prefer the Mayfair version, actually, because of the art on the tiles; fortunately I have the edition without the confusing non-river river bend.

These days, I play Reef Encounter more because I like its nature theme.  If I liked historical themes better, I would play T&E more.  Both games are on equal footing with one another in terms of complexity and thoughtful fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

Every time I even look at the box, I think about how much of genius Reiner Knizia must be.

RATING: 8
One of my favorite games. It is not easy to get into, and the strategies can take a long time to grasp. But after the game has 'clicked' it just keeps getting better.

I enjoy playing the Turn-Based online implimentation [url=www.BoardGameGeek.Com/Tigris]here[/url] on BGG and all of my games that are not played face-to-face are played here.

See my [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1781368]review[/url] for my full thoughts.

I believe the advanced rules in the new wdition of the game do add some additional elements to the game. A little bit more power to the pacifist strategies and internal conflicts. They add maybe a little more tension to the game.

RATING: 9
One of my favorite games. It is not easy to get into, and the strategies can take a long time to grasp. But after the game has 'clicked' it just keeps getting better.

I enjoy playing the Turn-Based online implimentation [url=www.BoardGameGeek.Com/Tigris]here[/url] on BGG and all of my games that are not played face-to-face are played here.

See my [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1781368]review[/url] for my full thoughts on the English Fisrt Edition.

I like the advanced rules, they certainly add something to the game strengthening the pacifist strategies in a manner that doesn't weaken them to external conflict.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
[b]Best with: 4[/b]
[b]3p rating: 8[/b]
[b]2p rating: 7 (nile map)[/b]

[b]7/18/13[/b]
After debating giving this game a perfect score some things really bother me about it.

-No compensation for late turn order, especially with 4 players. 
-The tile draw can be brutal. I appreciate this luck and see it's importance to the game, but the volatility it creates leaves a little to be desired. So it's essential to what this game is, but somehow limits this game from being a top-notch competitive affair. You can only dump tiles so much before you ruin your score. I think this goes away a bit with more competent and familiar play, but I've seen people "stuck" with a hand (and re-filled hand) of blue tiles with no room to start a new kingdom without getting squished. It seems to be a little rougher when you slammed with blue tiles. You can't use them to build a monument paired with the color you really need if the delta is already established. Also, some of the "boom-boom" plays, the situations where a player causes an external conflict and through a scattering of reinforcements players end up with a monochromatic hand and rape you in the following turn. Like mentioned, good play can minimize the tile draw chaos.
-The last point, among other factors, results in a game more tactical than I'd like.
-The game plays best with 4, but that player count only exacerbates the above 3 problems.

Still it's a game that I'd nearly never turn down. It has a geometric feel to it, almost abstract, that still works well with all the moving parts around it. It's almost elegant and simple enough to give off a "traditional" game vibe- like you could imagine this game having been played for a couple hundred years... well maybe that's a stretch, but compared to modern euro's of the past few years, the game is simple from a structural and mechanical point of view. This was one of the first games I bought back in 2006. Although it didn't hit the table a lot in the beginnings, it's seen fairly heavy table time from about 2010 on and I don't think it's going anywhere. If I could see a log the games played for 2023, I'd be shocked if we weren't still having fun with this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Own iOS Version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Very deep game with a lot of very tough choices to make. A Modern classic.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Components: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Rules: :star::star::star::star::nostar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really love this game. Easy to learn basic mechanics. Repercussions of choices and chain reactions is the complex part. Once you understand the ebb and flow of points as the result of external conflicts and how internal conflicts work to set up for external conflicts the decisions can be downright agonizing. Again love it. Setup is a breeze. Another game with a mechanic that will allow one player to hasten the conclusion.

Strategies
Wear your strength on your sleeve and by this I mean bluff if you have to! You want to give your opponents a reason NOT to engage conflict with you until you can beat them. Showing out strength plants doubt about what you may have in your hand.

Try to get your leaders next to as many red tiles as possible, while at the same time prevent engagement of internal conflict by not leaving open red sides for enemy leaders to attach themselves. If you are strong externally and there is no temple to attach to, you can often go untouched and unchallenged, offering more time to increase your strength.

Be careful of engaging external conflict between others. It's fun to do, but all you are doing is giving points to others but not yourself! Only create external conflict between your opponents if removing one of their leaders benefits you and the spoils of victory are small (no more than 2).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Keeps getting better and better.  In particular, I like the direct conflict and the fluidity of the control pieces.

RATING: 9.3

Oh I just love it.

But forget long term strategy, this is a game of opportunism, parry and riposte. Fortune favours the brave.

RATING: 10
This is an amazing 2 player game.  Its a wrestling match - keep your friends close and your enemies closer...

3p and 4p are good too, but more chaotic as you can be attacked several times and wiped out before your turn comes back.

It always amazes me how you can turn a losing position into a victory with a couple good moves and the right tiles.

With 2 equally skilled players, sometimes it can come down to luck depending on who draws the most red tiles.  However make the most of the tiles you draw and you have a good chance to win.

Still one of my favorites - I play online at BGG all the time.

RATING: N/A
Alkatrészek:
A szokásos gyönyörű FFG doboz. Az ember sajnálja kibontani, mert olyan jól néz ki és utána úgyis csak a polckopás jön. Bár bevallom a csillogó dobozokat jobban kedvelem, mint ezt a matt FFG félét.
Amin kiakadtam egy 17 ezer forintos játéknál:
- a paraván minősége. Az egy vicc. Egy szellő elfújja
- a műanyag alkatrészek nevetségesek. Ráadásul faragni kell, hogy összeilleszthető legyen. A színei csúnyák. Totálisan nem ehhez a játékhoz valók.
- Miért nem lehetett a fakockákat fakockáknak hagyni. Most karton tokeneket tettek bele.
- Nem voltak benne műanyag zacskók, pedig szükség van rájuk.
- A belső tárló is egy vicc.
Ami tetszett:
- Benne van a kiegészítő
- A karton alkatrészek grafikai minősége elsőosztályú és a grafikai is tetszetős.
- A tábla kétoldalú
- Elsőosztályú húzózsákot adtak hozzá logóval :)

RATING: 8
A very interesting game with a unique victory condition. collect a number of victory points in various colours and the one with the most in his least pile wins. this is the only thing that makes the game worth the play. i wish i could get my family to play more so that they would stop getting confused by the game-play but thats the way the cookie crumbles and with the amount of games i get to play i can't complain.

And if you don't play often the game-play is very confusing. internal battle? external battle? what colour cards are we using to fight with? why are you counting the ones on the table? so who fights next? why is my leader coming off the board?  

It is just confusing until you get it nailed!

RATING: 8.75

There is some luck in the tiles drawing but not more than , for example, in Brass with the cards. I mean, the best player is going to win 9 of 10 times.

Unfortunately, this game hits the table less than what I really want, that keeps me away for playing dencently, anyway I keep loving it and I'll keep it in my collection.

Knizia's best creation from when he was designing very good games.

RATING: 8.2

RATING: 9
評分:ForLight:6.5 ForHard:9 複雜度:7.5 互婊度:9

性質上很像下棋，自己辛苦建立的帝國被其他玩家侵略下來我相信對輕玩家並不好受，但這遊戲的計分幾制，策略深度都是我玩過的桌遊中數一數二的。

1.一開始應該先擺放黑色觀察狀況
2.手上儘量多保留紅色
3.神殿今收入大幅增加，也令防禦力下降，這兩個因素都會引來其他玩家的侵入，所以是否要建造神殿，甚麼時候建造是很重要的。
4.無時無刻注意自己需要的分數是甚麼種類

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Interesting tile laying game by the master (RK). Nothing here to complain about or wish had been done differently as regards mechanics, and the scoring of your "weakest" suit to determine winner is a clever twist. I can enjoy the game but (as with many Euros) I find it a somewhat sterile exercise in working the game mechanics. Sure all games end up that way when stripped down to essentials, but games I enjoy more put them in the background and keep their theme foremost in your mind (most CDGs manage this elegantly). This game reminds me of El Grande in the manner by which the mechanics dwarf and indeed totally submerge the theme. I'll play it but seldom suggest it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
Totally cool game!  You can only learn to win by playing.  There is plenty of conflict, enough to rate it as a war game.  This is another of one of the five euro classics I think everyone at sometime should play or own.

This game is about placing tiles to gain control and make victory points. You can create clever balancing engines in the form of temples, that can generate additional VP blocks for your pool.  I think no matter how many times you played it, you would continue to gain new insight to how to win with it.  

It is so unique that it is hard to describe its mechanincs until you have played it.

It plays great with 4 people.

The scoring mechanics are something that it takes playing 3-4 times to get the hang of.

RATING: 8
2009-01-15: Just got it and have been playing a couple of games by myself.  Not sure about it yet...

2013-09-18: In the past four and a half years, I've racked up hundreds of plays on BGG.  I traded my copy because BGG was the only way I ever played it.  Unfortunately, a couple of months ago, BGG closed their online implementation so I've reacquired it.  I've played it a couple of times and it remains my favorite war game.  Don't ever let anyone tell you this is a Euro.  It's a wargame (or to be more precise, conflict simulation) disguised as a Euro. Players can either turtle and hope their civilizations will be left alone or expand and pounce on those monument building, turtling cowards.  Building a strong connected infrastructre is key, but sometimes you just have to take a chance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Comprado en la pcra en Dic2010 gracias a un chivatazo de el_mago8.
Hay cuatro tipos de losetas y cada jugador dispone de un lider de cada uno de los cuatro colores. Los líderes solo se pueden poner ortogonalmente adyacentes a las losetas rojas. Cuando se coloca una loseta, se recibe un cubito del color de la loseta si ésta fue colocada en un reino en el que está presente tu líder de ese color. Los grupos de losetas adyacentes conforman reinos. Cuando dos lideres del mismo color coinciden en el mismo reino se produce un conflicto interno. Cuando una loseta provoca que se unan dos reinos se produce un conflicto externo. La partida acaba cuando alguien no puede reponer su mano de seis losetas, o cuando los cubitos comodin (que consigue el líder verde) se reducen a 2 (comienzan 10 en el juego).
Es muy táctico y ofrece muchas posibilidades. El jugador se puede recuperar rapidamente de los contratiempos del juego. Mucha interacción entre jugadores y rejugabilidad infinita. Algunos lo tildan de demansaido cerebral. Un gran juego, sin duda recomendable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Deep, very deep. Love the minimum limit scoring system.

L'objectif de chaque joueur est d'accumuler 4 sortes de Points de Victoires (PV) en installant ses propres chefs a la tête des différents royaumes qui vont se constituer et évoluer.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Challenging! High level of competition for control of kingdoms and monuments creates many opportunities for conflict. There is an element of surprise since it is difficult to anticipate exactly how a kingdom will be configured, with leaders and power, following the placement of a single tile (external conflict). The internal confict move is probably the most difficult of tactical moves - it can use so many temple tiles, yet gain you such a strategic foothold in another kingdom. Poses interesting decisions each turn. Should you really build that monument so early, even though you have the tiles? Other players will want to move into your kingdom, so be careful! In 3-4 player games, all players need to be equal so that an ill-conceived move does not benefit one of the other two players too much. In this respect, can be a bit chaotic if all are not experienced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Abstract civilization game. Difficult to teach, though simple rules. In order to win VP you must destroy kingdoms (nice...). Needs several plays in order to get the flow of it. Very gamers game.

RATING: 6.5
Rated for the app. I have enjoyed it, but it makes my head hurt, really hard to immerse yourself in this one, which is a bit of a turn off for me. Still, a really epic style Knizia game, which is really interesting to play. If you can grok it, then it's worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A highly tactical game. Lots of strategy with a pinch of luck thrown in. Engaging and brain burning. I particularly like the conflict (internal, external or otherwise). At first, I thought it was abstract but with replay, the subtle themes of kingdom building, war and conflict shine through. Simply a brilliant game from Dr.Knizia.

For a euro, it has an unusual amount of conflict between players. The tension is part of the great fun of this masterpiece. Holds up to replay very well.

We have played with the expansion on the alternate board with the German Pegasus Spiel edition. The expansion does not improve or add to the game, but rather it gives a variant. It's all good; with or without the expansion.

NB approx. once every 12 games, one's tile draw can be so crappy that it 'breaks' that game. Despite this one drawback, it still deserves a 10. 

Update March 2012:
Rating has dropped from 10 to 9.5.
It had been a 10 for 6 years. But now that I've played it 50 times against the iPad AI opponent, I realize how much of this game is luck dependent on tile draw. It's drawing the right tiles at the right time that makes or breaks this game. Sad that it is no longer a 10 for me. But 9.5 still speaks to its quality outside of the small luck element. 

Update September 2017:
T & E is 20 years old but it holds up! Not surprising, since essentially it is an abstract and they have much more longevity than euros. The playtime of 45 to 60 minutes is excellent for a game of this depth and conflict. An added bonus that it scales equally well for 3 or 4 players. A classic game of tactics that will stand the test of time, and not simply because it is old, but because it is that good. 

Still Knizia's opus magnum that he hasn't been able to top himself.

RATING: 9
I played this game for the first time today, and I find it supperb.  Set yourself up and formulate a winning strategy, and another player can quickly change the dynamics of the board with a single piece at times, making it is a fantastic strategy on the fly game.  The possibilities for points are everywhere, and maximizing them is the fun.  Plus, its a fairly simple game to learn, not too long, and great looking.  Instantly one of my favorite games.  Not given a perfect score because near the end of the game, sometimes people can get stuck if they have not used some of their pieces to the perfect advantage and luck can be a definate factor.

RATING: 9
A Knizia masterpiece.

The available moves are simple and straightforward (place a tile, move a leader, discard and redraw tiles), but the complexity of the interactions between them is staggering.

One fellow BGG member (whose name I forget) noted that T&E is excellent for encouraging creative play. I concur. There are always multiple paths to victory, and even the most well-fortified kingdoms can be toppled through clever use of internal/external conflicts.

RATING: 9

Having the balanced approach for victory...to me...is simply brilliant! Requires equally skilled players which becomes difficult since the game lends itself to the more brainiac type player. Still a great game and, so far, always willing to play.

RATING: 8
Everything that is wonderful, and everything that is terrible about German games in one box.  Wonderful = deep strategy, wonderful and clean design, superior components and art, simple rules.  Terrible = themeless, mathematical, and I will never be able to tell a good story about a game of T&E.  I really like it, but there's a crucial part that's missing, and that part is the theme that makes the game tell a story.  At the end of the game, I hadn't experienced the thrill of developing the land around the Rivers, I had nstead engaged in a mathematical exercise with a spatial component.  Maybe I'm just getting old.

RATING: 6
It's an OK game, but I just don't see what all the fuss is about. You play the tiles you have or swap them out either if they're all bad or you want to drive the game to a quick end. Try to keep your victory points balanced, and protect your interests when it matters, but keep in mind that the positions of your rulers really doesn't matter all that much until you're connected to a temple and raking in bonus cubes. Don't get too attached to any particular color of tile, *especially* red tiles, and be quick to move elsewhere when local returns diminish. Tactics aren't particularly straightforward, but they're no brain burner, for sure.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For a Knizia game, T&E has some tough and fiddly rules. We had a hard time remembering which tiles are useful for which conflicts. And there are also different rules for determining the initial support that your leader has. But there is an amazing ebb-and-flow to the game, and a beautiful mix of luck (from the tile draw -- wonderful tension when you attack, not knowing if you can succeed) and skill (from placements, shoring up your leaders' support, etc.).

One major problem with the 2p game is that sheer luck can lead one player to dominate by having her players take over an entire kingdom, banishing the other player's leaders. Once that happens, the other player is sunk -- he might as well concede. Otherwise he loses by embarrassing margins. (I say this from bitter experience.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I suspect that problem could be solved by more plays and look forward to that.

RATING: 10
This game has two notable negatives for me: thin theme and highly abstract gameplay.  Thus, it's an excellent example of how objective factors can't be used to compute a rating for a game.  If I were to rate all of the individual pieces of this game and put them together, it would get a pretty mediocre rating.  But instead, it's the only game in my collection that I will instantly agree to play, will play over and over again, and never get tired of.  I've started to get a bit tired of Puerto Rico, but have never gotten tired of this.  And I've been playing T&E longer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've been playing the new Pegasus version, and it's interesting how much the variant board changes the game. I didn't think it would make that much difference, really, but it did produce a game with a very different feel to it.

The little mini-monuments, on the other hand, seemed rather awkward (especially thematically) and like they didn't add much to the game at all.

Funny that playing the new edition of T&E has caused me to re-evaluate my rating, and kick it up to a 10. Not sure if I just had become burned out and needed a break, and now it's back, or what. It does seem that there is a class of Knizia games that are so intense and pack so much game into a small-ish package that they can easily be over-played. For me, T&E, Blue Moon, and Beowulf all fall into this category - I love them all, and consider them some of the best games ever made, but wouldn't want to play them every week, just because they're so involving that after playing it you need to step back and play something lighter, like a Settlers or something.

Is the new edition worth it if you already have one of the previous editions? Probably not, given the cost of importing it. But as a game collector, the new map has enough of a different play feel, and the aesthetic of the game is quite different from either the Mayfair or the Hans im GlÃ¼ck version, and I'm happy to own it (I own all three versions now). It's probably the least graphically effective of the three editions, in my opinion - although most people I know like the Mayfair version less than I do - but I still do like the richer colors and more evocative tiles.
---
Interestingly, this game has not quite achieved the greatness that seemed it's destiny when first released. Obviously, we're talking degrees of greatness - it's a very, very good game - but it doesn't seem to go "over the top". I think it's because the luck element (in the form of the tile draws) is just a little bit too heavy, and there is far too much potential for a mistake by one player to hose or massively benefit an uninvolved third party (this is an attribute of many games which don't suffer for it; but it's evidenced too much in this game). Still a very fine game which is highly recommended, but just misses my top-10 all time list.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A Euro with fighting! A game that really forces you to think things through. I've had victory snatched out from under me so many times in this game.

RATING: 9
T&E deserves a place in the boardgaming hall of fame, if one is ever built.  For players who enjoy deep strategy, T&E can be dangerously addictive.  The frustration level in this game can reach the boiling point, and it takes some time to explain the rules.  That's why I've given this game a 9 and not a 10.  However, when I get a group of serious gamers together, this is the box that we pull off the shelf.  It has an almost mythical status, and I salute Reiner Knizia for offering yet another profound board gaming experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Overall I find T&E fascinating, elegant, and excellent in terms of interaction.  This is due to a design that uses simple mechanisms and few action choices but one that allows for numerous tile placement possibilities.   Unfortunately some eurogamers today don't have much interest in T&E and maybe this is because of the emphasis on tactical and luck factors over pure engine-building strategy, the degree of abstraction in the theme, the nature of it having direct conflict, and perhaps some confusion with the rules and tactics on first play. After awhile things seem to devolve into tactical prowess, chaos, and plain-old fashioned luck (especially with more players).  Losses in war can have a huge impact on things and the winner can gain a huge boost in points.  Most Games end pretty close in scoring due to the scoring in the area that you have the fewest points in.    I really like how this forces you to balance out your approach and it can create more likelihood for conflict.  I found that Playing 3-4 player is the best while at 2 players i could find better games to play.  I also like that Players are not supposed to know exactly how well their opponents are doing leaving an element of mystery in the final scoring.  It is one of those games where it can be hard to see the board at first with all the options available.  A novice will often not be able to take advantage of the opportunities that an experienced opponent notices.   Though I wish the wooden leaders were kept somehow, I really like the updated FFG artwork and tile components that really spice up the look and feel of the original.  Overall a very good game that everyone should play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A Brain burner - always feel a little tired after playing this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Updated 5/27/10.

Only two games under my belt, so take the rating with a HUGE grain of salt.  I usually don't rate a game this early, but I felt like I had a pretty strong grasp of the mechanics and preliminary strategy.  For some reason, this one was just sort of intuitive. 

As an abstract tile-laying game that is quite different that most anything I've played, I really enjoy the experience of playing T&E.  The gameplay itself has a lot of tough choices and interesting chain reactions that take some foresight and careful planning to benefit from.  Most importantly, the game mandates interaction.  It's a game of positioning, akin to a chess match, and for some reason one of my personal favorite sensations in all of boardgaming is the jab-counter-jab-block-feint-counter back-and-forth of matching wits with a talented opponent in a game such as this.  (I'm terrible at chess and generally hate abstracts, however, lest the chess comment turn you off to T&E.  This is a whole different animal.)  

I would have preferred a more attractive board and bits (something about the artwork didn't resonate with me) and I struggled with the lack of theme (I just wanted SOME explanation for what the VPs are and how they related to each piece on the board).  I'm not sure my gaming group got the same experience out of it that I did and so I can't really see myself pulling it off the shelf that often.  If someone else wanted to play, however, I'm confident I'd have a great time.

Wife:8
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Initial thoughts after only 1 playing (btw Luke very expertly explained the rules, thanks).  Although I see some advantages of the "least color scores" idea, I feel it produces anti-climactic games to say the least.  Players must address their weaknesses instead of taking advantage of the strengths.  For example let's say you had this in an American Civil War game.  The South would be compelled to give up making use of their more experienced troops or better leaders, and instead just do all they could to build up their limited manpower, knowing all along this was unlikely to lead to victory (because by definition this is where they are weak, and is extremely boring also).  Similarly, the Union would not have time to make much use of their naval ability or great manpower, instead they should establish an officer's school, and maybe invade Canada to give them some experience.  In other words, working on your weakness (probably in a tangential way to the main action) instead of your strengths is no so much fun, imho.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dec 2006: 
The crème de la crème of German games together with El Grande, Puerto Rico and IMO In the Shadow of the Emperor. Knizia's masterpiece (as is widely acknowledged).

Funny though that Knizia's prone to copy himself. One of his 2004 releases, Einfach Genial!, seems to me to be the little brother of E&T. Simpler rules and abstract. I played that game before discovering E&T. 

IMO. The mechanics reflect the theme in many ways. That said, I maintain the same about El Grande. Indeed, I find it sad some claim its theme is pasted on. It's IMO a very elegant "German" treatment of the rise and fall of Mesopotamian city states - meaning it captures the essence that topic rather than being a history lesson (American-style games offer you that sort of experience). Quite frankly, I believe those calling it weakly themed just don't get it. Nasty me. :p
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Only played a couple of two players games because unfortunately my girlfriend didn't care for it as much as I did, nor did one of the members of my game group. However, I came away from my first two plays thinking that it's now my favorite Knizia after Modern Art. Could be a 10 if I ever get to play it more.

UPDATE: After more plays, I still like it quite a bit but I don't see it climbing in ratings as I originally thought it might. This is mostly because it's too dependent on the luck of the draw, overwhelming most long term planning. Still, it's a solid game that I'm more than happy to play. I still need to play it more, especially with 3 and 4 players before I can really judge it.

UPDATE: Played several more games with 2, 3, and 4 players. It works with any number of players and the luck of the tile draw doesn't detract from the game like I thought it would. There's a lot of depth and replayability here for the given complexity and playing time. Boosting my rating to a 9.

RATING: N/A
