=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
High player interaction. Sufficiently complex to require intuition. A very good game. Very aggressive too, so it's a nice contrast as compared to more indirect games like Puerto Rico. Furthermore the mechanism enabling a player to spark a war between two other players can be fun!

It plays reasonably fast (60-120, leaning towards 80min) and the theme fits good enough if one accepts that each player controls a dynasty of nobles that are spread out among several neighboring kingdoms, rather than a particular nation itself. (Think of european noble houses, which controlled several nations and even had wars amongst themselves.)

BIGGEST DRAWBACKS: Turn-order matters, less as in Puerto Rico though. Generally you are safe against your right-hand neighbor and prone to your left-hand neighbor in conflicts sparked by third parties. Medium to low luck influence. Starting player seems to have a competitive edge over later players.

Not suitable for players which are prone to analysis-paralysis and want to compute every little detail.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like the theme to fit the mechanic better. Easy to play, and you can play simply, but there's also some thinky-ness if you want to go there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Double sided board edition. 

I need a lot more plays to be halfway decent at this game. But from what I've played, it is incredibly deep in strategy, offers a wealth of different paths to take, and contrary to what most say, feels quite thematic to me. 

I feel the luck of drawing tiles holds it back from being a 9, although it is well mitigated. It just feels like you could get shafted for a number of turns before drawing what you need to carry out your strategy. And this isn't as reactive a game as, say, Neuroshima Hex to excuse it. At it's heart, it's an engine building game, with area control layered heavily on top of it.

Knizia might be an egotist, but his games are winning me over. Well done.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It is hard to define what is great about this game. Even though I believe this game to be great.

The battle to figure out how to turn your random tile draws into a balanced assortment of points, is definitely something that is exciting. The battle to start wars between your opponents that devastate their positions, leaving you with an in is fantastic and gives you opportunities for beautiful plays. Putting your opponents in lose lose situations is great. Sacrificing a battle for side benefits is certainly clever.

The problem is the game gives you so much with so little. So many possibilities during play for surprising inventive creative play, with a rule set that is spartan compared to games that get released today. I lack the vocabulary to properly explain why T&E is such an incredible game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It seem fairly strategically and tactically rich, but it just kinda bores me. As abstract as abstract comes, and as such, the rules are overdone and too unintuitive to compete with the truly brilliant and elegant abstracts (Go, Chess, Backgammon, even the Gipf series), while the utter themelessness (I'm not buying any of this nonsense about it 'feeling' like the rise and fall of Civs--bullshit) makes it pretty poor competition for other mid/high complexity Euros for me. To me, it never felt like anything more than a totally abstract cube-management exercise, and I like cube-management exercises, at least at a less-complex, or better-themed level. Dry, dry, bone dry and too little control for something that is supposedly 'deep'. I really don't see the appeal. Traded

UPDATE

All that said, I'd like to play it some more because I'm starting to realize that Knizia's games often take a few more plays to really shine. I'm staying open-minded in the hopes of playing again.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
Based on 1 play with 2 players: I bought this and Reef Encounter on the same day... I didn't realize they were quite so similar! Reef Encounter (based on first impressions) seems a little more interesting (and has less luck) but T&E has it beat in simplicity and elegance. Simple rules, good amount of strategy. I definitely need to play it again. We played with two players... and it seems like it would be really difficult to catch up if you fell behind with more players (especially 4). I'll have to try it with more sometime. I think I'd like this a lot more if I could play it with some regularity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
E&amp;T has so often been praised that the first time you play it you may find it a bit dissapointing (Too complex, too long  and too chaotic) but soon you will discover that the rules are quite intuitive, that you can build complex tactics, that you should look carefuly after your opponents moves, keep and eye on your resources, manages your civilisation tiles and your chiefs moves... At that moment, you must admit that E&amp;T is a great game with a very subtle and balanced mechanism (but may be reserved to hard core gamers).

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A great older game which I've unfortunately sold (one of my highest rated "previously owned" games - and I've only sold it as it's so hard to get to the table and it's almost only liked by me and my wife). When  played by just 2 players the game doesn't really work too well, and I vastly prefer it with 3 and 4 players! With 3 players, two of them can fight against each other while the last player can play his own game... Well, it isn't entirely true in this game as it's chaotic and there are lots of interaction, but you get the point. With 4 players, everybody are involved all the time and there will not be much free space to build on, so there will be lots of internal and external conflicts - excellent!

I think it is a pretty good game even though it's so old. I like that you can only do 2 things on your turn, which can be chosen from a few different actions, but there's always more than 2 things you want to do on your turn! To me, that's one of the signs of a great game. Also, it's a rather aggressive euro which is definitely not multiplayer solitaire and I like that for a change from the less confrontatial euro games which we have to admit form the vast majority... Oh, and the scoring mechanism is ingenious (!). Highly recommended!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Definitely a game that grows on you with gameplays. I'm still trying to work out the kinks with teaching this game - it's a very steep learning curve, but well worth it. No matter how clear you are with teaching, I think it takes a full gameplay before people really understand it. Also, with the enormous amount of possible moves at the beginning, new players often feel overwhelmed.

That said, I immediately noticed that since each player gets 2 moves on their turn, this game would take to couples/team play very easily. We tried it with three couples (two of the three couples being new players) and discovered that this is the ultimate way to teach the game - The couples immediately took to quietly discussing strategy and correcting each other on the rules during other people's turns. Fab game.. Tips I agree with: Definitely don't think you own anything on the board. Be extraordinarily flexible in your leader placement as to your needs. Play for the immediate point scores until you can learn to see further into the game. I'll start it at a 9 and expect it goes up. Thanks Santa!

[i]Update April 2007[/i] - The more I play the more depth I see. This is a fantastic game! As with Puerto Rico, I've put it at 9.5 now and the only reason it stays just below the mark is because it doesn't come out to play as often as I'd like. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Yep.  This is a fantastic game.  It keeps getting better every time I play it. Sure there are lots of rules and its a pain to teach, but its worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Strangely popular here on the Geek, given that the characteristics of T&E closely mirror those of unfashionable old American games such as Risk, albeit with some counterintuitive rules complexity added.  If you're the type of player who enjoys it when a roll of the die or a lucky run of tiles turns the game upside down, you may like this.  Planners won't enjoy it; gamblers will.  No one can safely avoid conflicts, because six tiles isn't enough to defend all of one's scoring sources.  The conflict outcomes are determined mostly by blind guessing and luck; if you make the rational play but your opponent happens to hold the tiles to defeat it, you're sunk.  Similarly, you're always vulnerable to one attack or the other, so if the attack is the one you can't defend, you're in trouble.  Only for those who don't mind seeing their best-laid plans constantly disrupted by Dame Fortune.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have played twice now.  Very intriguing game.  Can be a little frustrating with certain tile draws, but I'm still learning how to deal with those.  One of the few games that I could see rising to a 10 for me.  The replayability appears to be extremely high.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow. My head hurts. What an unusual game. T&E is the first game that makes me feel like I'm "a real gamer." I can't imagine what my reaction would be if this was the first Euro that I was introduced to.

This game makes my head spin because it inverts a lot of game conventions (i.e. "I'm this color." "This is my area, not yours.") The first game was jarring in that regard, but I'm looking forward to learning this game to the point where we all play smoothly with familiarity. 

Update: five plays, and this is still a solid 8. With each play, I find myself trying new tactics, and responding to the new tactics of my fellow gamer friends. There's a ton of depth packed into a game that lasts a very reasonable length of time. I can easily see myself revisiting this game off and on for the foreseeable future. My only knock on the game is that I don't see the theme like some others do, but the gameplay is so rich that I don't care.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
First thoughts based on one play (and it was a two player): 
Looks like the usual strategy games I like, but it's really an abstract game and I'm not fond of abstract games.  The theme seems extraneous to gameplay, bland, and not very engaging. Also I didn't like the artwork.  Reading through the rules was brutal as they are terribly written  and by the time we started to play we still had only a vague idea of what our goal was or even how a turn should play out.  

On a positive note, I started to enjoy the game about halfway through as I began to develop my strategy and a better understanding of the game. I would definitely be interested in playing again.  (Unfortunately, my gaming buddies don't feel the same way...)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is one of those games where I can see what both the people who like it, and hate it, see in the game.  It fits soundly in a category I refer to as Quasi abstract.  Not a true abstract as the random tile draws can make a significant difference.  And yet, not a richly themed or immersive experience.

Think chess, if the pieces were randomly drawn from a bag.

I have never liked the game per se, and I now find it gathering dust on the shelf.

Still I recommend everyone try it, it deserves to be in the top 25 games.  I'm just not sure if it should be in the top 10.

Addendum: Traded away and have never missed.

RATING: 10
High learning curve but well worth the effort.  Great game that is different every time and full of tense moments.  It takes a few games for the strategy to become clear but when it does...wow.  Clever game!  There is a lot of room for sly tactics that can rob another of his lofty position.  And I just love the way the board changes and evolves as the game unfolds.  Place one tile here and...bam...the power shifts and the board is different.  You can plan your next turn...but the player prior to you takes his turn, and now your great plan is not even possible.  Plays great with 2,3 or 4 players - although a much different feel with each level of play.

RATING: 8
I can see why this is compared to reef encounter so often, but I think I prefer reef encounter to this.  And here are the reasons why.
1)  The non-random tile selection in reef encounter seems a bit more in my wheelhouse then the draw some tiles from a bag mechanism in T&E
2)  Both games limit the number of actions you can take, however, reef encounter's cyclical produce/consume cycles just feels to me like it allows for more clever moves and a bit more strategic planning than your 2 actions in T&E
It might sound like I am bagging on T&E, but that is not the case.  Both this game and Reef Encounter provide (for me) a very abstracted yet thematic experience of waxing and waning.  Both games have interesting player controlled timers that allow players to control the tempo of the game.  What I like about T&E is the ability to control areas at two different levels (internal or external revolts) which allows its own interesting strategic planning.  It also allows players with different tile distributions to try to attack their enemies in two distinct ways.

Overall this is a very very good game, but if I had to choose one, I think I would take Reef Encounter over this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Could be thought of as a wargame.  very dynamic.  Lots of opportunity for clever moves.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There are a couple learning curves with this game. First is just getting the gyst of the rules. Then, there is learning how to identify and build positions of strength....both internally with temple support and externally with same-color followers. I find beginners too tied to having red tiles and not knowing what to do when they don't draw as many as they'd like.

There is a bit of luck to the tile draw, but I find that the more skillful player usually will win regardless of the tile distribution. The faster you are cycling through your tiles (and USING them, not exchanging them) the better your chances are of doing well. Your hand is your hidden information. You want to build disparities of colors to have surprising strength in a color, then attack or better, sucker someone else into attacking you. If you don't have a color you want, consume the other colors in conflict and draw a new hand that way. 

Tigris and Euphrates has a timeless feel to it which makes me think its really centuries old. In my opinion, this is Knizia's biggest masterpiece.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Another great Knizia design that seems to just make sense once you play it. I wish there was a way to minimize the red tile problem, but if you can live with it this game is imminently rewarding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Euphrat & Tigris is Knizia's tile laying magnum opus.

Players each control a faction with leaders in 4 colours, corresponding to the 4 tile types. On their turn, they place leaders onto the board, place tiles from their hand of 6, and can also ditch tiles from their hand and redraw if there is something particular they need. Each time a tile is placed on the board, a victory point cube in that colour is given to the player who has that coloured leader present in that cluster of orthogonally adjacent tiles (which are called a "kingdom" in game lingo).

Everything is fine and dandy until two leaders of the same colour end up in the same kingdom. This can lead to a revolution (if the conflict was caused by a leader piece being placed into a kingdom that already had a leader of that colour present) or to a war (if the conflict was caused by placing a tile that joined two kingdoms with leaders of the same colour present). Revolutions are simple: the two leaders count up the number of red tiles they are orthogonally adjacent to, and can also throw extra red tiles from their supply of 6. Loser removes his leader, winner gets a red VP cube (regardless of the colour of the leader removed). Wars are much more complex and are where the game is generally won and lost. Wars involve checking the number of tiles present in the entire kingdom that match the leader's colour (i.e.: conflict between two blue leaders, one has 2 blue tiles in his kingdom, the other has 4) and then throwing tiles of that colour in support. Loser has to pick up his leader and all of the tiles of that colour from his kingdom. Winner scores VPs in that colour equal to the sum of the tiles +1. Wars can lead to multiple conflicts depending on how they play out, which can create avalanches of point scoring.

The other way points can be scored efficiently is by building monuments. When 4 tiles are placed in a square, the player placing the 4th tile can opt to flip them over and place a monument on top. There are monuments in each two colour combination, and the one placed on the tiles has to have the colour of those tiles present as one of its colours. Monuments sit on the board permanently from there on out, and if you have a leader connected to it at the end of your turn, you score a VP cube of that colour. This is very efficient, and as a result, monuments are generally fought over viciously once they are constructed.

The end game scoring is based on having sets of the 4 coloured cubes, a Knizia staple. Hence, balance is required to win.

Euphrat is justifiably known as a classic in the Knizia catalogue at this point. It's a deceptively simple game rules-wise, but has a lot of subtlety in the board play, particularly in setting up for advantageous wars, which is where the game is usually won and lost. This is a game that tends to create apathy for the first play or so, but it seems to gain a shine as players gain more familiarity with it and as the nuances of play open up more. I wish Knizia still designed games like this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Despite its age, still a great game

RATING: 9
Knizia's masterpiece.  This is truly one of the "great" games, even if it is at first somewhat less accessible than something like Settlers.  Excellent, hardcore strategy that just gets better and deeper every time you play it, unlike most Euros that have a play threshold of about three times.  Everything about this game has a classical feel, which makes it a touch academic and maybe a bit cold, but it's a great game with tension, conflict, and tough decisions that are completely at odds with what most Eurogamers hold dear.

RATING: 8
Build an empire starting from scratch, and when it falls, invade someone elses. This game is amazing! So much to do on your turn, but not enough actions to do it all. It is all about prioritizing, while finding your enemies weakness, and exploiting them. Trust me, they will have them, and so will you. It is a constant struggle to keep everything balanced. And just when you think you are taking the lead, you remember, It isnt the person with the highest score that wins, it is the person whose lowest score is not the lowest! Give the game a try. My only complaint is that the tile picking bag is a little bit see-through.

Edit 12/14/07: It just dropped a little. Still a great game, it's just not as shiny.

RATING: 9
Probably Reiner Knizia's best game.  Three or more players is recommended.  Almost an abstract stragegy game, since the civilization theme is really just barely pasted on.  Feels a bit like a wargame at times since in order to win it is necessary to "attack" other players.  This game is not as difficult to learn as it would appear to be.  The gameplay contains Knizia's typical extreme depth within simplicity of mechanics(not as simple as Samurai) and perfect balance between randomness and strategy (not as random as Battleline).  It is easy to get truly engrossed in this game while playing and the hidden point mechanic keeps things very exciting right up to the end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Probably the only true classic ever produced by that one guy. Number of plays is low.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Eufraat & Tigris (that's the Dutch title for this game) is Reiner Knizia's undisputed masterpiece. Reiner made other fine games: Through the Desert, Ra, Amun Re, Taj Maha, to name a few. But none can hold a candle to this title. There are several reasons for this; I'll handle the technical ones first. First of all is that the rules of this games are simple and straightforward. Some complain about the opacity of the two types of conflict, and I agree that the game can be a bit rough until you get these nailed down pat. But they honestly aren't difficult: as usual with these things it takes more effort to write it down than it is to actually do. Second: no gamey rules. Everything is there for a reason. Nothing can be taken out, nothing needs to be added. Third: despite a random influx of tiles, there is plenty of opportunity to play around the luck of the draw. Randomness in this game is used as a means to introduce variety, not as an equaliser of different player levels. Fourth and final reason: the game scales well, whether you play with two, three, or four players. To get all these aspects right is [i]hard[/i] to begin with. But there are a few more things...

For players, the ruleset means that they need to get creative on their own. For me that is a hallmark of a good game. There is nothing resembling a feedback mechanism in E&T: everything that happens on the board is a result of what the players plan and act on. You cannot play this game automatically. Secondly, the game knows about emergent patterns. E&T isn't about randomly placing tiles and hoping for the best: no, the game settles into a certain pattern of growth and destruction of kingdoms which you need to know very well in order to exploit it to the full. It even allows you to get back from a tough position because at some point the attention of your opponents will shift to other places on the board: if someone is gouging themselves full on, say, red cubes, he is not very interested to put up a fight to hold on to a red temple. Good players will remember what a player collects and exploit that knowledge.

All in all, what remains is a wonderful title to learn, explore, and play. There is an addictive balance between strategic and tactical notions, and the various subgames occuring on the board result in a tremendous amount of variety. This is an exceedingly solid title which never fails to disappoint. And what makes it more exceptional is the fact that the game appeared in 1997. If you take into account the onslaught the game has had from the new gaming kids on the block, [i]and[/i] that it still remains in upper regions of this site without ever having left it... That is impressive.

[b]TIP[/b] Having trouble explaining or understanding the scoring rules? Try the following. The purpose of this game is to collect [i]sets[/i] of cubes, with a set being 1 red, 1 blue, 1 green and 1 black cube. The player who has the highest amount of sets at the end of the game wins. Is there a tie? Remove the most limiting colour and compare again.

[b]Update[/b] With BGG retiring its own edition of the game, and with gamers nowadays spoilt for so much choice that a game must deliver on the first go [i]or else![/i], the title is finally on its way down the ranks. I wish it would have been otherwise as I still think the game is simply a damned good [i]game[/i]... but unfortunately gamers have changed since the days it was published. I'm keeping my own copy, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Much less elegant than TtD or Samurai, but the somewhat intricate rules are part of the charm.  It feels like some incomprehensibly esoteric game that would be played by aliens in a seedy science fiction bar.  And yet, like Cribbage, the complexity belies what is at heart a fairly simple game.  

The only thing I don't particularly like are the endgame conditions, or more specifically, having a game end due to running out of tiles.  It would feel very anticlimactic to have a game where two or more massive kingdoms slowly build up and amass power, only to have the game end before the seemingly inevitable cataclysmic battle.  Seems that adding 25ish more tiles would "solve" this gripe, though I suppose the sweeping changes in fortune that would result from forcing such a clash would undermine the slow and methodical play that is at the heart of the game.  The massive wars are always an option for those who choose that route.

*59,000 11/3/18 interhobby card 50,000
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of my favorite older strategy games. Balances decisive tile placement against player conflict very well. Victory point system is brilliantly and elegantly designed, rewarding players who best balance each of the four key areas of development within their civilization. The scope of the game is very focused with not a great deal of complexity, but a great amount of strategic planning, pitting each player's perceptiveness and daring directly against one another, making every more significant and tense. The downside is the randomness of the cards drawn, which have a sizable impact on the game, which can be frustrating when stalling a well-crafted and timed plan. All in all a great and satisfying game, but you have to enjoy direct competition and conflict, as it is a game of mutually exclusive manipulation - although  the internal/external conflict mechanics do an excellent job of creating a back door for players who have become dispossessed of their kingdoms to re-enter the game, and make for an enjoyable and precarious conflict procedure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Well, a game I rated as medium heavy. A good gateway game into heavier games I would think. Took me many readings of the rules, man, they need a rework, with lots of videos, some cheat cheats, finally get it. It really isn't that hard, but, there is a learning curve. Not a game to whip out for a family game experience or for new players just to be included. Best think I can compare it to is learning how to play chess. Don't get me wrong, this is an excellent game to invest into learning. It will take you 3 or 4 games and then the elegants of the game comes through. I am not a heavy gamer, but, this game is just enjoyable. It is best to muck you way through it with one experience player over a few games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Good strategy game with lots of player interaction, the theme is an interesting one even though it's a euro which means its almost non-existent but this game can get really cutthrought. It's fun that you can merge kingdoms and create external conflicts(or war if you prefer) even if you are not part of the kingdoms yourself and just see a way to weaken your enemies. The monuments are really good and bring a lot of points to the table so there will be constant conflict for supremacy in kingdoms that have 1 or more monuments.

The fact that you have to be good in all 4 areas of the game(religion, farming, trading and kingdoms) and not just focus on 1-2 of them, makes the game even better as it forces the players to think more and interact more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the best 'German' game of all time, mile better than 'Puerto Rico' for a start!  T+E is fantastic in that there is always something a player can do to improve their situation regardless of the tiles in hand or the situation on the board.  Thus the element of luck in the game (the drawing of tiles) is balanced by the relative freedom to put those tiles to several different uses.  The game can be played in several different ways, one can fight for control of temples, develop one's own kingdom, attack the kingdoms of other players in external in internal combat.

The best thing about T+E is that one can't write a FAQ or a 'how to play' sheet that covers most game situations.  The game is so fluid that one must think on one's feet all the time, waiting to exploit openings in an oppenents kingdom and being prepared to leave your own meticulously constructed kingdom behind once you already have enough cubes of a certain colour.  Brilliant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A GREAT GAME ONLY FOR GAMERS..

RATING: 5
Must be the most frustrating game i ever played.

You work for 8/9 turns trying a strategy only to have it fail miserably because your opponent drew one more tile of a specific color than you expected... and right there you lost the game, having needlesly to continue on the game since there's no way you can recover from it.

This scenario seems to occur in every game.

Easy rules, but way too deep for it's own good. Like chess in that you just KNOW you're going to lose against a more experienced player before you even start... Not fun.

RATING: 8.5
2-4 players, 90-120 minutes, medium heavy, tile laying, Knizia

Recently purchased this game and tried it out tonight with my son (7). We had fun and did not bother each other....yet. That is something for next game. 

All in all the game looks nice and has a nice theme, the best part is the condition to win: you need to collect stones of 4 different colours, but you need to balance this, as only the colour with the least number of stones counts. I want to play this again soon :)

Update: played several games with 2, 3 and 4 players and upgraded the rating, as this is indeed a very good game and i.m.o. one of Knizia's best, possibly the best one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
$20 BGG
Regarded by many as Reiner Knizia's masterpiece, Tigris & Euphrates is set in the ancient fertile crescent with players building civilizations through tile placement. Players are given four different leaders: farming, trading, religion, and government. The leaders are used to collect victory points in these same categories. However, your score at the end of the game is the number of points in your weakest category, which encourages players not to get overly specialized. Conflict arises when civilizations connect on the board, i.e., external conflicts, with only one leader of each type surviving such a conflict. Leaders can also be replaced within a civilization through internal conflicts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is Reiner Knizia's best game design, in my opinion. Building monuments and then battling over them to score is fun, but this is also combined with the need to score evenly in all resources (a scoring mechanism which was later used to good effect in one of Knizia's later games, Einfach Genial). Catastrophe tiles can be pretty devastating and all players are subject to the luck of the draw, but players can move their leaders around freely to reduce the impact of the tile drawing. There are a world of possibilities for strategic play and also varied tactics available to support that strategy. Yes, this game is as good as they say it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First game, loved it and I think I'll appreciate it even more after a couple of extra games.

--Update--
Opinion on the game has yet to change, though it definitely should be getting more playtime.

RATING: 8.5
Tigris & Euphrates is truly unlike any other game I've ever played.  Although the theme is so perfunctory that it's borderline abstract, it's also incredibly deep strategically, almost Chess-like.  I think I was having a hard time teaching it to people because I always felt as if I was shortchanging the myriad of different plays that you can make, especially where it concerns Internal and External Conflicts.

As I said to my opponents after our second play: "This is the sort of game that I really want to practice."  Frankly, I can't think of higher praise for a game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What I really like about this game is that even though it comes with a cool theme and design, you could cobble it together at a pinch with stones and coloured wooden squares. This relative simplicity means it should last a thousand years, like Chess, Go and Backgammon have. In this age of games with hundreds of different bits, resource costs and calculations, cards with fiddly bonuses and so on, it must be quite tricky to find a simple set of rules using a simple set of bits, yet still be able to create a game with the same mind-numbing analysis paralysis that this game often involves! I love it.

RATING: 6.5
 Got this for Christmas.  It is said to be Reiner Knizia's best game.  Well, compared to Relationship Tightrope, I'd have to agree.  Only one play so far, and that was only 2-player. I'm not even sure if we played it right, or not.  The rules are definitely counterintuitive, which means a lot of switching of mental gears.  Not an easy game to learn.  I'd really like to play with an experienced player, so I can learn it better. Then, I just might rate it higher.

OK, I got to play it a second time, and this time with a better understanding of the rules.  It's actually a pretty cool game.  Once again, It was only a 2-player game, so I'm still looking for a 4-player game to really get a handle on it, but I'm starting to like it more.
Unfortunately, my wife doesn't care for it, so I traded it away.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
This is an outstanding game.

Hard to plan, devilish and completely absorbing, which is probably the weakness which dilutes a little bit the social interaction... until there is an external conflict!

Hardcore players will simply devour it. Hard to convince light players to play/enjoy in a late boardgame night.

Playing it regularly is a challenge but also one of the way to make it accessible as the difficulty is to grasp the difference and become familiar with the power and intricacies between internal/external conflicts.

Games vary dramatically from one another.

Again, my alltime favourite.

RATING: 8.33
Family Rating Breakdown:

A.J.: 7
Zachary: 8
Isaac: 10

Design genius is obvious, but "inelegant" is almost an understatement. . . . It's another game that Isaac seems to win consistently. I think I'm beginning to see patterns here: of our frequently-played games that rely heavily on tactical decisionmaking (Yinsh, Coloretto, LotR-Confrontation), Isaac more than holds his own (he's pretty good at chess, too). Zachary and I are more in our element with games that emphasize strategical thinking, multidimensionality, or executive planning functions (Sleuth, Modern Art, PR, the classic space 4X4 tic-tac-toe game). We don't have any wargames, so maybe this will be our next purchase.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
When I first got on to Board Game Geek, this is the game I really drooled over, desired even. I read through all the reports on the game, looked at the strategy articles, and really absorbed what the game was about. It ended up being the first board game I ordered over the internet, because my FLGS, Coolstuff Inc., did not have a copy in stock. I even through myself into playing it here on BGG, despite the fact that I did (and still do) get trounced regularly. 

The game itself lived up to my anticipation for it, though I ended up having difficulty getting it on the table regularly. While others see a thin theme, I see the ebb and flow of civilization. Where others see the randomness of the tiles, I see the need to be flexible with what the game gives you. For a long, long time this was, in fact, my definite favorite game, but I have found myself requesting it less as time goes on in favor of other games like Agricola and Race For the Galaxy.

Unfortunately, the sheer quantity of times I have played it both face to face (the plays recorded here) and on-line have vastly dimmed my desire to play with inexperienced players. Not that I beat them all the time (I do not), but their lack of understanding of the strategy in the game usually increases the chaos to a degree that I find it less fun. I may lower its rating because of this, but I am not quite ready to yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
very competitive which puts off some people. Good mechanics but artwork is a bit dull.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a 2 to 4 player tile laying game, where players build up kingdoms of tiles on the board, and try to position their leaders to their best advantage. The game is won by taking cubes in four colours, but your score is the colour you have the least of. Ingenious mechanics and subtle deep game play. Simply wonderful. Buy it now. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Awesome game.  The rules are elegant, though sometimes complicated for new players, especially with respect to internal vs. external conflicts. I definitely recommend watching a rules explanation video or downloading one of the rules summaries available on this website. Takes some patience to learn and the willingness to play a few times before it clicks. Like the spatial aspect and a nice amount of randomness.

RATING: 10
Intense. Love playing in person and online. When I first joined this site, this game was in the top 5 and has subsequently fallen in the rankings. It's a shame - to win, you need a mix of strategy and tactics. Although people consider this an abstract, you definitely feel the narrative as kingdoms rise and fall. This style of game is just less popular than the opaque resource conversion games that are so popular these days. The depth in this one comes from your opponents.

RATING: 8.5
Of the Euro-Games, I think this is the best one (from an elegant design perspective).  It plays equally well with both 3 and 4 players which is rare since most 3 player games turn into a 2 on 1 situation or where 1 player winds up being kingmaker.  Sure it happens in this game, but just not as much as others.  I don't really care about theme, so the abstract nature of the game doesn't bother me.  Has slowly slipped in rating as new Euro's have come out. Some people say its a good 2 Player game, but unless you make the board smaller or something, its pretty lame 2 Player.

RATING: 8
Deserves the plaudits of being a classic. Playing it, you can't help but appreciate what Knizia is capable of as a games designer and understand why he is considered to be one of the giants of the industry.
    T&E offers up a challenging puzzle with a lot of player interaction. Interesting ways of scoring points and manipulating the landscape of the board make for a large variety of possible moves for you to think about. 
    It's quite hard to pull back the lead from someone who has gotten too far ahead but with experienced players it looks like the game will balance out nicely. Theres a bit of luck and suspense involved in the 'combat' when jostling for control of zones on the board because of the hidden information behind player screens. 
    It's really a uniquely interesting game which definitely deserves a spot in my collection. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Here is my first impression:
"Maybe it's just because I've only played this 2-player, but this game seems to be the complete opposite of the other Euro games I enjoy. I just don't find the mechanics to be clever or engaging. A good example of "more is less" for me."

On further investigation, this game floors me. I still agree that this isn't an "elegant" game in that it has a simple but profound mechanic like most designer games. It's just a whole different beast.  The planning and creativity required by this game makes my head 'splode with intensity; some of the moves are so Machiavellian and evil. I still haven't played with more than two players, as I suspect the "kingmaker" situation would cause me to get a little too emotionally "invested". Two player can have a bit of back-and-forth bickering with the internal conflicts, which I see as problematic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only just played this for the first time, and really really liked it.  I can see why its at the top of the rankings.  I suspect my rating will go up with future plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've played this classic a few times, but never really enjoyed it.  I don't really have a problem with the Knizia scoring, per se.  It works in this game, as well as several others.  The problem comes in the fact that the tile draws are random, and it takes half your turn to try and get better ones.  Their values shift over time depending on which cubes you've collected, but some are always better than others.  You can't get points at all unless you have leaders on the board, and you need red tiles to get/keep them there.  Blue tiles are essential for connecting civs across the rivers, but otherwise much worse than the others, since they can only be placed in specific spots.  Black, as I recall, also has a slight edge over green.
There's inevitably a time in each game I've played where I wind up with 6 blue tiles.  Well, you can use them to start a battle, win it handily, and get rid of all your tiles, then hope to draw something better.  That'll net you a bunch of blue points, but it doesn't really improve your situation.  If you're stuck trying to improve your worst color, you may not have any good options.  To score in that color, you need your leader on the board, but forget about placing him later on if you don't have reds.  Even if he's there, not having tiles of that color to place means you can't get anywhere.  Ingenious at least has the rule that you can get a free mulligan at the end of your turn if you don't have any of the color that's your lowest.  In this game, you're stuck spinning your wheels until you can draw something useful.
I've also never seen the monoliths do anything useful.  Producing a cube a turn seems powerful, but it may help the other players as much as it helps you; more if you can't defend it.  

Anyway, for such a well-regarded game, I've always found it a frustrating mess of unintuitive rules and random screwage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Very brief comment: My very first game, finally get to played this classic Knizia's game. I have to say that the internal and external conflict are interesting so to speak. A little abstract but it's fine with me.

The tile laying mechanics is pretty interesting as there are a lot to see. Every player each has four leaders they need to balance with as the final scoring is done by only taking the lowest score among the four leaders/colours.

RATING: 8.5
Great game that offers a lot of possibilities every turn and thus is very replayable with lots of variety.  Most games offer good interaction between players’ different kingdoms (unless players mostly just tend to their own holdings).  There is a luck factor in drawing tiles, which can be frustrating, but may keep the game from being too analytical; although it can become a conflicted game that appears to want a lot of analysis but undermines it with luck.  Could be too analytical for a multiplayer game (possibly best with 2 or 3 players...).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Euphrat & Tigris is the kind of game which is a real brain burner! Lot's to think about during the game.

Euphrat & Tigris has lots of different possibilities if you got the right tiles. Having the color tiles you need more or less at a given time can limit your choices during your turn.

Either you have the right tiles to save your a$$ at the right time or you see your oppenent run you over. You would want to do something specific, but you can't because you don't have the right colored tiles.

I have not played this game in the last couple of months due to it plays only up to four. It would be nice to get this game on the table again. We are often 5-7 players. Definately a game which is worth more plays, but Euphrat & Tigris is not for everybody. I used to play it a lot online a couple of years back.

I need to put this game out on the table soon at home. Played twice in one day at the Concordia group in July 2005 the last time.


9 plays since recording games played.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An interesting twist on the civilization genre. Instead of building out a tableau, players seed the Eyptian desert and witness the rise and fall of empires. Once the few rounds of peaceful growth pass, the game enters a state of constant flux, where monuments will be built, usurper will claim power, and civilizations will be fractured by war. Tactics rule, but medium-term strategies are necessary as well. The rapid escalation the game undergoes after a few monuments/buildings have been placed is incredible, and helps round out the scope of the game. Tigris and Euphrates taxes your brain in a unique way, and while not being very accessible, it is vastly rewarding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Almost completely abstract tile laying game. The only luck is the draw of the tiles. Always plenty of choices, and some deep player interaction/conflict.

RATING: 9
Really a fantastic game.  It does have its share of problems, in that it has rather picky rules (although they become second nature after a few plays), it is difficult for new players (in part because of the former problem, but only in part), and it is exceptionally confrontational and not for the thin-skinned.  The game can be very ruthless to players who've spent a lot of time developing a kingdom, since points, not kingdoms, are what the game is about and kingdoms, much like in ancient Sumer, come and go.  It's brilliant in that respect, but if players don't get it, it can be an awfully hard go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[2 plays]  Wow.  A classic that I've wanted to play for ages, and just finally got around to it.  So far I really like it.  Yeah, there's a luck element in the tile draw; the second time I played both I and another player did not draw a single blue tile for about the first two-thirds of the game.  Maybe I'd have been annoyed if I were more experienced and competitive at the game, and not still approaching it in the spirit of "How fun it is to learn this nifty game!"  But it wasn't that annoying--maybe because the bad luck was ongoing and could change at any time.  

I think that's less annoying than either a game where you get bad luck at the beginning and then are stuck in a losing position the whole rest of the time, or a game where you build stuff up thinking it's going well, and then some kind of bad luck ruins it.  With something like dice rolls or tile draws, it could get better at any time.  If it doesn't, you may look back on the game and denounce the streak of ill fortune that held you down, but it's not like a single crushing stroke.  

Anyway, this is a clever game with a nice mix of stuff going on.  I think the theme actually fits it well.  Unlike Vinci, which disappointed me because I expected a civilizationy feel and didn't get one, in Tigris and Euphrates the theme of rising, falling, and struggling civilizations seems to fit the dynamics.  The interrelationships have enough density to make it interesting and challenging, but not so much that it seems futile (the way I felt about Dominant Species).  

I am looking forward to playing this some more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Having tried this once, I enjoyed it immensely.  It's not overly brainburning, although I'm not sure about my wife getting AP, and her thoughts about the amount of confrontation it has.  I have Mayfair's revised edition (2008) which includes an expansion map on the reverse side of the board.
See my pictorial guide to the new edition here: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/376984

Teaching video [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/628367/introducing-our-first-how-to-play-video-htpv-tigri]here[/url].  Suggestion: call internal conflict `revolution' (or `coup') and external conflict `war'; see also [thread=1107315][/thread].

Easier way to describe win condition: player who has collected the most sets of cubes (with a set consisting of one cube in each of the four colours).

Strategy tip from Martin G

[q][b]Misconception:[/b] the player who draws most red tiles wins

[b]Reality:[/b] inexperienced players just haven't figured out the many ways of getting what you want that this game gives you beyond internal conflicts. If you're not drawing red, you must be strong in other colours. Use those tiles to win external conflicts. Or use catastrophes cleverly. Or build monuments. Or...

And even more importantly, if you're not drawing enough red, you're probably not drawing enough tiles total. The ABC of T&E is Always Be Cycling. Don't just play one or two tiles each turn; look for opportunities to spend several in an external conflict (even if you lose). The more you draw, the less likely you are to be weak in a colour.[/q]

Mayfair 2nd edition I own includes: [gameid=43490]

This one, however, is a Knizia game that I appreciate (if not play) very well. It's a brilliant design. The conflict effects are so intricate, however, that the game is fragile and chaotic if not played by experienced players. Once you get to that point with your group, the game shines.

RATING: 4
First you have to deal with three or four games filled with confusion as you try to 'get' the rules, then you spend three or four games getting your butt handed to you by your brother because you wasted the whole game fighting to own a stupid temple on the east side (even though your brother owns 3 temples on the west side.) Then you realize that you've got to start thinking before playing. It's at this stage that I decided to pull out the Xbox.

But, seriously, this is a decent game as long as you're not a dunderhead. If you are a dunderhead...Xbox!

Update: After a dozen more sessions, I'm still waiting for this to be fun. Sure, there are inovative scoring systems at play. But so what?

Even more Update: Sold it.

RATING: 9
Based on 13 plays.
+ One of the best Eurogames there is
+ Nice combination of an abstract game and an "historical simulation" or some sort.
+ Rather good pace for such a brain-burner
+ Good graphical design with players as symbols and colors as point types.
> I haven't played with advanced setting (Ziggurat) yet. There's enough in the base game to understand for now.
> The cubes are trackable, so should the players' cubes be open information? Personally I want to keep them hidden and force players not to take written notes.
- I'd like to grant points also for tiles that connect two kingdoms if no conflicts arise. It just feels more intuitive. And why shouldn't I be able to connect two kingdoms with a leader if no conflicts arise?
- Agonizing over bad tiles is rather common. Yes, I know: discarding and drawing is the solution.

Since 2009, updated Dec 2011.

Haven't played this forever, but the iOS version has reminded me why I love it so much. I [u]really[/u] need to get this one out again.

RATING: 7.45
Listed 7/7/08

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze&gameid=42]Ratings[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ignore those who think the game is dry and abstract - they have no idea what they are talking about. Unlike modern Euros, this game is confrontational, destructive and swingy. To quote my friend Orntt, "the best part is that you are rewarded for screwing other people over!"

The game is well-themed at a higher level; Knizia eschews the common mechanics used to represent civilisations (units, cities and dice) and creates an innovative product. Each leader has slightly different special powers, and each colour a slightly different role.

The positional aspects of kingdom separation, "good shape", and the vulnerability of monuments are interesting, and I really love the separation of players and kingdoms that allows very devious tactics via revolutions and wars. I've found the midgame disappointing because of the chaos and wild swings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Boîte plastifiée.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Although it's abstracted and simple in many ways, it gives a very tense multiplayer wargame feel for me.  It's a neat birds eye view of spreading and merging nations.  It took a couple of plays to get my head around it.  If you can handle some conflict and are able to learn a few abstract rules, give it a try.  A game I like but am not good at.  Tense with just the right amount of randomness.

Note:  I've been playing this more and I really do like it.  The game isn't really as hard as I thought it was (or as heavy).  The trick is 'seeing' the board and understanding the possibilities for your turn.  T&E is one of those games where you always seem to see a great move after you've finished your turn!   It  just takes a several plays to get past the abstractions and you have to keep with it.  Most importantly you have to pay attention to the scoring and keep a cube color balance.  If you get caught up in doing stuff on the map and lose track of your color balance you won't do well.  The scoring system is the game.

Looking forward to more plays!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[Tile Placement/Civilization Building/Wargame] {2P:9, 3P:9, 4P:10} Superb game, and one that seems to have unlimited replayability. The extremely strong theme of the rise and fall of civilizations, and the greed of men (especially the greed of men) fits extremely well into the game; it's not surprising that the game was developed after the story was written. Multiple roads to victory, deep strategy and tactics, angst-filled turns and a delicious victory condition to make this practically an obligatory addition for any collection of German games. I like E&T best with four players due to the tightness of the board and the scarcity of real estate, but it also plays excellently with two or three players. *** UPDATE: Reaffirming my 10, one year after I first played the game. E&T is the real deal. The depth continues to astound, and what I initially believed to be irritating randomess in the tile draw has become the lynchpin of this masterpiece. There is still nothing like it. *** UPDATE: Well, I've been focusing a lot on E&T as of late, and with more familiarity comes plumbing the depths and reflection on the findings. E&T is a great game because it is different from many of its bretheren. After over 100 games, I know I'm still going to be playing this game years from now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A 2 hour game that has smart mechanics and clever scoring system.
This game is about taking up opportunities in the short and medium term, which can be very challenging to our brain. However, long term strategies are very difficult to sustain, as no position is permanently secure.
The game promotes individual logic deduction rather than player interaction. This is the first thing I dislike in it.
For my gaming taste, the weakest point of the game is the level of abstractness. I love when a game gives me a sense of reality. With T&E this doesn’t happen at all.
Despite the negative factors (for me), the intelligent game mechanics make me enjoy the game.

RATING: 8

I've only ever played with two players and apparently it's better with more but I love the way the game builds up and then all hell breaks loose as you keep finding ways in to each others civilizations to score more points. And the scoring itself is really well done, ensuring that you can always focus on your opponents weak points to try and best them.

A really good game with the right people.

RATING: 10
I love analyzing the colorful geometries that rise and fall across the board, and I think the scoring and combat mechanisms in this game are well balanced. Despite the fact that I am awful at this game, I am a T&E fan.

A while back, I really appreciated the online T&E provided here; it really was a great version of the game and I truly appreciated being able to use it freely. Despite this, I did have some ideas to make it better. Many games lasted a few weeks, and it was therefore quite difficult to get a feel for the game with such long breaks between turns. And we all know how cumbersome reading the game log was. I had a mission to learn the appropriate code languages so that I could code up a program capable of solving that problem of "reading" the game log and presenting it in a visual format, just as it was played, but I gave up on that.

Again, how much do I owe Knizia? GENIUS!!!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Reiner Knizia főműve. :)
Régóta érdekelt játék, most végre sikerült kipróbálni. Vegyes érzelmeket váltott ki belőlem. 
A vesszőparipám: a tematika. Érdekes módon Kniziához hűen nincs sok tematika a játékban, de valahogy itt ez mégse zavart. Valahogy menet közben összeáll az egész élmény, és valamiért most nem igényeltem, hogy legyen válasz minden mechanizmus vs témával kapcsolatos kérdésre. Szóval ez itt egy jó pont :)
A mechanizmus: viszonylag egyszerű szabályokkal, nagyon sok kombinációt és lehetőséget kínál. Ez nagyon jó. Nem mondom, hogy első játék után átláttam a lényeget. Egy-két taktikai megérzésem lett, de biztos tartogat még meglepetéseket a játék. Talán kicsit úgy éreztem, hogy a végjátékban a piros lapoknak a súlya aránytalanul megnő, ami a szerencse szerepét növelheti. De ezt azért még nem merem biztosan kijelenteni. :)
És végül egy-két negatívum is:
A tábla és az alkatrészek valahogy nem annyira tetszettek (pegasus).
Érzésem szerint ez a játék nekem túl absztrakt, sakkszerű lesz, de ehhez azért még jópárat jétszani vele, hogy biztosan kiderüljön. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Is it a civilization game? Is it an abstract? Probably a little bit of both. The rise and subsequent fall of the various kingdoms certainly shines through but tile placement, scoring rules, and also the occasionally large swings in fortune move the game closer to the abstract side.

In any case, T&E is an aggressive game, with lots of direct conflict. It also seems to me like it starts out in a precarious balance that is easily broken by players just floundering about. A large part of that is because the game just is a nail-biter. Every move counts, and a wrong move counts double. Therefore I strongly expect the game to be much better with an experienced group of players. And yet, even though it's usually close and I think I appreciate what the game tries to do for some reason it's not really engaging.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
{"sleeves":[]}
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game. 

The setting: ancient middle east, on the shores of the Tigris & Euphrates. Objective: build a civilisation which will flourish througout the years.

The options within this game are almost limitless. You can start your own civilisation, join the ones build be your competitors or even take over there civilisations.

Each aspect of your civilisation deserves your attention because the aspect which earns the least points at the end of the game will determine who wins.

Great feature within this game is the possibility the start internal and external conflict. With both you'll need do some math before you decide to start a conflict. And even when you've done the math, you'll still need a bit of luck.

Disadvantage of the game? The only one I can discovere is the two-player-mode. This game is best played with three or four players. If you play it with two players te board is to big.

Why don't I own this game anymore? Simply because I don't get to play it very often. The people I play with don't like it. So I'll just have to purchase the I-pad version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A modern classic. Very cut throat but rewarding in the end.

RATING: 5.5
2016
====

T&E is an odd game to me. I've loved it and hated it. I've played by the rules and played by strong house rules. However, for every bad experience I've had with the game, I've had twice as many great experiences, so that's something right? At the moment I have warm feelings about the game. Talk to me again in a month.  

[2014.12.01] - 8.25
I've found this to provoke aggressiveness in tactics and may even surpass Chess WRT head-to-head play.  Aside from being a beautiful game visually, the game unfolds after a few plays and continues to do so as I play more and more.  Against very good players this game is an exercise in humility.

[2015.08.20]
Almost a year later I have pulled away from this game.  Played by the rules it's entirely too random.  Played open scoring and open-handed is a better game IMO, but it loses most of its aggression.  It's basically a different game -- one that no one is likely to play with me.

RATING: 9
Fantastic tile-laying civilization building game with lots of player interaction.  Subverts a lot of standard game concepts such as "my kingdom", "I'm red" and the scoring system.  All of these makes you think differently about what is actually happening within the game.

RATING: 8
Very open-ended and deep brainburner with choices galore. Maybe a bit more luck of the draw than I'd expect from such a serious and well balanced game, but manageable risk all the same. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love everything about Tigris & Euphrates. I call it a thematic abstract game because it plays like an abstract but the mechanics actually do fit the theme very well. I love how the scoring always challenges you to balance your points. The push and pull of building large kingdoms only to be destroyed in external conflicts, and then stealing positions in established kingdoms to make up points is very satisfying and creates great player interaction. Some might say that the randomness of the tiles is problematic, but I think it helps to motivate players to cultivate the adaptive and creative strategies needed to win control over kingdoms and monuments. I like what Knizia says about the randomness: a seasoned player can adapt their strategy to the tile randomness and will most likely win every time against a new player, but the games will be close enough that the loser always enjoys playing the game. While the game is deep, it is very easy to teach and scales wonderfully from 2 to 4 players. I love every aspect of this game and consider it my favorite board game of all time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An amazing game, with about as many layers as pieces.  Its visually appealling.  Intellectually challenging.  Immensely engaging.

My 2nd 10 on BGG. Damn! I really love it. Full of choices. The luck factor isn't really important. You can always find a way to gain VP's in the colour you need. Great, great, great!

Love it! Love it! Love it!

RATING: 8
A classic. Some very interesting mechanisms pertaining to confrontation in this brain burning, head-scratcher, which is in fact, more of a chess-like experience to some degree. Easy to see why this is a classic. But it can be a bone dry strategy game experience, since the theme does not come through much (or is even necessary). The only poor luck issue, as many mentioned, is that the player who draws more red tiles will have a better chance at winning (especially over someone drawing many blue tiles).

Update: Really like the 2015 version- the tiles are more aesthetic and I don't mind the plastic pieces (although the wood was fine).

RATING: 8
Reiner Knizia. "Emergent"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b][i]Tigris & Euphrates[/i][/b] is an area control game that illustrates why Reiner Knizia is known as a great designer. The game is mechanically simple, but with such involved strategy as to guarantee it a place in the pantheon of great games. Many (including myself) enjoy T&E for the strategical play.

An unexpected reason why I enjoy this game is that, somehow, it feels thematic. Everyone is building civilizations and your leaders are competing for the influence of the people. I wouldn't recommend it for its theme, but don't be surprised if you end up role-playing your characters.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I like this game a fair bit.  I tend to be a fan of RK's games.  Not cult like fan, but a fan.  This game takes a few tries with some good players to really get a good grasp on it.  The BBG average was 8.3 when I wrote this.  I do not feel this is a top 5 game, maybe not even top 10.  Close for me, but not all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really like the connection between theme and gameplay; it's quite abstract, yet the rules create a strong metaphor for the rise and fall of ancient civilizations.

E&T really seems to scratch some deep mental itch for me. I like how the board changes dramatically over time, forcing you to constantly adapt your gameplan. I find the thought process behind formation of short-term strategies to be immensely satisfying.

Best with 3, good with 2, becomes a bit too chaotic with 4.

The latest revision comes with an "advanced game" variant, which provides one "civilization building" in each color.  The presence of such a building doubles the tile placement points in that color within a kingdom.  I played this variant once, and was thoroughly unimpressed.  The additional scoring method adds some "bookkeeping complexity" without actually making the game any more interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'd play this more if I could only play it with two.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2-player rating. This is hardcore. A vicious, exhausting, bare-knuckled turf fight that never lets up. Wrapping one's mind around the principles of conflict takes a game or two, and the administrative tallying of the monuments in FTF games can be distracting and easily overlooked when consumed with battle plans.

Update: Mere hours later and just one more game, my reluctance crumbles. A solid, splendid 9, my first yet. An inspired thing of genius, this game.

Update: Almost as excellent with 4, though the games demand players of equal skill to keep everyone in check and balance.

Must be played with open scoring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
This is a tough one for me.  My friends love it and they can't wait to play it.  For some reason for me, I have a really hard time 'seeing' what is going on in this game.  The board and where you are can change so dynamically that you just can't be attached to anything you have built.  Also, I think you really need to be aggressive into breaking into what others have built.  I like many of the concepts of the game, and I will play it, but for me this just isn't my style of game.  Maybe my opinion will improve with repeated plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Tigris and Eufrates[/b] [i]Reiner Knizia 1999[/i]
This is an abstract game and I dont like abstract game at all. So the first time I played I was pretty cold towards it. But after two or three games I was really really impressed. It is an almost perfect game of with a lot of thinking and some dosis of luck in the tiles drawing. It has some drawbacks, as the analisis paralyisis with some players or the fact that, due to the abstract rules, is sometimes difficult for the newcomers, but anyway this game is really wonderful. Some players just dont get it. It is a little bit more complex than the average eurogame, not because of its rules (the instructions booklet is very good) but because of the game´s nature and the scoring system that Knizia uses in it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Good with two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
There are so many great ideas in this game. The point system is brilliant, the battles are always tense and interesting, it has smartly designed built-in catch-up mechanisms and the way it forces you to fight and outwit your opponents is wonderful.

There are things I don't like though. The worst problem is that one bad player or play can very easily decide the game. I don't want to be elitist, but the game breaks down unless everyone is at the same skill level. There's also a lot of fiddly upkeep and things easily forgotten, like everyone having to draw from the same bag after everyone's turn. You can also be screwed by bad, random draws which is annoying given the otherwise abstract feel of the game. The player order is also a bit too important for my liking. I think the game would be less random and less fiddly if everyone had their own equally (or perhaps not depending on the player order) distributed bags of tiles, but who am I to question the great Dr. Knizia?

I can definitely see why people love it and if I had a group dedicated to learning this game properly I'm sure we'd have a lot of fun. As it is now I think it's a good game, but not great.

RATING: 10
Wonderful game with great depth.  Endless replayability.  One of the all-time greats.  I've played 20 games on BGG and haven't won one game yet...but the more I play this game the more I like it.   Even if I'm not very good at it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
Bought June 2015.

This game is a masterpiece. In no other game I have played is there the potential to be almost completely wiped out from the board halfway through the game, and yet still have every chance of fighting your way back and ekeing a win.

The board is always the same, but each game feels different - in one game there'll be loads of monuments right from the start, in another hardly any; in one game the fighting will start early and small, the next game will build up to a couple of huge battles at the end, and the next will hardly have any battles at all.

There's a joyful element of brinksmanship as you build your individual kingdoms, waiting for the optimum time to strike. Risk-taking, creative thinking and clever sacrifices are often rewarded. You can be left in tatters at the end but still win, or if you're not careful you can seem all-powerful yet be pipped to the post.

If you're looking for a game that's highly interactive and dynamic, this is the best.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Owning new Fantasy Flight Games edition. Excellent game, excellent components and aesthetics, excellent theme. Game is tense in every phase - from early game to last move. Even when it is close to end, you can still collect points by making huge war. Everyone is very involved in game from it's first till last minute. There is much conflict in game, this is almost a war game. Peaceful development is possible, but your kingdom will be attacked very soon as players try to get most points and valuable kingdoms. Revolts and wars are very common in this game, so be aware about that in your gaming group. There is luck in tile drawing from bag, but just enough to keep the game balanced and forces players to consider risk in every move carefully. To do well in game, clever strategical moves are essential as well using good opportunities to build defense or prepare for attack.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Even after many, many games, I haven't quite decided whether this is a game with a little bit of luck or a game with a lot of luck. Ultimately, I really don't care because it's so unbelievably fascinating and enjoyable to play, and because the scope for richly-textured strategic and tactical play is astounding.

Knizia sometimes gets accused of using slapped-on themes, and this game is one that is often mentioned in that argument. Which baffles me. The feel of this game matches its theme almost perfectly. Ancient Mesopotamia and the Fertile Crescent was a place of constant upheaval and quickly-changing politics, with an endless stream of leaders and civilizations battling for supremacy. Playing Euphrat & Tigris really puts me in that thematic mindset of scheming and adaptation and opportunistic takeovers. I love the way that the game forces you to constantly rethink your strategy as the landscape and power structure evolves. You may be living large off the fat of the land, but eventually you'll probably have to uproot and reinvent yourself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

If you will be playing this more than once a year, I'd say buy it. If not, its a bit painful when you finally dust it off and try it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Finally got a chance to play T&E...very underwhelming. I have to admit, I am a little surprised to see it ranked so highly. A game where so much relies on which tiles you have in your hand at any given time (i.e. whenever someone decides to attack you). Seems so chaotic. Having a conflict and holding no red tiles is one of the most excruciating boardgame experiences out there. Only topped by being beaten in a conflict by an opponent holding 4+ red tiles followed by watching another opponent win a conflict with 2. That this happened in my first game knocks several points off my rating.

(Maybe unfair to rank such a highly regarded game this low after one play, but this is how I feel about playing it and I doubt I will play it again.)

RATING: 8
Seventeen plays face-to-face, lots more online. 

A brilliant design. It's a fairly deep game, but the key to enjoying it, I've found, is to take it seriously but not *too* seriously. There is a lot of strategy that can be applied, but in the final end there is a certain amount of luck involved as well. I like the game best with three players; with four it can be a bit more chaotic as kingdoms collide because of lack of space, and there's not much point to building monuments since they tend to change hands rather quickly.

RATING: 7
4-player only.

Alterations:
1. No screens
2. Determine turn order
3. Players choose their six tiles to start.
4. Empty the draw bag and arrange all of the remaining tiles on the table so that everyone knows the order in which they will be peeled up.
5. Follow the resupply rules exactly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a hard one for me to accurately rate. On the one hand, the mechanisms are near-brilliant. It's very challenging (and rewarding) to figure out how to equalize the colours of your victory points given an uneven tile draw. On this basis, Tigris deserves the rating of 9 that I've given it.

On the other hand, the game is *very* luck-driven, mostly due to the volatile nature of the conflicts. A very small difference in position (your opponent has three green tiles instead of just two, say) can result in massive swings of fortune.

While overcoming poor tile draws is interesting and challenging, the winner is usually the player who doesn't need to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my all-time favorite game. It has an unusual combination of long term planning that must also be completely flexible. I had an unusual winning streak going for a while that netted me some deserved negative feelings, but I've lost now so you can stop making fun of me. *UPDATE* Clearly, this game has passed me by. After not having played it for over a year, I managed to finish dead last in the BGG.Con E&T Tournament. Any skills I may have once had have clearly flown out the window.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When you're reading the rules to this, it sounds like it is a game of "holding your own empire" but all that changes when you realize other people might be pulling ahead of you just from the tiles they are getting.  This forces people to "invade" and things can get messy.  WARNING: Can lead to swearing and frustration when "your" stronghold quickly changes hands and forces you into conquest of your own!  Not just a simple tile laying game any more, is it...?  

I really like the point system of having your worst resource being your actual point total.  This keeps things honest and doesn't cater to someone who is just getting a whole lot of one color.  

Fun stuff!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Been playing this online at game table online and other places.  I own a copy but haven't played F2F yet.  This is a truly fantastic game, well deserving of all the praise here on BGG.  Its very deep and the strategy feels like an abstract, but the theme is surprisingly strong for a knizia.  The conflicts are a lot of fun, there is enough randomness to keep it interesting, and there is tension throughout the whole game.  It is a bit of a brain burner, so you have to play with people that don't get bogged down.  The more I play it the more I appreciate it.  

UPDATE:  now played face to face 6 times or so, and this is one of the most deep and engaging eurogames out there.  This game is crazy, chesslike, and insanely addictive.  If there could be only one...  this would be the top euro.  Beautiful game.

Update II:  tempted to rate this a 10.  Still an absolute blast!  Super deep, strategic, and interesting.  Games like this are the reason euros are popular, the massive amounts of VP-scoring shovelware shit out there can look up to this masterpiece.

I'm half tempted to get the new edition for the variants!

Edit:  Six years after the first rating....  played this again the other night, and you know what?  This game is still really awesome.
