=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Moja ulubiona gra :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tigris & Euphrates is a thrilling mix of gambling and strategy that pushes you to constantly adapt and improvise. Games build up and explode, and the challenge is to try to time the fuse just right to orchestrate the right mix of catalysts and capitalize maximally on the shards and pieces. It's is a game of conquest and usurpation, of building and trapping. 

The only problem with T&E is that it is over too damn quickly (~1 hour). It would be perfect if the game was 2 or 2.5 hours long. But at 1 hour or so the game's extreme intensity burns too quickly.

Earlier comment, which still holds true for me: 
While I am generally enthusiastic about games, I am a bit freaked out by just how much I enjoy this game. I think what is hooking me is the dramatic and slightly chaotic vibe that starts around the last 4-5 rounds in the game when all the kingdoms clash and the board changes in significant ways. The game builds and crescendos and it is packed with drama. I really can't believe that anyone would seriously call this game dry and mechanical. 

A great summation by BGG user [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/3299475#3299475]Jambo[/url]: "T&E is a game of opportunism and short-term strategies. As an analogy, I'd say playing this is like a cobra about to strike - you have to wait for the right moment and when you do strike, strike hard making sure that your opponent is sufficiently crippled that they can't retaliate. Easier said than done."

SUGGESTION FOR NEW PLAYERS: While I don't normally like reading strategy articles, I'd actually recommend doing so with this game before you play your first game. The investment of time in advance will allow you to have quite a bit of fun with your very first game. Don't worry, there'll still be much to learn afterwards too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hans im Glück and Pegasus edition

RATING: 4

In fairness, we only played 3 games of it, but my wife absolutely hated it, and while my son and I did not share her exact feelings, we did not really enjoy it at all either.

It is a tile placing game (think Carcassonne), but I would much rather play Carcassonne than this game.  So, while 3 plays might not be entirely fair, none of us are interested enough to play more of this one.  There are simply many other games that are more interesting.

RATING: 10
[Initial Impression:10]
I was hooked immediately, and this remains my favorite game - I love the variety of decisions, the tension of feeling like you can never get enough done in a turn, and watching the game board evolve over time.  Each player's turn can have small or tremendous consequences, depending on the situation, and trying to forsee those consequences provides enormous strategic depth. Games always seem to come down to the wire, and the game is fluid enough that even when one or more players believe they're out of it early on, they can remain in contention.

RATING: 9
Well this game often called as Reiner Kinizia's masterpiece. This statement can be true as the game has very easy rules but with great depth wrapped around it. It is highly tactical with a lot of confrontation going everywhere on the board as fighting for the monuments for more points are essential to win. The twist is that vainly you can be the best from three colors but still finish in the last place. This is a modern classic which was created in 1997 but after all it is still a great game nowadays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played it once and was confused... and so were the other players at the table. The person introducing the game did a good job for the time she took, but the game is confusing to new people because of the lack of a player aid that organizes the rules. The game isn't hard to understand, it's just that the whole time we were saying "uhhh oh yeah internal conflicts are red, lol whoops"

Not a big problem after your first play, and I am not rating this game from my learning experience. I am rating it for what I think it would potentially be if I kept playing it.

And I give it a solid 8. I like that it has depth, in that you have many decisions and areas you can affect. If you think about it, you have a LOT of decisions! 

The major downer of the game is that it has little interaction with other players. I could be playing this game online with 3 other people, never talking to them, and I think I would have the same experience. Maybe if I revisited the game and tried to take on a more diplomatic role, this game would be more fun... so I am eager to try this game again and rethink my score of 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
6-4-15
There are a lot of neat mechanisms with conflicts at hand, but I hate how conflicts pretty much decide the game.  The ideal is to sneaky wins through external conflicts for maximum points.  Turtling can't help a whole lot, and avoiding conflict won't get you enough points.  The game isn't much different each time you play.  If we were going to play a conflict game, I'd rather play something lighter like Cosmic Encounter, or hunker down with Twilight Imperium.  Both games are fun to play even when losing, and provide more come-back options.  This can be a satisfying play if in the right mood with the right people but otherwise a bit of a drag.  If I want something dry, I'll opt for something like Container or Power Grid: Factory Manager.  Not worth keeping around for me anymore.

Traded 6-2-15.

RATING: 7.5
Only played once or twice, but I really like this so far and defintely see it rising in the future.

Raised this to a 7.5 after trying Gamegrunt's 2-player modifications- these greatly tighten the game flow, making it both faster and more head-to-head.

The game itself is almost abstract in it's activities, but the way in which it plays out, and the Knizian struggle to excel in all areas (possibly originated in this game?) make it a challenge to play well every time.

A classic Eurogame, in the best sense.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great game for 3 or 4 players, intent on taking each other's civilizations out of the picture.

And the fun thing is, that rarely matters in this game.  Once you've laid out your tiles and scored for them, there is very little reason to protect 'your' civilization from other players.

In fact, the biggest realization that dawns after a few games is that the game position is not represented on the board, but behind the player's screens in actual score.

Once you realize this, any sentimentality over kingdoms melt away and oppertunism rears its beautiful head.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

RATING: 5

RATING: 8
This, and Aquire are two games where scoring seems counter intuitive.  I explain that you are collecting "sets of 4 colors" and that seems to help new players.  However, how to score points is somewhat difficult to explain to newbies.  I like the mechanism that you don't "own" a color, and how switching control of cities can surprize new players.  However, the theme is a little dry and the game is only attractive to a small number of my play group.

RATING: 8
Regardless of what many will tell you, I find this game to be choke full of theme. IMO, the reason why many people find this game hard to teach is that they don't use the theme effectively. I really enjoy T&E's confrontation dynamics: Different forces make you want to be both the attacker and the defender in a conflict. Deciding when and how to start a conflict in T&E is one of the most interesting decisions you'll have to make in a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a real brain-burner. Well, at least the first time we tried to play it, trying to figure out the rules. Typical, poorly written rules from Knizia that are confusing (e.g. Ra, Samurai) at best. Yet, this is a genius of game design. I am continually amazed at how Knizia comes up with these unique game mechanics which are so simple, yet so profound.

Update (07/16/09): Played it again twice in one evening, after not playing it in over a year. It's a lot easier having the rules explained to you instead of trying to figure it out from reading the rules (and having played it before F2F and with the computer game). The play is much quicker, although it comes to a crawl near the end with thinking about all the various conflicts that could happen. The game is brutal, and a newbie can easily throw the game in someone's favor. It's not a perfect information game, however, due to the hidden tiles, but if equally matched in skill, this game could play like chess. This means it requires some investment to play well, and as a social experience, leaves something to be desired. Regardless, I'm upping it to an '8' from a '7'. It's growing on me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally, I have bought this game.  This is often regarded as Knizia's finest hour, and it is easy to see why.  The current edition comes with a double sided board which is apparently "harder", but I suspect it will be a while until I feel the need to try it.  At the moment, the main question I have is "is the random selection of tiles likely to skew the game significantly with experienced players?".  I look forward to answering this question over time.

Update: I must only have played this a dozen times so I am still a relative beginner, but my enjoyment is marred with the random tile draws much more than with, for example, Samurai.  The game is more complicated and has some nice asymmetries, but I just don't find it any more rewarding.  Plus, I now own [thing=24508][/thing]...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I enjoy this game.  It is really a confrontational game and thus needs to be played with people who can take that.  I played with my son and he got angry with me when I moved into his region.  If you are really into heavy confrontational games, you will love this game.  There is a lot of depth and strategy involved.  I rate it a "7" rather than anything higher because it is not really my kind of game.  I appreciate the genius of it.  I will play it and enjoy playing it, but I would much rather be playing a game like Reef Encounter, which is a similar, but much better and more creative implementation of this type of play. - - - - Having now played Reef Encounter a bunch of times, my recommendation is to get Reef Encounter instead of Tigris and Euphrates.  It is a much better implementation of the same type of mechanics, with a few extra twists thrown in to make it more fun.  I've now traded away this game because I would never choose to play T & E over Reef Encounter, which I rate a "10" and is one of my favorite games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
1.國戰發生時，交界板塊不算勢力，帶戰爭結束後恢復
多個戰爭發生時，引發戰爭者可以選擇戰爭，若選擇不是自己當戰爭者，則其他戰爭的攻方為引發戰爭者的順位下家。
2.國王領袖在國家內沒有其他類領袖時，放置其他文明可以得分
3.放置文明有其他玩家領袖在內，幫該玩家加分
4.內戰發生時，是比直接相鄰的宗教勢力加上補上的勢力，得一分紅色分數
5.一個國家內只能有一個寶藏，當有2個寶藏時候，擁有商人領袖的玩家可以領取寶藏
6. 文明最多連接兩個王國發生國戰，領袖不能連接王國
7. 每人有兩個行動，換版塊為一個行動，數量上限為6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Whew!  What a game...after playing it for the first time, I have played it a total of 6 within a week.  The interplay between leaders and civilization tiles allows a multitude of strategies and tactics.  Should you pursue a kingdom composed of only your own leaders?  Should you latch on to another players kingdoms?  Do you fortify against Internal conflicts? External conflicts?  And all the while attempting to maintain a balanced scoring attack, as your ultimate score for the game is the lowest score you post.  A Classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I have mixed feelings about this one due to some odd player interactions.  In our last game, player A launched an ill-advised attack against player B, which ended up giving player B a commanding lead.  As player C, it was rather frustrating that there was nothing I could do to stop this or to catch up afterward.  I'm afraid I prefer games in which players who make poor choices lose, rather than make some particular other player win.

Often ownership of the cities becomes an issue and some people have an illogical need to "build up their city" which is not how the game plays.(ideally you need to be more fluid than that not just trying to make monuments) Good game but rarely understood or played.

RATING: 8
Tigris and Euphrates is one of only a handful of games that I really hated on first playing, but I've warmed to it to some extent by playing the iOS version. It's a highly tactical and opportunistic game of building kingdoms and taking them to war. In spite of being a heavy game, there's still a substantial luck of the draw element in which tiles you get and the chaos factor can be huge as the kingdoms merge and break apart. There can be a nasty feeling of frustration in the conflict resolution, getting your leaders knocked off the board in midgame can lead to a spiral of defeat and weakness that's impossible to recover from. It's this that gives the game a 'bad experience' feel and with tight scoring, a few tiles either way can decide the game. The combination of rules heaviness with the random elements makes this a gaming oddball in my view, and as an initial sceptic, I fully sympathise with those who "don't get it". If you want a probability-based conflict game, Backgammon has fewer rules and less playing time, but my view of T&E has grown the more I've played it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I think this is by far Knizia's best game and I like it more with each play. Plays differently every time. Lots of scope for clever play of the sort you don't get in most games.

RATING: 7
This is a pretty deep game and there is a real ebb and flow to it as civilizations rise and fall.  It's largely about opportunism (leaching points out of other people's civilizations or attacking them at the right moment) but you can gain plenty of points by holing up with your monuments somewhere too.  I feel like there are far more layers to this than I will ever get to unravel, but it's certainly interesting. (3 plays)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
El JUEGO con mayúsculas del genial Knizia que debe jugarse muchas veces para apreciarlo como se merece (al contrario que Puerto Rico o Power Grid, que me aburren más conforme más juego). Clásco moderno de gran profundidad, comparable a la de los grandes abstractos. Muy, muy reflexivo. Genialidad absoluta el sistema de puntuación que obliga a desarrollar distintas estrategias en cada partida. Buen punto a su favor la mecánica de "los reinos no son de un único jugador". El azar presente no es determinante para ganar. Contras: Prácticamente compites contra ti mismo (ingnoras la puntuación ajena). Abstracto con reglas complicadas para ser un abstracto

[ENG]

It´s the Knizia´s GAME (with capital letters) that should be played many times to appreciate as it deserves, unlike Power Grid o Puerto Rico, that became boring with more plays. It´s a modern classic brainburning game at the same level of other great abstract games like. Extremely reflexive game. The system of scoring VP is genius becouse it obligates you to develop several strategies in each game. The mechanic "the kingdoms are not of the same player" is one of the most interesting ideas of the design. The randomness of the game does not determine who´s the winner. DRAWBACKS: Actually, you´re in a competition against yourself, becouse you can ignore the other´s scores. It´s an abstract game with fiddly rules to be an abstract.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Lots of depth and clearly benefits of multiple plays.  Scoring your least dominant color is a fantastic mechanic and drives you to change your focus throughout the game.  Abstract, tile-placing may be too dry for many people.

L’estrazione casuale delle tessere, lo rende, a mio avviso, un gioco più tattico che strategico. Geniale il meccanismo di calcolo dei punteggi, simile a quello di Samurai, dello stesso Knizia.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As Christopher Bartlett (cc_TheToph) wrote: "Everything that is wonderful, and everything that is terrible about German games in one box."  I basically agree with this.  It's wonderful to play, but afterwards there's nothing to remember fondly about.  "hahaha remember that time when I played a red tile and that gave me the one point I needed for the win.  Good times."

Another thing that I find surprising, is that on BBG most Euros players seem to hate luck in their games.  In T&E, however, the game is almost completely dependent on luck (tiles drawn out of the bag).  Since you have to give up an action to discard your hand, if you have a bad set of tiles, you are in a severe disadvantage because of the Reiner Scoring (tm) system (winner is the highest of the lowest). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I am incredibly impressed with this game. I had put off playing it because it sounded incredibly dry.  Nothing could be further from the truth.  Given the time to play and interested opponents, I would choose this over every single game that I've tried so far.  To all those out there who were put off at the thought of another tile-laying game do not despair.  This one is different and often exciting.  Having now played both a few times, I have difficulty understanding how this is rated below Puerto Rico.  PR is good, but not great.  This game is great.

RATING: 5
After 14 plays I've decided not to play it ever again.
It's just way too random compared to the length of the game.  Given more time you can counter bad luck, but not in a game lasting ~1h.

4 players is the worst number - you get too few turns and can do too little to turn around the bad fortune.  Maybe with 2-3 players it's slightly better (don't rememeber; I haven't played in such a mode for a long time), but it's not MUCH better...

Rating down from original 9 to 5.

Sold.

RATING: 9.5
An excellent strategy game with lots of interaction, it is a little tricky to learn but quite accessible, be sure to play a few times before passing judgement (It might take that many for everything to click). Lots of interesting strategy in this game that still intrigues after double digit plays. The theme seemed a little weak at first to me and it did seem a little dry in an abstract chess-like way but after more playings you do get the sense of civilizations rising and falling and the aftershocks of such ordeals. Watching and shaping the developing board is fascinating in a way that few other games capture and the anticipation of the coming conflicts really get your strategy juices flowing. More plays and a comparison to reef encounter to see which I might buy...

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 8.5 => 9 Rating went up and could more. This is really a "gamers" game and not one to teach the faint of heart. Some depth here and maybe his deepest along with TAJ. The scoring is very good and of course balanced as is the game play, it really goes without saying I think. Very challenging game and easy to overlook something as there is lots going on, 3 or 4 players would really be somewhat chaotic until you had a really firm grasp of the game. This is a classic to be sure even if a little dry, I'm not sure the wife will like it though. Still needs more plays...

[u]UPDATE:[/u] More plays FTF now and the wife is not crazy about it yet and she likes almost every game she plays, 3 games more with 2 people only, I believe 3 will be the sweet spot so I can't wait to try 3 and 4. 

[u]UPDATE:[/u] Played with 3 and while it was a great number the tile draw was horrible, one guy had all red and another none all game. This better not happen often...

I'm not sure I see the rating going above 9 now as the luck could be a tad higher than I like spoiling the occasional game. Another note, doesn't seem to be a very wife friendly game for some reason...

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 9 => 9.5 Guess what, it finally grew on the wife as she realized the brilliance of how the game develops and how dynamic the game is, it also doesn't hurt that she is good at it as well. Out of 20 games only one was really bad due to the tile draw (no red which is the worst) albeit the tiles can dictate your strategy but that is part of the beauty here, it forces you to slightly adapt on the fly not being too dependant on one strategy and to look for creative ways to gain cubes in your weakest colour. An excellent amount of depth versus game time here just like Taj, we knock this off in an hour, LOVE this game.

Still it is one of my desert island games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Strategisch spel in Mesopotamië, waar koninkrijken en leiders ontstaan en verdwijnen. Spelers spelen met leeuw, stier, urn of boogschutter, niet per kleur. Elke speler heeft een leider in elke kleur (rood: priester, blauw: boer, groen: handelaar; zwart: koning) waarmee hij een volk kan leiden (en punten in die kleur kan krijgen voor elke fiche in die kleur die in het koninkrijk bijkomt, of voor elk monument in die kleur in dat koninkrijk). Twee leiders van dezelfde kleur in een koninkrijk leidt tot een intern conflict (meeste rode tempels wint); twee leiders in verschillende koninkrijken die worden samengevoegd door het plaatsen van een fiche leidt tot een extern conflict (meeste fiches van die kleur in oorspronkelijk koninkrijk wint). Groene leiders kunnen schatten verzamelen; i.e. witte blokjes die als joker kunnen dienen. Het spel eindigt wanneer alle fiches opstaan (je vult steeds bij tot zes achter je scherm) of wanneer er aan het einde van een beurt nog maar een of twee schatten op het bord staan. Om de winnaar te bepalen kijkt elke speler naar de kleur waarin hij het minst heeft gescoord; de sterkste wint. De grafische vormgeving in deze oude versie is wat flets, maar het spel zelf is super strategisch en zit geweldig goed in elkaar.

Spel 2016: tweedehands gekocht 15 EUR; gekregen met Kerstmis 2016 van An
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A game i loved and finally got to purchase.Just alot going on in this one and love the conflict and strategy involved.Not really a hard game with a lot of rules but just a deep game as you try to figure out the best way to get points in your lowest color.

RATING: 8
I was pleasantly surprised by this. After being underwhelmed by Samurai and somewhat lukewarm on Ra, I figured this had no chance. But it was pretty compelling. In particular it was easier than I expected to get into. I hear it get compared to abstracts a lot, and I usually don't like abstracts because I feel like you can't really learn to play the game just by playing and I don't care to study a game. But it seems like you can pick this up fairly quickly just by playing it. And there are definite decisions and tradeoffs and all the things I expect out of a good game. I know this sounds like I'm saying it's good because it doesn't do anything wrong, and that feels like an odd thing to say, but I can't quite put my finger on what makes this game special, but I feel like there is such a thing to this game. Though I wonder how much its rating was helped by my low impression of the designer going in.

RATING: 8
This has stood the test of time and over 200 plays for me. Anything over 10 plays for me would have to be a winner already, this is an absolute top shelf game. It can be a real brain buster at times but that's why I love it! It's Knizia's best game, I think most wouldn't argue with that too much. Yes, there involves some luck with the tiles draws, but this game is otherwise all strategy and tactics but you play to the odds. This is not a light game nor is it extremely heavy and there is a bit of a learning curve that will be overcome after a few games; but it's absolutely worth the effort! IMHO this plays best with 3 players, each player has a little room to grow before battles begin. Four-player games tend to be crowded, players are often forced into battle a little too early. Two-player games are the bloodiest, there are constant back and forth conflicts with the winner of the first battle usually coming out on top. If you don't have this, you need to try this ASAP and lucky for you it can be played right here on the geek for free! Give it try then go out and buy!

**UPDATE** I've played this game a LOT, 200 times here online alone! It's getting a little...old. I took a while off from playing it, came back and played about 10 games and quickly got tired of it again. It's like hearing Thiller on the radio, used to love it but nowadays...? *flips station*

RATING: 10
Great. A bit too dry and heavy, a true classic in my bookshelf. A very solid game though. Reiner Knizia's masterpiece. This is a 2 to 4 player tile laying game, where players build up kingdoms of tiles on the board, and try to position their leaders to their best advantage. The game is won by taking cubes in four colours, but your score is the colour you have the least of. Ingenious mechanics and subtle deep game play. Simply wonderful. Buy it now.

RATING: 8
Edging out Lost Cities for my favorite Reiner Knizia game, Tigris & Euphrates contains some relatively simple mechanics that lead to tough decisions and exciting tactical play. It seems like every mechanic is interesting, whether it be the differences in the two forms of combat, the unique powers (both obvious and subtle) of each leader, the formation of monuments, or scoring only the lowest number of points, each mechanic somehow meshes together to create a unique gameplay experience.

Turns don't take a long time since you only get 2 actions.  The game mechanics actually encourage interaction and conflict, which is a huge plus for me.  The scoring system is very unique, and each game so far has played out differently.  Highly recommended for any abstract strategy fan.

(I won my next iPad game, but then got crushed by the better AI player because I neglected monuments.)  I'm sure it takes a lot to beat a skilled player, but there's just a small initial hump between newbies and intelligent play.  Watch the videos, go ahead and play without the tutorial, and before you finish a game, the differences between internal and external conflicts will make perfect sense (it's good to think of them, as the How To Play video suggests, as "revolutions" and "wars").

RATING: 10
Build kingdoms in ancient Mesopotamia. Possibly my favorite German-style game overall. The game is quite abstract, but for some reason the theme clicks with me anyway. The game also has that "constructive" feel, ie. you get to build/develop stuff, no matter whether you win or not (a game feature I am very fond of), and finally, gameplay is just extraordinary, with a fine balance of development, nasty tricks, and outright warfare. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
2016-07-04

Initial Rating: 7.5 (August 2010)

Tigris & Euphrates is a good game, there is no question about it, however, I almost never want to play it.

The game components are very good and they look great on the table.

The theme doesn’t excite me, but you don´t feel it through the game anyway (as most Knizia´s games).

The rules of the game aren’t complex, but the internal and external conflicts can be confusing at first. You can explain the rules under 20 minutes with examples. Game length is over 2 hours.

Best with 4 players, but it scales very well from 2 to 4 players. 

There is a healthy dose of luck in the game, I’m still undecided if the luck factor is uncontrollable or not, but I feel whoever got the most red tiles has an unfair advantage.

I liked it better when Mr. Knizia designed heavy games. I have disliked most (if not all) of his newer lighter games. I miss his old self :/.

Bottom line, I should love the game, but for some inexplicable reason, I never want to play Tigris & Euphrates. For now, It is a 5.5 for me. It is a game I respect, but that doesn’t grab me.

Current Rating: 5.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Draw a hand of tiles in four types. Each type supports a different one of the four leader types. Each player as one each of the leaders, but the tiles are shared/competed for on the board. Leader fights leader in "majority support wins" conflicts.

An excellent mix of engineering strategy and tactics, but having to steer your tactics according to your tile draw. A game that take some people a while to "get", since it's easy to get stuck in thinking of "my kingdom" and "your kingdom" which (a) closes many of possible directions of play and (b) substantially reduces the interaction and involvment of the game.

It's a more intense game than I want to play every week, but it's superb.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
one of the best tile-laying game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's very good. It may move up to a 9 with more play, but it could drop a slight bit too.

It's a pretty balanced and fluid game. I would not be surprised to hear complaints about the tile draws affecting the game and your play (I've cursed the tiles more than once!); this is true, but it's a lot like poker in feel to me, over time, it'll even out. 

The tiles do affect the game and they have too, it's the main motivator for change and action in the game, it's what creates the fluid nature and the obstacles all games need (obstacles make any game). You must be nimble and able to accept the fog-of-war the tiles bring to the game. 

The only time I can see the tiles strongly influencing the game is in the balance of reds and the impact your drawing luck has on rebellions (internal conflicts); I say this because the maximum on board defense you can have prepared for a rebellion against one of your leaders is 4 red tiles laid out in what I call the 'crucifix' (your leader on the cross). 

If you have no reds in hand when a rebellion strikes, you're hosed. Now, is that a bad thing for the game? A valid question and up to your opinion, but I see it as an intentional design of the game. It's clear that rebellions are meant to be damaging as there are 57 red tiles (20+ more than the rest of the colors); you are intended to rebel. This is important to note and it's to stop run-away games (along with the scoring method forcing balance). If the game were solely based upon external conflicts you would eventually get unassailable kingdoms by good players. 

You can build extremely solid empires with strong supply lines and board positioning. The positioning of a kingdom is huge in the ability to storm it (think of castle building positions in real life and you'll be thinking along my lines). Without a rebellion threat, these solidly built kingdoms can be neigh on impossible to storm. Rebellions (cultural revolutions, red book storming) provide a constant threat and opportunity. The higher count of red in the draw pile gives an average pay out over time (not necessarily in a particular game) and should allow you to at least have a couple of opportunities to punch back (though you may not win).

Now, even if that's not the case in a single game, you will have many chances to keep in the game depending on how you build and manage. I make no claims that you can always recover, you can't, but you will have options.

"Tigris and Euphrates" requires some willingness to be bold and strike when you're not certain you can win and sometimes the best strategy may not pan out due to the Fates and the fog-of-war. Boys and Girls, that's a fact of war...sometimes things go wrong or your timing is just off.

I can see a strong Poker influence in 'Tigris and Euphrates' and I can strongly see how it relates to wargames (yet, isn't one). This is a nebulous point here and I'm not sure how to state it, but it's about supply lines and cohesiveness in your kingdoms...It's about avoiding separations AND YET at times intentionally creating your own losses to break a kingdom for a follow up thrust.

"Tigris and Euphrates" is a very good game. I'll be curious to see how it develops for me and if I come to any firm resolutions on it. I'm still thinking about opening positions and I have some thoughts there (it could become static in standard openings, but the actual game play will vary greatly) and I'll have to play it with more players, but I like it so far. 

I took to the understanding of the game fairly quick, but I don't make a case that I'm dangerous or mighty in it--as I'm not, I'm kind of pathetic so far. :laugh:

I must confess that I'd avoided it for a long time (something just didn't appeal to me by looking at the box) but I finally bought it in a mad flurry of purchasing. I'm glad to have it and I'm glad the 'Geek has it online to play as it may be hard to get people to take a crack at it; this will depend greatly upon your group's tastes and reasons for gathering together for a game--so, pay attention to your group and who might like a more involved session. this is not hard to teach really, but my gaming background (and GameMastering) history probably skews my view.

I'm very glad that Jimzik (fellow 'Geek) invited me into my first ever game. It was a good time and I really thank him for it. I actually held up longer than I thought and hope that I was, at least, respectable in my showing.

I'm going to develop this writing out as a separate article and will shorten this entry at that time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-4 players. Strategic, tile-laying game. There are four categories of points, of which your lowest is your total score, requiring you to balance your acquisition of points between all four types.

RATING: 10

RATING: 10
OK, two (ftf) plays in twenty years and I finally get this - why did I wait so long?

In an era when the same set of Eurogame mechanisms get endlessly recycled in an whirl of themeless, interaction-free, forgettable same-as-it-ever-was points engine generators it's refreshing to contemplate how simple yet razor-edged this game was, and remains.

Boiled-down, competitive (at times brutal) Eurogaming at its best. Multiplayer solitaire this is not.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
- The SU&SD "good move" review sums this one up really.
- The theme does work, but really it's an abstract game.
- I really like that on your turn you can do two actions. It's just enough to do stuff, but really you often want/need a third. Great game design.
- Heaps of player interaction. This isn't a game where you can win (realistically) by doing your own thing. You need to get up into peoples' grills.
- The scoring mechanism is great as it forces players to interact and change-up what they're doing regularly through the game.
- Despite the last couple of points, it's easy to become attached to one's creation, fighting to maintain control over it, when really you should just let it go while you fight over someone else's empire.
- Plays great with all player counts, but with 2 it's neck and neck. Love it!
- Teaching is not hard at all. The game has simple rules. The problem for new players is that it's not obvious what to do, and it's hard to remember the main mechanisms at first because they are so abstract.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I would have to count this as the best of Dr Knizia's work. Not only does it display the quantitative analysis which is his hallmark, it also ably recognises the importance of variable strategies to a good board game.

RATING: 6
My preference is for the Mayfair edition... the original German edition is "too busy".  And, the rules for scoring could have been worded differently (why not just say that you have to collect sets of colours?)

At one time I rated this game higher, but I've dropped it to a 6.  I still enjoy playing, but the "shine" has worn off... there is definitely too much luck in the tile draws.  

I don't mind luck in most games, but the person who draws the right tiles at the right time in this game is going to win nine times out of ten.

Luck will tend to even out over the course of a few games, but sitting for almost 2 hours and only ever drawing 5 red tiles can be very frustrating.

I am looking to buy the new Euro edition with variant mapboard.

RATING: 6
I'm not sure why people LOVE this game.  I can see people liking it, but to be in the top 10?

Admittedly, the scoring mechanic is clever and works great.  Some of the colored attack mechanics are interesting and allows for great decision making/interaction, however, I simply don't see the appeal.

I much prefer the good doctor's more recent Ingenious.  Both are abstracts that offer the same great scoring mechanic but Ingenious is much less complicated and plays about 30-45 minutes faster.

RATING: 10
My favorite boardgame so far.

It plays differently, but oddly, I could write the same comments than for the game Manhattan.

The genious idea of this game is the scoring system. Players secretly accumulate points in four different categories, and when players reveal their final score at the end of the game, they compare the amount they achieved in the category where they have the lowest number of points !

Grande, cada día me gusta más como juego, además puesto sobre la mesa y avanzada la partida queda muy bonito.

Juego tenso donde los haya, en el que la colocación de las losetas en el tablero no hace otra cosa que generarte preocupación porque tus rivales no vengan a por ellas.

Tiene un puntito que es virtud y defecto, y es la interacción, que es alta. Cualquier cosa que hagas sobre el tablero se va a ver reflejada en los demás. Esto es un pro a la hora de planificar tu estrategia, pero un contra porque provoca un alto factor "kingmaker", y alguien sin querer, puede arruinarle la partida a otro jugador.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I imagine we're all on the same page here, but here's the "last time, on BGG" voiceover for you anyway. T&E is Reiner Knizia's highest ranked game. It's the oldest game in the top 10. It was #1 prior to the release of PR in 2002. It is rated a perfect 10 by both of the site owners and can be played in the forums here on BGG. It also has a reputation for being a "bolt from the blue" as far as game design goes. My geekbuddy analysis shows comments like "crazy-unique" and "game-god made flesh." It is well known for being strategically opaque and counterintuitive yet smooth-flowing and engrossing. The game's thematic integration polarizes players into those who see a pure positional abstract, and those who see the ebb and flow of civilizations. Etc.

OK, so I finally played the game, and what I found was the supreme development of Sid Sackson's 1962 classic, [thing=5][/thing]. There's no memory element (for those of you who play Acquire with closed shares), but the basic premise is intact: add tiles to [-]hotels[/-] kingdoms, position yourself as a stakeholder in these kingdoms, and maneuver such that when two kingdoms [-]merge[/-] collide, you score points. The thing is, in Acquire, tiles are permanent and the hotels glom onto each other, eventually forming super-duper hotels in one giant tile-blob. Conflicts in T&E are multi-step because each Kingdom may have up to four "dimensions" (various elements of civilization: agriculture, religion, etc.), and the resolution of each conflict will remove one or more pieces from the board, segmenting and re-segmenting the kingdoms. Thus, "ebb and flow." 

I think it's a very good game that requires repeat play to get into. To keep it from becoming straight-up multi-player chess, Knizia included both hidden information (you have a hand of six tiles - just like acquire) and a not-small dose of randomness via the tile draw. During conflicts, you may play tiles from your hand to influence the outcome, and on your turn, you may use an action to discard all of your tiles and draw new ones. In other words, tiles are drawn frequently enough that it's not uncommon to randomly have three or four of one type, and that could really save you if the right situation arises on the board. I won my first game of T&E because I had three black tiles during a 5-2 attack. The back-blast against my opponent gave me 6 points in my second-lowest color, just as I was setting up to score big in my lowest. I won with 9-9-9-11. 

I think the tile-draw is always going to seem "one step too far" to players, as far as including an element of chance. I don't think it ruins it though. The other easy criticism of this game is that external conflicts heavily reconfigure the board such that you have to discard your last three minutes of planning and take another three minutes before proceeding. The 2hr playing time comes entirely from the "need a new plan" syndrome. 

Personally, I think anyone who is new to gaming should avoid T&E unless they're predisposed to like more abstract and positional games. It's a must-try once you're a "gamer." 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Abstract, brain burning, great! Eurogames aren't made like this anymore and if they were I would doubt that they could be succesful with worker placement and combo- / deck-building being the name of the game. T&E offers a wealth of options that only are revealed with experience. It's a game of positional play and preparing your attack. You better have a master plan what you're doing... and a Plan B as the actions of other players can alter the state of play dramatically. It's similar here to games like Indonesia or Chicago Express that inexperienced players can completely turn the game with an unthoughtful decision.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Eminently satisfying though fairly chaotic game, This is a true Euro but should appeal to those who enjoy direct conflict and some randomness in their games. T&E owes more than a little to Sackson's classic Acquire but surpasses that earlier game in a number of ways, not least of which being the fact that one is scored on his or her weakest color, which forces a balancing act throughout the game. The rules are a bit complicated, but they shouldn't be much of an obstacle after a few plays; trying it out and making mistakes seems to me the best way to learn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Does it get better than this?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Yes, I can see why this one is so highly regarded. Quite difficult to teach, but great depth and replayability.

RATING: 9
I really like this game a lot. The way the winner is decided is simply great and the hidden-scoring adds a nice factor of mystery. Even more important for me, though, is the fun involved in continuous searching for ways to attack other players. I think this is great even when lady luck's not on your side. You'll just have to play to your own strengths, i.e. not whine about getting bad tiles but trying to be creative with them. It's extremely rare to get just bad tiles all the way through a play. Also works fine with 2 players. And what comes to the theme, I think it's quite strong.

RATING: 8.5
I know I'm in the minority on this, but my favorite part of this game is its theme, and how thematic it is. I know it's blasphemy to say this about a Knizia, but I love the theme of a family being involved in the development of multiple nations, being pushed out, coming back in a rival nation. The stories you can tell with this are a cool, Game of Thrones-like intrigue. I love how each color does something different. Making such things feel different in small ways is something I like a bunch, and this does it well.

RATING: 4
After playing a few times this game plays where you beat up on the little guy in order to stage the final confrontation with the other big guy in the game. So you are either the big guy (because of a good starting draw) and you pick on the little guy... or you are a small guy and get really good draws and finally get to internal conflict the big guy... or you just get to be the little guy the whole game. Lets just draw the colors out of the bag to decide the winner instead to save some time shall we?

The scoring is based on who has the most blocks of smallest colored amount. Yet people still try to monopolize one or two colors the whole game thinking it is of benefit by simply denying someone else of it. So when the game is all over, the winner has 6-8 points or so... all that effort for 8 points...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In relation to the other Eurogames I've played since having been introduced to the genre, Tigris was quite unique.  I liked that it had some aspects of a resource development/management game but it was contained in the same system as an abstract game of conflict.  The competitive mechanics were much smoother in this game than other Euros I've played.  Games like Catan, Caylus, and Puerto Rico are built on a core system of personal resource management, so when you get robbered or provosted it can be frustrating, ie, "Why didn't they just concentrate on their own development?"  But in Tigris it felt very clear and natural.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is the greatest example of a less is more design paradox.  Knizia has given players about 5 million torturously difficult decisions from a total of about 5 cohesively designed mechanics.  
You can play this game fast and loose or slow and tight.  And there are both tactical and strategic considerations with the random tile drawing and the hidden scoring mixed with almost a chess-like potential for misplay in tile placement.  
Because of the hidden information and the randomness, you cannot simply analyze the best play like you can in a more abstract game with perfect information.  This dynamic is created in true Knizia fashion with a set of mechanics that constrain players just enough so no one gets overwhelmed by analysis paralysis while considering their many possible actions.  
It's Knizia's ability to walk this line and make a game that feels both light and deep that makes gameplay feel satisfying without being exhausting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Absolutely great game.  Nice method of playing out conflicts with Euro mechanics.

RATING: 8
One of my favorite heavier games, which I still haven't wrapped my head around yet...but still enjoy playing

I can see why this game has much acclaimation, it even scales well from 2-4, though the dynamic completely changes.

The internal/external combat is one of the neatest concepts I've seen in gaming, causing you to balance out your defences.  Kind of gives you the feeling of playing two positions at the same time.

RATING: 7.1
A real brain-burner!  This is a game worthy of some exploration.  The first couple times you play, the strategy is hard to grasp.  

This is Reiner Knizia's most interesting game - at least as it appeals to my intellect.  But there is a extremely dry feel to this game.  (The theme enhances this.)  Mechanically this game is hard to grasp, and takes some repeated plays to learn how to play well.

Unfortunately these lessons get lost with long gaps between plays.  So lately my sporadic plays of this title have been less fun than earlier sessions I can recall.

RATING: 8
Bought at Playing Games on Museum Street in London sometime around 2000, when on vacation with my then girlfriend. I remember reading about this on the young Internet, it being hyped as some guy "Knizia"'s to-be-masterpiece. It was probably the theme that interested me most as I had not yet discovered Eurogames, being firmly planted in Avalon Hill material.

The game is Knizia at his best, and is one of my favourites, though it is somewhat demanding of its players. Scales very well between 2-4 persons, I think. Somewhat of a brainburner, though. Try & you'll like!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A little bit euro, a little bit wargame (Well high conflict game anyway).  I grew up on wargames and chess so I don't get the "We all have to hold hands and play nice when playing a game." thing so many these days seem to have.  This game sort of even reminds me of other old games like Acquire in how "mergers" happened.  More than any other element though the scoring system is a brilliant design and showcases just how lazy many more modern game designs are with their boring scoretrack and 84 ways to score points.  Tigris & Euphrates is simply a perfect and elegant game design.  And its not complex at all, only the strategies are.  I sold my original copy in order to eventually pickup the FFG one as I dig the art in it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My favorite Reiner Knizia game. First several plays are very abstract but upon reflection and replay, strategy and planning become more obvious. As with many of his games, balance is important since it is the person that has the most of the least that determines the winner – tile distribution adds some randomness into the game but does not take away from the depth or options available. Board position can be important as well as carful observation of other players weak colors. Quite enjoyable game that does not get as much play time as it deserves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Played once and didn't see what all the hype was. Should play it a couple more times before I rate it, but I feel comfortable with this score.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The first impression when learning Tigris & Euphrates is a big "Huh?": the mechanisms that it employs are extremely clever and balanced, but they are far away from being intuitive so the first steps in learning curve can be frustrating and disappointing for some. The extreme shallowness of the theme does not help a bit there, so you are going to have a hard time if you do not like abstracts. But then, what is it good? Simple: everything else.

As a tile laying game, having a general strategy is important, but where you will squeeze your brain will be developing and adapting your tactics each turn, depending on what you draw. A lot of people complain of excessive luck and, though it is possible to be screwed, skill is far more determining than anything else, just make sure to keep changing your short term goals depending on what tiles you are dealt.

Another big plus of the game is the interaction, which is great: there are a lot of ways to affect your opponents, either creating conflicts or with a clever use of disaster tiles. Indeed, if you avoid conflict and you employ your disaster tiles poorly you will loose. The classic Knizia's scoring mechanism (ending score equal to your lowest partial score) works like charm and helps in growing the conflict atmosphere a lot.

What does Tigris & Euphrates offer? Well, it is a wonderful tile laying game with loans of interaction and possible lines of action. For me the game's luck factor is just enough to provide a challenging tactically game.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:4

RATING: 7
Rating is based on a handful of online games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome game! Simply the best! Firmly occupies the top spot in my all-time top10. Rather complex and surprising when you start learning the game, but once you master the game mechanisms ... pure bliss! **** The goal of the game is to build-up a balanced civilisation (represented in the game by four colors). The importance of the "balance" is obvious from the very original victory points calculation: your final points are the number of cubes in the color of which you have fewest. **** Luck is limited to the tiles you draw. The game is tactical in the appropriate use of the set of tiles you have, but still also strategical in the placement of tiles to allow building monuments and to avoid loosing external power during conflicts between other leaders. The randomness of the tiles ensures replayability. Even if you are very low in a specific tile, it is possible to win. **** Euphrat & Tigris plays equally well with 4, 3 or 2 players, although is at its best with 4. One-on-one games between equally skilled players will most likely result in very tense games, often decided by a single tile or a rather minor tactical error. **** My most played game with more than 175 plays, mainly thanks to the online version at BGG. By the way, the open scoring makes it even more tactical. **** The Nile (2-player variant board) is a refreshing new map and can also be played online at BGG. Played: 9 (win: 8, 5 as lion and 3 as urn - loss:1, 1 as lion).

RATING: 6
I enjoyed this one on my first playing, on a purely intellectual level.  Uses the seemingly counter-intuitive "weakest-set-scores" mechanism that Knizia seems to prefer (of course, it's just completed sets).  Must play again to see if it's actually "fun" for repeated plays.

UPDATE: I've played this a few times now.  It's OK.  I almost never want to sit down to play it.  It's not "boring" so it's not a 5.  I can't quite put my finger on it.  May simply be too dry, abstract, and calculating for me.  The terminology is irritating -- the baroque system of "internal conflicts" always using red tiles, but "external conflicts" using the tiles of the leader is a little weird.  A better name would probably help new players grok the rules.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Regarded by many as Reiner Knizia's masterpiece, Tigris & Euphrates is set in the ancient fertile crescent with players building civilizations through tile placement. Players are given four different leaders: farming, trading, religion, and government. The leaders are used to collect victory points in these same categories. However, your score at the end of the game is the number of points in your weakest category, which encourages players not to get overly specialized. Conflict arises when civilizations connect on the board, i.e., external conflicts, with only one leader of each type surviving such a conflict. Leaders can also be replaced within a civilization through internal conflicts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.3
Maybe it's because I started playing this one only after the other two titles in the tile-laying trilogy; I'm not sure this one is the best of the bunch. Strong and great game, but luck has a bigger role than in TtD and Samurai; also it is strictly for gamers (while the other two aren't). At the moment it does not seem to be the game that is the hardest to win against gamers with lot of experience.
Update: while all said above is true, it IS a very enjoyable game, a great one in fact. It's just very different from the other two in the trilogy. One of the best games I have, and the second best of the trilogy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[Original] The heaviest Reiner Knizia game ever published (to date). That said, it is by no means unapproachable. As in Knizia's "Through the Desert", once you get past the concept that as a player you are not a "color", the game is easy-to-learn but hard-to-master. What is interesting, is that this conflict game offers a nearly unique end-game scoring system (seen again in Knizia's 2004 release Ingenious). This tile-laying game should be played (at least once) by every gamer, be that gamer a Euro gamer or grognard. 

[2007.Mar.19] Traded my 1998 (Deutsch) Hans im Glück edition of T&E away. Although, this game is well-respected and loved-by-many, it simply did not receive enough time on the game table to warrant its inclusion in my game collection. To be honest, I always feel like I "play at" playing the game, rather than play the game. I guess T&E simply doesn't hit the right chords for me.

[2007.Aug.8] To clarify, T&E is by no means a bad game. I am sure that I will continue playing this Knizia classic in the future; it's simply not my first choice to play.

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

RATING: 10

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Phenomenal game with an utterly unique array of brilliant and jaw-dropping dynamics. I can see why so many people consider this to be Knizia's masterpiece!

I normally wouldn't change the rules of a game so well designed; however, I think this slight balance tweak can be justified: the first 2 players only take 1 action for their initial turns. (In a 2-player game, this restriction only applies to the first player.) This subtle modification compensates very well for the known turn-order advantage, without changing the fundamental strategies/tactics/etc. of the game. It's also very Knizia-esque: he used this same balancing principle in Through the Desert one year after Tigris and Euphrates was published.

RATING: 7
The archetypal euro.  An exceptional game that is now suffering from old age for me.  I rarely say this, but here, the theme and ambiance is so abstract and inconsequential that we tend to favor newer, "shinier" games.  Still, it's a classic for the thinking player.  With the years, it seems playing Tigris feels more and more like playing 'Go' or 'Chess', and less and less like playing a boardgame (in the modern sense).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I knew that this game was not for me, but I happen having no choice to play it. Anyways, since it's a classic, I had at least to play it at least once.

It's a very abstract game, the theme is very thin, there is a lot of colors, which is bad for me since I am partially color blind, and it's made by knizia. These are all good reasons for me to hate the game.

Because of the color issues, it's very hard for me to analyze the board. I do not have problem differentiating colors, it's just that it's hard for me to see in a glance which chunk will have a majority in a certain color.

Second, each leader has special powers, each tile have a different effect in certain circumstance which makes it sometimes confusing making the board even harder to analyze.

So this game is only made for pure euro style games fanatics. The theme is so thin that you have no feeling of actually building up a civilization.

RATING: 10
Tigris and Euphrates is a really well done game.  I don't want to play it very often, but it's a really well done game.  


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This classic has to be one of my favorite Knizia games.  It's stellar with four and very good with three.  It takes newbies a bit getting used to in understanding the effects of certain actions or inactions and in learning the distinction between internal vs. external conflicts.  It's also important to understand the probabilities of drawing a red tile vs. a blue tile vs. a black or green tile throughout the game.  Keeping track of these is probably as important as trying to keep track of which players have accumulated how many of which colored cubes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A hard one, because my first few plays I found this engrossing and incredibly tense.  I was ready to crown the game as so many others have.

And yet, each time, at game's end, I felt oddly unsatisfied.

What it comes down to is that for such a calculative, brain-burning game, far, FAR too much of it comes down to the luck of the tile draw.  You can get completely killed, or dominate an opponent completely, based on a hot or cold run of the tiles.

I just don't like the mixture of brain-burner / wild chaos.  One or the other would be fine, but I don't want to stare at the board for minutes pondering my fate and have it all be undone because I didn't draw enough red.

Too, the rules are just a tad too fiddly for me as to annoy.

In the end, I traded it away.  I might play it again if someone put a copy in front of me, but I don't feel the need to own this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wanted to play because the high BGG rating.  Some claim this as a deep Euro type game.  Interesting to know how does it play out. I like the iOS version much better than the boardgame version given that it is basically a mathematically maximization game. Euroish and abstract. There are a lot of choices and somewhat like GO.  Each game can be very variable and testing your nerve all the time.        

I quite like the game and so far I haven't been able to beat the AIs yet.  The game seems to have a lot of layers and deeper than I initially thought.  There are quite some options to make the game interesting and longevity extended, for examples, hidden scores, hidden tiles and hidden no. of remaining tiles heightens the darkness revolving around you about the development of the other civilizations and timing of the end of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Definitely my favorite game alongside Imperial (and now Chicago Express). Very simple rules, but it really takes a while to master the strategies.

One of those games that will make you talk about for quite some time after each play. Some say it is "too abstract", but, to me, the design of this game is just perfect. Newbies tend to think luck of the draw is excessive here, but my experience in the old days in Tigris@BGG clearly shows that good players will virtually always beat bad players regardless of what they draw. This is really *the* benchmark in strategic/tactical board game elegance.

I've wrote about my first five years with this masterpiece here: [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1222399/five-years-tigris-and-euphrates]Five Years with Tigris&Euphrates[/url]

RATING: 8
My rating is for the 2-player game.

Great feelings: the conflict is open on many fronts.  Great tension.  Both strategy and tactics are very present.  Drawing tiles adds randomness but luck is not so important.

Intense reflexion.  The fact that kingdoms are not necessarily owned by a single player is refreshing.

Quite difficult to play, in the first few games.  It takes time to get accustomed to _not_ owning a kingdom.  Also, the two types of conflicts are easily confused, at the beginning.

Not good for 2 at 30%, according to BGG!  (Good or best at 70%...)

RATING: 9
I hesitated to rate this because I've only played here on BGG, and the normal flow of the game isn't readily apparent that way.  Now, however, I am convinced that this is a great game.  The randomness of the tile draw, which can lead to frustration sometimes, is the one thing standing between this game and a 10 rating from me.  Still, it is very deep, both strategically and tactically, with a large strategy space for a German game.  Too bad I pretty much suck at it.  I may even add it as an entry in Fawkes ludomasochism GeekList :)

UPDATE: I decided 9 was a tad high for the time being, although I imagine that when I get to play this FtF (assuming I do eventually), this will get bounced back up.  Call it a wannabe 9 :)

UPDATE: Ah what the heck.  I'm always playing this on BGG, usually 3 or more games at a time.  If that isn't a 9 I don't know what is.

UPDATE: I now own a copy, and have played it face-to-face. What a pleasure, although it will probably take a couple more plays before the others in my group get comfortable with the game. Still a 9, but there's some upside potential there.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I had no idea what I was doing in the game I've played, but I can still tell how expertly designed this game is. It's like the modern Go, fairly straightforward rules but incredibly brain burny with a place a piece for area control aspect. The different colors makes you have to consider different modes of play by your opponents, while the scoring of your minimum color score makes it so you can't just spam one color. Like Go where you place your tiles is not immediately apparent all the ramifications it has, which adds layers of strategy, but also potentially AP. The random tile draw while some might not like the randomness adds some hand management aspects to the game while presumably making the start of the game more variable, and there is a mulligan action (which is not a complete wasted turn, you can also use it to stock up on a color you want or rush the end of the game). Overall seamlessly combines all of its mechanisms together (albeit very abstractly) into a game that I can understand why there are many proponents that it should be ranked #1.

I wish the board's size scaled to the number of players, as otherwise it seems too open with less than 4, but it is nice that there are 2 sides to play on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A good game. However, it hasn't hit the table in a long time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A classic.  When you read the rules at first, it seems less streamlined than many of Knizia's games, but the depth those extras add to the game is vital.  Each turn is short and tight and each decision builds on the others.  Many turns will be simple and straightforward, building and building.  And then the conflict (which is the heart of this game) begins and a turn of intense concentration ensues, where you weigh every option carefully.  It is true that a lack of one color (especially red, but often blue) can thwart even a great player, but for the most part, a great player will not let his inadequacies show.  There is some luck, then, in the draw of the tiles.  Again, a good player will be ready and will make sure of his victories and reduce the losses.  As I said, a classic.  I should be playing it more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a classic tile-laying boardgame with simple rules.  Collect the most sets of all four color cubes, and you win.  Includes elements of direct conflict, push-your-luck, and hidden/trackable information.  Reiner Knizia's masterpiece.  The Sage mobile app is also pretty decent.

RATING: 8
This is a physically beautiful game, with a lovely board and varied components that achieve a gorgeous stylistic unity. Gameplay is lots of fun - full of tension and reversals, and the "count your lowest score" mechanic is pure genius. This having been said, although the rules are very idiosyncratic it does play rather abstract. For this reason, it just barely loses out (for me at least) to the more recent, highly similar KHRONOS, which is perhaps not as original, but has even better art, and rules that do a palpably better job of catching the theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My favorite Reiner Knizia game.  You place tiles on a map to score points of different colors if you have a leader of the same color in that kingdom.  Form a square to build a temple that scores every turn.  You can have rebellions and wars to remove tiles from the game and score points.  

Your score is your lowest number of points on a color track which encourages you to have balance when expanding your tracks.  

I really like this game.  It was formally a BGG number 1 ranked game and it is different than most other games.  If you have not played I strongly recommend you play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
It was the scoring mechanism that truly intrigued me into playing this game.

A great tactical, abstract, civilization builder.

RATING: N/A
Worth owning for a good price, but recognize that this game is definitely heavy at 3.6 weight and therefore will not be played too often by casual gamers. 

Tigris & Euphrates has been through several different editions already:
1997 - Original German edition: Hans im Glück = Top Licence & 999 Games (French/Dutch)
2003 - Original English edition: Mayfair Games (Beige box, thin blue border)
2007 - Revised German edition: Pegasus Spiel
2008 - Revised English edition: Mayfair Games (Blue box) --> THIS VERSION (the revision) IS THE ONE TO GET!!
NB: "Main diff betwn the 2 english editions is the map artwork and some additional elements" (ex: new artwork, doubled sided expansion map)
NB: Box says 3-4 players. WRONG! it's 2-4 like it's predecessor.
NB: Not enough treasure cubes for the expansion board (comes with 10, but needs 14)

Why did Mayfair produce a revised edition?
Mayfair sold out of its previous copies of Tigris & Euphrates. Since the German publisher Pegasus Spiele released a revised version of Tigris & Euphrates with several new elements (a two-sided gameboard, four new civilization buildings, and an advanced scenario for game play), Mayfair decided to incorporate these new elements in its new printing. The new elements were designed by Knizia himself.

To read more about the revised edition: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/376984/so-youre-wondering-about-the-revised-edition-of-te


NB:recommended by Matt Leacock (http://www.leacock.com/games/index.html)

REVIEWS WORTH READING:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/509126/a-reminder-why-old-school-te-is-such-a-great-game
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/529564/knizias-masterpiece
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/591322/te-first-impressions-after-roughly-5-plays-also-so
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/413768/tigris-euphrates-short-review-why-i-wont-be-buyi
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/399480/tigris-euphrates-as-a-2-player-game
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/146278/before-you-buy-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tigris & Euphrates is highly interactive, with fast and epic changes on the board, and a reasonable fog-of-war.
Each turn is a puzzle to be solved, but it's not too deep, due to the random draw, which limits the downtime.
It's surprisingly difficult to learn, since what looks to be symetrical, turns out not to be - there are exceptions to most rules, but it all balances out.

Some players think it all comes dawn to drawing the right tiles, but that's only true if you look at a single turn - over the course of the game it equals out. If you play your tiles, instead of looking for tiles to play, then you win.
Think like this: Instead of looking at the board for the best move, and then at your tiles for the ability to make that move, then look at your tiles and make the best play you can.
Don't (and I'm close to saying never) waste a move on exchanging tiles - it'll only frustrate you, and it's not the way to win (unless of course, you do it to empty the bag in the face of you worst opponent ;-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
First impression after two 3p games.  I can see why this is a Knizia and abstract classic.  Very interesting abstract game with a high degree of player interaction and what appear to be an open board with many ways to advance one's strategy.  In spite of the "luck of the draw" it is definitely a skill based abstract where a more skilled player will have an advantage.  Very intrigued, would like to play it again to get a better sense of how fluid it is and how interesting after repeated plays.  Don't beleive those who say that there is a theme -- it is a pure Knizia game, abstract with a great game mechanic and a pasted on theme for cosmetic purposes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tigris and Euphrates walks the line between the mutually exclusive qualities that attract me to games.  It is great with 2, but scales well to three or four.  It has confrontation but no player elimination.  It offers multiple paths to victory, and all paths have an equal chance of bearing a player to victory.  It is a study in compromise, the most versatile game in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game really can't be called themeless.  This feels like a game that was played in ancient Sumeria as their version of a game of Fertile Crescent Empires rising and falling.  You'll get it the first time you see a vast empire wiped out in one catastrophic conflict, watching as the remnants either fade under the shifting sands or rise again to challenge for supremacy in the region.

My only critique?  The anticlimactic (yet undoubtedly good strategy) way the game can end with someone choosing to empty the bag on their turn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Never seems to get enough gameplay as I like, other people in my playgroup always want to play some of our old standbys more than this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
3.5 iOS only
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
The Knizia Magnum Opus. The ultimate masterpiece. Very simple mechanically, yet offers astounding depth and strategical possibilities. The mechanisms are abstracted to purity but the thematic connection is still discernible in how each kind of conflict is resolved and how the different civilizations that the players represent and guide relate to each other. There aren't many games that I think everyone should own, but this is one of them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The rules are simple enough but understanding the result of a tile lay due to conflicts is not so obvious. It taks a few plays to get a grip on how the system works. 

The game plays well and rewards planning ahead.

RATING: 10

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
+ plastic cubes!

Rating based on 3 and 4 players.

A wonderful game. A terrific blend between strategy, thinking, and just the right amount of luck in the tile draw. The rare Euro that has elegant rules that encourages aggressive play. A game that requires careful consideration, but doesn't have too much downtime because you might have to act on anyone's turn. The hidden scoring and tile-drawing makes things less AP-prone, and gives the game tension--you can deduce, you can guess, but you can never truly KNOW.

Despite Knizia's reputation for pasted-on themes, I find the mechanics of T&E to be closely tied to the game's theme of kingdoms being built and falling--it doesn't matter to you, you only care about your dynasty and doing what benefits it. Revolt/war mechanics make sense--are the people/the gods on your side, or your opponent's?

I have the FFG version, and am happy with it--the only problem I have is that that I miss the cubes from the previous versions (EDIT: I bling'd it out with cubes!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Hands down one of my favorite games of all time, which by now surely can be called a classic. Coincidentally, the very first game I played when getting back into games in 2002 after a long hiatus.

Brilliant design by Knizia; atypical in the sense that a game like this wouldn't (and didn't) pop out of his creative process regularly. A towering achievement by a master at the height of his powers, Knizia manages to synthesize his design approach into a single masterpiece that tells a story and has a narrative arc without any crutches (phases, etc.) or chrome. 

Game/theme link is downright fantastic, though abstract. The way kingdoms rise and prosper and then fall by the wayside through wars, with some remnants still languishing on the board, I find very evocative. Building a monument weakens the power base of the leader benefitting from it the most. Stunning how a relatively clutter-free design can include details like this by just flipping four tiles. 

Try to watch some of the old Board Room episodes on YouTube about E&T. They did a twelve-part series just on this game together with Knizia.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
You people and your strategy! This game is not neccesarily one of my favourites. It's saving grace is that when I played it for the first time I had a cute woman as my partner.

RATING: 9
19,95 eur - sep 2006 - Dreamland Wilrijk
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A tile laying game. The game mechanic is simple, with you taking 2 of any 4 actions a turn (place tile, place/move leader, destroy tile, draw new tiles). However the game is a rich puzzle of building kingdoms and destroying your enemy. The game state changes so much from turn to turn that you are so invested in the game state. Many games say that you "care" or are "interested" in others turns, but this is the first game I've ever played that on others turn i did not worry so much about my next move, but was analyzing my opponents.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is just one of those games that, when youve figured out whats going on, youre blown away by how clever it is. 

Sometimes you can get screwed a bit on the tile draw but theres a lot more you can do to deal with this than some people make out. The games is about making the best possible moves with what youre given. And theres a huge amount of options.

Dont be put off by people claiming this game is too complicated to understand. Its really quite simple, even for a euro.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of Knizia's finest. I have always enjoyed this game!

RATING: 9
I find the tension in the game excellent.  The rules favor agressive play which makes it even more interesting.  I prefer the artwork of the original Mayfair edition over the reprint.

One of the few games that plays well across the entire spectrum of recommended players.

The rules are little hard to grasp for new to moderate gamers. New players seem to have trouble remembering that they're not playing a color but instead a figure/dynasty-image.  I've never had a problem determine internal from external conflict but that seems to be a tricky point with new players. Maybe it's the difference with how the payouts occur.

Many, many paths to victory. Rarely is there not something advantageous to do on your turn.

RATING: 6

Repeat playings keep stripping away from this, it's a "decent" tile laying game, but there are many better games I'd rather play out there.

RATING: 8
A solid game overall. The internal and external battles are interesting mechanics not present in many other games this way which along with the lowest section score makes it less of a majority control game and more about timing and focus. 

The types of battles and kingdom join rules take a bit to explain though, but after a quick first game, people jump in. Hidden points are always good (avoids bash the leader). 

No real theme though, so if that bothers you, this may not be a hit.

RATING: 10
Preliminary rating: I really like this game. It has an abstract feel, but the theme is very well chosen. It looks like the gameplay is really in line with the theme (building up and breaking up of kingdoms with wars that give you spoils and might let you lose income).

I think this game is easy to understand and gameplay is simple, but it takes a while if you're AP prone: there are so much options! Only building and with that mechanic collecting points will not be enough to win the game. The conflicts and monuments and treasures are necessary to get a competitive score.

Definitive rated: the game feels very thematic and abstract alike. This is what I want a game to be.

Edit: gave this version away to my parents. They liked their one play of it and we plan a few more in the future... ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yes, I know: I bought a second copy... The new edition, same game. I love the plastic bits (they look really cool), but somehow I like the wooden bits a bit more. Especially the fact that the wooden monuments were evenly divided in colour (the colour missing for the main building was black, only stairs are black), now 3 out of 6 plastic monuments, the main building is black. That's a bit too much black that can alter a bit of the playstyle (black is visually made more important). 

What if FFG would have made the same bits, but then in wood? And what if FFG had kept the same colours of monuments used in all the older versions? And what if FFG would have made the tiles with a qualitative better cardstock? Then I think I would sell my Mayfair copy.

RATING: 8
