At its base an abstract game, but where the theme of developing cities and states in Mesopotamia feels right and not shoehorned on the mechanics. It is a little masterpiece, with chess-like brain burning and long session times for deep thinkers being the principal drawbacks.

RATING: 8
Le berceau de l'humanité
La Mésopotamie, et plus précisément la région bordée par les deux fleuves nourriciers que sont le Tigre et L'Euphrate à été le théâtre du développement des premières civilisations. C'est ce thème que nous propose de revisiter Reiner Knizia, le plus célèbre et prolifique des auteurs allemands, avec son jeu "Euphrat und Tigris" (E&T). L'objectif de chaque joueur est d'accumuler 4 sortes de Points de Victoires (PV) en installant ses propres chefs à la tête des différents royaumes qui vont se constituer et évoluer.

RATING: 9.5
I think this is one of the best boardgames out there. While it's ranked a notch below Puerto Rico on the Geek, I consider it more likely to be played in the XXII-c. as, if nothing else, a representative of the "Euro" craze of the early XXI. It's also uncommon among Euros as actually involving its theme in gameplay; it doesn't feel "pasted on" at all. My girlfriend (who was not a Eurogamer before me) also loves this game. I think, in spite of its depth/complexity, it's quite accessible to the strategically adept non- (or not-yet) gamer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Civilisations blossom and collapse, violently. The game is one of slowly building up your position, carefully sculpting your moment to pounce. Its also about surfing the chaos of your opponents who aim to do the same. 

A volatile game, prone to erupting into chaos as plans go awry. Almost like a card game it has that edge of bluffing and posturing, your position is never quite safe, but they don’t know where you are weak, and vice versa for them. Yet despite the volatility there is a strong core that keeps the game from descending into the roll of a dice. The scoring (you score 1 for every complete set, aka your score is the colour you are weakest in) means that the game remains tense even after your little civilisation was thrown into disarray, your leaders exiled, your plans wrecked. You can come back by making the necessary sacrifices, feeding points to players who no longer need that colour, then throw down in a wild gambit to pull yourself back in contention. Another strength of the game are the many nuances of the positional play - for the first few games it is easily lost on a player that while where you place and what can at times seem insignificant, it is anything but. Bad placements will haunt you, weaken you and take away the edge you need to win.

So you have the recipe for a very tense game and this tension builds in waves, because it is unavoidable that conflicts will erupt at some point. Not only because the board shrinks but because wars and monuments are the only way you can go beyond what is otherwise a maximum scoring potential of 2 points per turn (aka potentially half a point at best). As for theme, well, history unfolds itself on the board, delivering a far more thematic game than even the most chrome-laden comparison. 

In short I really enjoy this game, its not an obvious game and can take a bit getting into and understanding the “hows” and “whys”, but this is a game you can play and do clever things in - or see other players do clever things, and what emerges will be different every game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With the "right" people, this is an awesome game.  Brilliant, stunning and wonderful.  With the "wrong" people, you will only get glazed stares and soon-empty  chairs.  The view from the top is magnificent, but the climb up is a tough one.  "Weaker" rating due simply to entry barrier.

RATING: 8.5
The rules are easy to learn (although not necessarily easy to teach), imo, and the depth is perfect. I think the ebb and flow of the game fits perfectly with the theme. I can't wait to really play this game. Have only played a few times due to lack of players.
Update 8/7/2007: It's a pretty solid game. The game has lost some of its luster now that I've played a few online games. It's a really good game, but I prefer to play it in its board form.

Update 5 October 2008: Keeping it at an 8.5 as I really enjoy the game, but for some reason I have trouble keeping the rules straight (contrary to my original entry in which I played more regularly). I've played another 4-player game and it seems pretty chaotic. The winner is usually surprised and can't really explain her path to victory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Bought the Tigris & Euphrates version. Not sure if they are different. Even though I have only played online.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Game in a Nutshell: Abstract tile-laying game of leaders and their kingdoms. All your leaders need support from tiles of the same color because you never know when an opponents leader might come looking for trouble and tear your status in the game apart as you know it.

Played as: 2 (Nile map on BGG),3,4 player

Pros: My current favorite, and it's definitely not because I always win; I rarely do. Luck is the mother of all variety but rarely decides the winner. Many important choices and never enough moves makes every turn feel like the game is in the balance. Requires a fair amount of creativity to stay in the game when you're not dealt the hand you'd hoped for; best of all this game gives you the freedom to do just that.

Cons: The rules never seem to be easily grasped due to the fact it's just a masked abstract. Part of the game's biggest problem is tied to its greatest strength: The openness of how you can affect the board with your turn. This creates the opportunity for some un-appreciated player-imposed chaos whether from a newer player or even a more experienced one who figures he's mathematically eliminated from the game and just wants to stir s*** up. Not a game I'd play two player as I find that the person who comes out on top in the first mash-up tends be at a huge advantage from that point on. 

Other: Takes one game to grasp the rules, at least three to realize potential strategy, and I don't know how long to "master" it (I'm nowhere close). That said, it's funny how experience was never essential for my enjoyment. My experience has shown that it's not a game for non-confrontational gamers. 

Best Use: When it's game night and the non-confrontational players are too tired or busy.

RATING: 8
Recently totally revisited this game with fresh eyes after years of it sitting unplayed. It is a brilliant, well designed, tense game with a set of in your face simple, straightforward mechanics that require you to think through every turn. Every game plays differently. This isn't a friendly tile laying game - there will be conflict. The key is setting up your monuments and defenses against both internal and external attack. I won't say it is as elegant a blend of game and theme as something like Sekigahara, but it is a brilliant, thematic game for strategists and newer players alike - just don't let them play together.

PL
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow, is this a great game.  Currently I have this ranked #2 in my top 10.  I tend to like games with little to no luck, and this game provides exactly that.

In Tigris & Euphrate(T&E) everybody is trying to make the support for their leaders grow in the kingdoms on the board.  Each player starts with one leader in each color (4 total), and six random supporter tiles (4 different colors to match the leaders).  Players are given two actions per turn in which they can move around their leaders, add, tiles, or put down a destroying catastrophe tile.  As you play tiles in a kingdom (a group of tiles with at least one leader), cubes are given to the leader in that kingdom of the same color.

Everything goes great and everybody is happy until two leaders of the same color come together in the same kingdom.  This can happen in one of two ways.  The first is an internal conflict.  This happens when one player adds their leader to a kingdom that already has a leader of that color.  In this case the conflict is decided based on the temples (red tiles) that the leader is touching, plus any temples the player has in their 6 random tiles hidden behind their screen.  The loser (ties go to the defender) must remove their leader and the winner gets a red cube for their efforts.  The second is an external conflict.  This occurs when a tile joins up two kingdoms and their are leaders of a given color in both the two joining kingdoms.  In this case the conflict is settled based on the number of supporters (tiles of the same color) that are in your kingdom, plus tiles of that color you choose to use from behind your screen.  The loser removes their leader and every supporter from their kingdom.  The winner gets a cube for every piece removed.  This can really shake things up.

I love this game because there is so much strategy involved.  Sure when you draw to bring your tiles back up to 6 it is all random, but there are ways to improve your luck, and that isn't the main part of the game.  Like all strategy heavy games, this game suffers from new players making bad moves that help some other player out, so it is best to play this with people at the same skill level.  I only teach this to a group of people if I expect to get several plays out of it with that group.

I give this game a 9 because it is about as close to perfection in a game as I have ever seen.  It doesn't play too long, assuming there isn't a lot of AP going on, and the decisions each turn offer a lot of depth.  If you like games with a lot of luck, this one definitely isn't for you.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::star::star::star::halfstar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::star::star::star::halfstar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::star::star::star::star: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::star::star::star: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 3-4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic game!

A classic tile laying game (and one of the earliest eurogames that I recall playing) that rewards both strategic planning and sharp tactical plays.

Probably the deepest and most challenging game in Knizia's Tile Laying Trilogy and the best imo.

Plays can be quite devastating and nasty, thereby rewarding smart and aggressive moves.

-------------------------------

Disappointed by the FFG 2015 edition for the following reasons:

- plastic monuments and player leaders don't handle as nicely or look as good as the wooden pieces used in the Mayfair or HiG edition.

- cardboard tokens used by FFG instead of the wooden cubes in prior editions are less visible (treasures on game board) and more difficult to handle. 

Map board art and tile artwork is OK, but it is subjective and a matter of taste as to which is better.  Glad I held onto my Mayfair 2008 edition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Played twice, with four players each time.  This is an area control game that has many unique mechanics, all of which add up to an amazingly complex, extremely tactical game that is loads of fun to play.  Players are highly restricted in the number of moves they can make (two per turn), and have only six tiles (which are used both to place on the board and to fight battles) in front of them, making each turn an exercise in precision.  Players have four different leaders they can place on the board in "empires" (sets of contiguous tiles with a leader in them); when "empires" are combined, or when two of the same type of leaders are put into an "empire", battle ensues.  The ability to connect, and disconnect, empires adds a huge amount of complexity to the map, and the hidden scores make one think that one is losing throughout the entire game.  

This does seem like it would require the right type of player: you've got to have thick skin (as you will get destroyed at some point), be extremely flexible, and willing to think through lots of possible moves on a turn to see what would benefit you the most (and benefit others the least).  

It took me two years after my first play to get in my second play; I hope my third play comes much quicker.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a real classic. The theme is completely pasted on but if you take this one for what it is, it really is amazing. The tactical choices are endless. A 4 player abstract that's full of conflict.

Doesn't seem to get a lot of table time with my group. It does lack the "excitement" factor but a good game, none the less.

RATING: 9.65
Changed rating from 9.0 to 9.65 on 4/27/16 because having played this multiple times now, this game is FANTASTIC.

This classic game, rendered even more gorgeous by the reprint with its gorgeous art and chunky plastic pieces, is almost too good.  You get that classic "build an engine and watch it run" mechanic but most importantly - you build up into other people's cities and  then the fighting begins... and "control" of the economic engines of the game can and will change hands multiple times.

If you're looking for a classic game that is easy to learn and play but hard to master, this may be the game for you.

(Written 4/27/16)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've seen other reviewers say that Tigris & Euphrates feels almost like a rediscovered game from the ancient world, one of those games that has persisted through history (much like Chess or Go). I'd tend to agree with that sentiment; the game just feels timeless.

I find Tigris to be an extremely creative and fluid game, not at all the dry abstract it's sometimes painted as being. It’s got a wonderful “life” to it that is almost purely based on the interactions of the players. I like watching how the board state changes over the course of the game; it very much reminds me of a time-lapse of civilizations rising and falling. So, though the game is certainly abstracted, for me it's not completely lacking in theme. Finally, on the randomness of the tile draw, this has never bothered me. It makes the game more tactical, and I enjoy the challenge of working with what I'm given. That said, the game provides options for mitigating tile draw either by taking the discard and refresh action or even by starting a conflict simply to use several tiles you don't really need for board position.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Downgrading this game, which saddens me just a bit seeing as I was the WBC Tigris champion one year :/.

The game is simply too tactical for my taste. I have done very well over the years waiting until my turn to come, computing the most advantageous move given the existing board situation, and letting the chips fall where they may.

That's not to say the game isn't fun at all, it's just not one that I would readily recommend on a random gaming night. A nicely calibrated '5', which is exactly in the middle for me.

RATING: 2
I have played several unregistered online games of this to get a feel as to if it was something I'd be interested in. The answer, unequivocally, is no. The actions feel meaningless, the level of abstraction is so high it could just as easily be themed with types of offal floating in a sewer as it could be ancient provinces vying for control of a kingdom, the tile draws add chaos without the game providing any way for the players to control or funnel the chaos, the rules are overly complex, and there are exceptions and exceptions to the exceptions. COMPLEXITY does not equal DEPTH!!!

Another piece of Eurotrash that needs to be punched in the face.

RATING: 9
Superb game that, when played right, is all about dramatic conflicts. I'm glad to have acquired this one off recommendations of Geek Buddies (not to mention a stellar rating here on BGG). It's a keeper.

A couple of its initial advantages have proven to be illusory: it's not as intuitive for many people as it was for me, making learning games somewhat excruciating (i.e., In Brass, I can understand why people don't get it at first. Here, seriously, you still don't get external conflicts?), and the two player game is weak (though I've yet to try the Nile board). The game becomes undeniably dull if someone musters a sizable lead and then crushes an attack or two; I've been on both sides of this situation and am glad one of those games wasn't my first.

UPDATE 1: I was momentarily little worried that successful play is a tad scripted, but was proven wrong on my very next game.

UPDATE 2: Nearly 30 games in, and this game is still blowing my mind. This might have to go to 10, or maybe become my only 9.

Második kapudrog volt nekem: a Zooloretto megvétele után kezdtem keresni, hogy milyen társasjátékok vannak Androidra, így akadtam bele Knizia régi, de szerintem legjobb társasába. Amikor felbukkant egy használt verzió, le is csaptam rá.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The simplicity and originality of the rules and gameplay, versus the complexity of the strategy and tactics, are remarkable. I feel that more should have been done to avoid the sense that there's a distinct first-player advantage.... but otherwise I wouldn't change a thing. I love the natural way that alliances emerge in this game in a way that's totally unlike any other abstract game--much more like a social deduction or bluffing game. It's usually best to hitch some of your leaders to other players' empires to make the cost/benefit ratio of two empires attacking each other more complex: this discourages mindless assaults and encourages more machiavellian play. An older game that holds up beautifully.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Upgraded my score to 7.5 after playing on the iPad about 6 times. 

T&E has lots of tactical choices to seize scoring opportunities and build up offensive and defensive positions. The game starts out a bit like chess with usually predictable opening moves. As the game map develops the tensions ramps us with conflicts breaking out and players poring over ways to make their hand of tiles work on the map to disrupt their opponent's scoring base (eg monuments). The mid and end game are where all the fun is at and T&E gets there pretty quickly with experienced players. There isn't much long term planning required, more short term planning of tile play.

T&E's counterintuitive rules about external and internal conflict and the scoring around leaders rather than territories make T&E a tough learning curve for novices. It really takes 4-5 games for T&E to shine through. Also, players need to initiate combat and break up high scoring turtling players, so gamers who don't like conflict want a game of applying vengeance won't like T&E. In short, T&E isn't for newbies who don't like war-like games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Still, this is a great game...

RATING: 7
I gave this game a ton of chances before I finally grew to enjoy it, and even then I'm not sure if it's a game I think is all that great. There is a lot of underlying depth for a game where I would describe the rules as medium-weight. There are a couple of quirky things to remember, but nothing too bad. This is one of those games that really requires you to play it many, many times before you start to uncover what it's trying to accomplish. Right now, I'm finding that conflicts can sometimes be a bit too swingy for my tastes, and as such, it's very difficult to gauge who's winning. Overall I like this game, but it's one I like playing in short bursts. Bad losses in this game can really sour my mood. For some reason I still own it though. I wouldn't count it among my favorite games, but there's something about it that makes me want to keep it around.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Tigris & Euphrates must be the perfect game. Here is an element of go, where you place tiles to create kingdoms and score points from them. Here is an element of chess, where you maneuver your pieces for attack and/or defence. Here is an element of the classic civilization building, where you improve your kingdom through monuments and buildings.

However, this is not a peaceful game without player interaction. Conflicts come in two interesting shapes. In internal conflicts you plant your dynasty members in your opponents' kingdoms with the objective of overthrowing them and reap the benefits for yourself. In external conflicts the clashes of expanding borders may form one stronger kingdom for a winner or leave the two kingdoms weaker after the fierce strife.

But it does not end there. There is no such thing as "your" kingdom, they are only there to serve your dynasty's interests (i.e. generate victory points) and may (should!) be abandoned when they no longer serve any purpose.

Finally, in this chaos of rising and falling civilizations you need to find a balanced growth because it is not your strongest area that awards you the victory, it is your weakest area. The game is simple but the depth of the gameplay is immense.

Reviewed at https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1224187/tigris-euphrates-perfect-game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Tigris & Euphrates.  Played 5/13/2006 (4 players, 2 hours);  8/25/2006 (3 players);  5-11-2007 (4 players, 2 hours, 19 minutes)

RATING: 10
So here it is, the first 10 in my collection.  This is the kind of game I dream about (no, really) and the type of game my thoughts keep returning to time after time.  Although the rules could be better explained, the mechanics are simple - you take your choice twice and take the points.  From this humble ruleset, however, empires rise and fall, and conflicts can turn the board into a ruined landscape, and I haven't even mentioned the scoring yet, which ensures that you never know really if or how far you might be ahead.

Awesome, truly awesome.  Everybody should play this at least once, and most should own a copy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
On a l'impression que tous les coups se valent, et pourtant, il n'en est rien!

On a l'impression que tout est pareil, et pourtant, tout n'est qu'asymétrie!

On peut au premier abord trouver le jeu très austère, et pourtant, chaque action laisse place au suspens!...

Ce jeu requiert de bien planifier et de bien choisir où, quand et dans quelle séquence positionner ses chefs et "ses" tuiles, de manière à se rendre le moins vulnérable possible face à d'éventuels conflits. Comme il existe deux types de conflits, il est indispensable de faire un bon usage de toutes nos tuiles, et particulièrement des rouges. 

Le paradoxe est vite créé: Encercler ses chefs de tuiles rouges augmente leur défense en situation de conflit interne; mais: 1) moins de tuiles rouges en main complique les tentatives d'initier soi-même ces conflits; 2) négliger de poser des tuiles de la même couleur que son chef le rend vulnérable face à un conflit externe; 3) conséquemment, laisser derrière soi une case "forte" (entourée de tuiles rouges) suite à une défaite en conflit externe laisse cette "case forte" disponible pour un chef adverse!...

Ce jeu arrime combativité et complicité. Ne l'oublions pas, tous nos chefs ne se battent pas contre tous les chefs de l'adversaire! Il est tout à fait possible de cohabiter avec des chefs adverses, du moment qu'ils ne partagent pas la même couleur! Mais bien sûr, lorsque plusieurs joueurs dessinent simultanément l'expansion d'un royaume, cette expansion ne prend pas la forme et ne va pas systématiquement dans la direction souhaitées!

Attention, les territoires ne sont jamais acquis! Nous travaillons à obtenir le contrôle, puis maintenir notre contrôle de zones et de royaumes; mais un royaume n'est JAMAIS à soi pour de bon - ou du moins, durant la partie, on ne peut en être certain! Il faut être créatif et il faut tenir compte de l'ENSEMBLE du plateau de jeu!

N'ayez pas peur de "concéder" une couleur à tel joueur, et telle couleur à un autre joueur. L'idée n'est pas d'avoir le pointage le plus élevé dans TOUTES les couleurs! Laissons l'orgueil de côté! Il n'y a aucun mal à ce qu'un adversaire obtienne un pointage très élevé dans une ou deux couleurs...

À partir du 2/3 de la partie, il faut principalement se concentrer sur les couleurs faibles de chaque joueur. Obtenir des points, ou empêcher l'adversaire d'en faire de même, il faut parfois alterner la stratégie s'il n'est pas possible de faire les deux en même temps!

La position finale importe peu, car nous pouvons avoir nos quatre chefs en dehors du jeu, mais néanmoins gagner! L'important est la couleur de nos points! D'ailleurs, il n'est pas interdit de volontairement prendre du retard dans l'une d'elle dans la première moitié de la partie. Dans une bonne position, il est plus facile d'augmenter qu'un seul pointage faible plutôt que plusieurs! Alors tant pis si on ne pige jamais de tuiles vertes! On planifie en conséquence, on essaie de construire un monument vert même s'il n'est pas immédiatement sous notre contrôle, et on aura tôt ou tard l'occasion d'augmenter cette couleur faible (conflits, catastrophes...)

Un jeu totalement différent à deux, trois ou quatre joueurs, et quelque peu sadique à plusieurs, car la stratégie commande parfois de s'attaquer au plus faible plutôt qu'au plus fort.

Bref, ce jeu mérite d'être joué et rejoué, car, avouons-le, la toute première partie est totalement déroutante!

note: Je préfère de beaucoup la seconde carte (14 trésors) de la deuxième édition. On tombe moins dans la course aux trésors.

À deux joueurs ou trois joueurs: 10/10 si les joueurs ont une expérience relativement équivalente;
À quatre joueurs: 8/10: le jeu est alors plus spectaculaire mais à la fois un peu moins stratégique et un peu trop court...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This game is sorta like Chess with four players, but alot more fun.  A true classic brainbuster that is fun to play and simple enough to teach.  Very deep game in terms of strategy and knowing how to place leaders and use combat to your advantage to score trading/religion/settlement/farming points in the most balanced manner.  Just the right mix of luck, which is relatively low and manageable due to ability to cycle tiles.

RATING: 8
The more that I play this game, the more that I appreciate it.  It packs a lot of strategy and conflict in a surprisingly short game, and I really like the way the best of the worst scoring system affects your play.  I also enjoy the assymetry to the game, and the fact that the gameboard has better locations and worse locations.  Finally, the fact that this game is still fairly opaque to me definitely intrigues me.

It doesn't scale that well across its player range, as is often the case with games like these, but that is a minor complaint for a great game.  A stronger theme would probably be a good thing, but I'm happy with the game exactly as it is.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Area influence/tile placement game from Knizia. Lay tiles and leaders from your country to score points, but conflicts can occur within your own kingdom or with other kingdoms. Score is the minimum of your earned points in the four colors. This is Knizia's first game I played in March 1998. Since then, I have been playing his designs. Good solid game, unique scoring system. Some battles near the end can have a decisive impact on the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.3
[b]Tigris & Euphrates[/b] by the prolific game designer [person=2][/person]
2-4 players

Strategic abstract with the following mechanics:

Area Control / Area Influence
Hand Management
Set Collection
Tile Placement

Have played 2 and 3 player. Wondering how it is with 4. Really like how you don't know who is leading the game till the very end due to the hidden scoring mechanism. I have found that this mechanism  keeps my gf from getting angry with me during game play!

Some claim there is [i]luck[/i] in this game, particularly involving the tile draw. However, the more experienced players are claiming that skill will trump this random factor. I suppose it is similar as in card play: one must know what to do with the cards dealt to him.

Wish I could play this game more.

Question that needs answering with 3-player: is there a Kingmaker problem here?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Let me start with: This is a complex game. 
That said, once you have the basics down, the variety of ways to play are simply astounding. Aggressive, defensive, isolationalist, wow. And the game can change so quickly. Link up regions in the wrong order or settle conflicts without enough planning and your "sure win" can crumble before you. 

And I especially like that your smallest resource determines your placing; you can go all out and have a stack of Green cubes but if you let your Blue ones fall behind, you're hosed. You have to balance all aspects to have a chance to win. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Top tier Knizia game, second only to the much lesser-known Rheinlander for me.  I don't think the abstractness is any more prevalent than in most of his other titles.  The "most of the least" victory condition is something I love because it forces players to digest the game in its entirety.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A very involving tile laying game, with far more accessible gameplay than the rulebook would lead you to believe. However, while the basic mechanics might be accessible, the choices involved can be some of the most enjoyably agonising of any game I've played. It also includes probably my favorite methods of victory point scoring in any such game to date.

However, for some reason I have trouble getting it to the table. While I do like it, I find that other games more closely tied to their themes, or less abstracted overall, are my first suggestions. And it just seems too oblique or too reliant on those agonising choices to be inflicted upon non-gamers. As such the score has fallen more than I'd like, but I barely ever play it. A pity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is my personal perception of the game, which, I suppose, we are all entitled too. The game's artwork is magnificent and the quality of the components superb, but as usual Knizia designs game mechanics to show off his mathematical genius. Everything is abstracted to the level of a shape-recognition IQ test, with all theme being thoroughly dessicated. Playing many Knizia games is like drawing a tattoo on oneself while watching your movements through the mirror.

There is clearly a nice game in there, but it is too clinical for me.

RATING: 10
I purchased this in mid Dec 2005.

Wow . . . a new favorite.  Easily in the top three.  I do think the game finishes a little too fast, as one can't really deploy long term strategies all that well (i.e. amassing tiles of a certain color, detrenching a strong ruler through consistenly clever temple play followed by internal conflict).  The problem is that one doesn't score while planning such longer attacks, while the target leader can score the color and not care (because he has already scored enough) that he is eventually unseated.  This makes me want to be less aggressive in my play, yet you'll lose if you don't win a few external conflicts, because you just can get VP's as quickly through tile placement as you can through well planned attacks.

Anyway, there's a lot more to this game than I can get in a play or two, so . . . until then, I'll end with very high praise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After a few plays I had to upgrade this one from a 7. It gets more fun the more I play. Playtime that runs right around an hour, even with relatively inexperienced players, is a huge selling point for me.
***
12-10-07: I've only played this once when I didn't love it, and I'm always looking for an excuse to play. Moved from 8 to 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Tigris & Euphrates is a good game, and one that I'd be willing to play pretty much anytime. It has unique mechanics that make for interesting play. But I will never own it. Why? Because I can't actually describe the game effectively to someone who has never played it. Its just so abstract and strange and a real brain-burner to boot. As such, none of my friends would be interested in playing, so there is no point in buying it. Still, T&E is a classic, just not for everyone.

A final note: To satisfy my craving for more of the game, I bought the app from the iTunes store. I still can't explain T&E, but now I have some bots to play against and I've a better understanding of the game.

The emergent dynamics of this game from a simple and unique ruleset are fascinating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have seen this game referred to as "an experience", and I would agree. It has the perfect balance of strategy and chance for my taste, and every action in the game provides satisfying feedback. I love how it manages to be simultaneously intense and relaxing. The only thing that could make it better is a finely crafted wooden playset.

Some of my feelings "I've been playing some Tigris & Euphrates; I've really fallen in love with it. I'm a sucker for hand management games, and this one takes that mechanic, which is usually a hard, grubby little thing--like a fig--and makes it broad, airy, and spreadable, like fig pudding. Both the scoring of actual points (through the beautiful leader tokens) and the way you compare them (highest of the lowest color wins) are ingenious (and also similar to Ingenious, which I haven't played). I'll be playing this game for a long time."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Widely regarded as Knizia's summit - a feisty, rich game that leaves lots of room for strategy, tactics and interaction. Euphrat & Tigris would stand higher if it wasn't for the luck of the draw, kingmaking issues and the enormous difficulty to catch up with a player once they leads the game: there's often a plan B, but it must be spotted quickly and even then getting the wrong tiles can sometimes be really painful. Lacking red tiles for several rounds means your game is pretty much doomed to failure... and it can still take some time until it ends).

Euphrat & Tigris can be enjoyed by players of similar level; if there are less experienced players they will most probably learn through 90 minutes of relentless tough love try after try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Un Knizia. Molto profondo e cerebrale dalla meccanica tutto sommato semplice anche se non immediata. Adeguata anche la durata del gioco non molto lunga (anzi potrebbe finire troppo presto). Il calcolo alternativo del punteggio finale per decidere i punti vittoria ricorda Himalaya ma soprattutto Samurai (altro gioco di Knizia), ma nel complesso Tigris & Euphrates risulta molto più articolato e gratificante. La grafica non è molto coinvolgente e l'ambientazione è praticamente assente. Alternativa l'idea di attribuire 'le pedine' di ogni giocatore non in base ai classici colori ma al differente logo (alle prime partite questa differenza potrebbe infastidire). Esiste un gioco di carte che cerca di emularlo, sempre di Knizia, ma soprattutto esiste la versione tedesca, praticamente identica visto che il gioco è indipendente dalla lingua, che però si chiama Euphrates & Tigris e costa molto meno.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Each player builds 4 parallel empires and scores the worst one. Conflicts occur when 2 leaders of the same type occur in one empire or when 2 empires come in contact. Due to the scoring mechanism, the most aggressive player isn't necessarily the winner. 

The play is deep, but the rules are relatively simple.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
Wow. So many options. So much to do. So much freedom! I love being spared from the tight restraints of other big-box classics, and there are shadows of Go in the simple rules propagating so many choices. I expect it will take a bunch of plays to understand the nuances of this game, and thankfully I can't really get enough of it. Hard to get to the table for some reason, though.

RATING: 10
Deep, deep game. I do like these games that give you limitless options on a turn, but it can get overwhelming. At least it gives you some direction with the starting tiles, your hand, and the rivers--otherwise I'd be as lost as I am when I play Go.

The depth of strategy in choosing when to start conflicts, which to resolve first, how to build your civilizations, where to place your support tiles, when to use disasters, and how best to exploit opponents' unstable civs is insane. Brilliant game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I know I'm late to this party, but MAN is this a good game! This is the best "abstract" war game, disguised as a tile-laying euro, I've ever seen.

The way the player's pieces works is a little counter-intuitive at first, as are the different ways to fight with other players, but eventually it becomes second nature.

The fact that "diagonal doesn't count" in this game, really makes it better...AND worse in a lot of instances.

Never has so much been done before with just a mere four shapes and colors.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For a game that is relatively straight forward, the first couple of plays, especially learning to play from the rules are really confusing when it shouldn't be.

Now I've played a few times I think this is a real winner.  It plays rather gamey like chess and plays well 2-4.  

Lots of difficult and tricky decisions.  It's great to bait an opponent into challenging you when you have a large amount of that colour tiles behind your screen.

I can see myself playing this a lot in the future.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]Tigris and Euphrates[/b] was traded away for Among the Stars and Qwixx 12/18/14.

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]I still think this is an amazing game and hopefully I will get to play it more. This is definitely a game that requires repeated play in order to start to pick up all the nuances of game play. As is often joked about, this has been a game I've brought to meet ups and it's usually ignored. I was hoping with the reprint that there would be some renewed interest, but so far I haven't seen it. 

I am glad to have played this classic game, it provides a lot of insight into modern board game design and in my opinion is a must play game.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (9):[/COLOR]

[i]Absolutely loved my first play of this with my family. 
It only took one play to realize why this game is considered a classic. 

- Brilliant scoring system; you need to make sure that you are scoring points consistently in all four colors.
- Love the interaction between the leaders, there is only conflict if two of the same type of leader are in the same territory.
- Two types of conflict (revolution versus war) which are both caused/resolved using different tiles.
- Accessible to my older kids (9 and 12), but they have played a lot of other games.
- I am one of those people that find this game thematic (even though you are collecting colored cubes for vp). I thing it is interesting to watch the territories grow and expand and then splinter off into different territories. The monuments make thematic sense, they are the artistic pinnacle of each civilization. 
Granted everything takes place on a very macro level, but I think the civilization building theme makes sense.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Xadrez temperado! Minhas regras rápidas: http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/70818/regras-rapidas-v1-1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Sweet game!  Learned face-to-face at a game group.  I then read the awesome annotated Tigris and Euphrates geeklists and learned a lot.  I have since played a few email games here on the site.  The design of the game is almost perfect.  I still plain out enjoy RRT more, but that's in spite of some hinks and flaws in the game design.  

I originally felt a little lost playing T&E--the longterm view of what might happen was so hard to get my mind around, that many of my moves felt random or completely tactical.  It's like Chess at first until you develop a sense of your whole side interconnected instead of a bunch of individual pieces.  I thought that lost feeling would be more of a barrier to getting my group to play, but some on my wife's side of the family have really taken to it now.  

I love how many possibilities and clever moves exist.  The game can constantly swing in unexpected directions and there's always a little bit of tension as someone can drop an internal conflict at any time with a lucky red draw.  I love this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Like most of Kinizia's games, the scoring mechanic is wonderful.  I think that this works best in T&E and Samurai.  Here you determine winner by comparing the volume of cubes in your *weakest* color.

While I have the German Edition, would love to have a back-up copy (if my tiles were ever damaged I would cry as the USA edition is not even close in quality of game pieces).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Very strong strategic/tactical game. Difficult to win, many options possible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I recommend 2 players and that the game is seen as a very good replacement over playing chess. If played properly, one will be spending substancial ammounts of time thinking about all the different option, what their consequences will be and what will the other player(s) be able to do next.

3~4 players will mean lots of time waiting for your turn and, with so many players, you can't really spend that time preparing your turn since alot will change in the mean time.

If played 3~4 players in a not-so-much-thought way, though, i guess it will be a less brutal struggle between 2 players and it will flow decently...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I didn't expect to like this game as much as I did (it's a game of math and strategy which are not my strong suits) but I managed to push past it and really dive into the game. I knew it was a reprint of a nearly twenty-year old game when designers were just learning to not rely on dice or cards; I was skeptical of it keeping my attention beyond the third turn. But I was wrong. While not exactly "fun", "exciting" or "tense," I was never bored or uninterested in other player's turns. I can imagine that in 3 or 4 player games, AP is multiplied but between Paulo and I, it was never an issue. I really like the scoring mechanic of only scoring the resource you have the LEAST amount of; it makes you reevaluate your strategy every turn and try new things. While not as thematic or fun for your basic Euro, Tigris & Euphrates's strategy runs deep. I'll play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very, very strategical game - much like chess or go. Strong historical background and feeling. Still, i feel that something is missing - i couldn't feel thrilled when playing it.

RATING: 8.5
Наверное это лучшая игра в которую мне удалось сыграть в этом году. Действительно замечательная игра для Книзия. Каркассон теперь убит на нашем настольном столе. Суперстратегический, многоходовый пазл про жизнь древних шумеров, неплохо сбалансированный и для двух игроков. После игры остается ощущение не зря потраченного времени и в голове все еще прокручиваются возможные выигрышные комбинации. В общем всем любителям полу-абстрактных, умных игр рекомендовано к ознакомлению. Удручает качество русской локализации - картонные крашенные огрызки и отсутствие монументов. Но игра все равно классная. Покупайте сразу немецкую версию.

RATING: 9
50+ plays. A classic gamer game that has stood the test of time and maintains lasting appeal. There's early establishment, then comes the drama of the wars which can dramatically alter the landscape and provide rich opportunities for clever moves. The need to obtain a balanced score across the 4 colours drives decisions, and means sometimes seemingly obvious moves are not the best ones, making for surprise. Excellent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
What I like:
- It is a very well designed game
- The rules really are relatively simple, for such a deep game

What I don't like:
- Shared ownership
- Lots of conflict
- Brain-burner
- Not enough red tiles
- Having players be shapes, not colors, is disorienting
- You have to think outside the box to find the really creative (sometimes counter-intuitive) moves

I didn't hate it as much as I thought I might. Our 3p learning game only took 100 minutes, which wasn't bad at all. The end game dragged a bit. As expected, I didn't like the shared ownership, nor the constant conflict. Basically, it's not a style of game I like.

The weight of 3.6 really reflects the depth, not the rules complexity. I would give the rules complexity about a 2.5.

RATING: 7
I have only played this once, and I think we didn't have it quite sorted out about the conflicts. Since my aunt was relying heavily on the "conflict" strategy to win, I didn't like that at the moment. But I believe in a subsequent game on another day when I wasn't playing, our regulars worked out the finer details of waging conflicts. So next time around, that will hopefully be clearer....one thing that frustrates me is when we can't come to a consensus about what the rules mean. You end up spending more time arguing about the rules and what they mean, and trying to convince each other of your opinions, and less time playing the game. 

But, other than that...I enjoyed the theme, and I thought that the fact that you were ranked according to your weakest color, thereby forcing you to try to balance the different areas, was a very COOL mechanism. So I'd definitely want to give this another go.

RATING: 9

I can’t understand why this hasn’t been reprinted recently.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Once you get your head around how the conflicts work, this game really has a very simple ruleset. But I do not think anyone will ever completely explore all the depth this game has to offer. There is plenty of room for devious and clever play and Knizia seems to have purposely left out unnecessary chrome that would have bloated the game.  As is, this is a classic game that requires a high level of thought and skill to play well despite the relatively simple rule set.   True, some do complain about the randomness of the tile draw, but games are rarely decided by this.  Good players are able to use their precious actions and the hands they are dealt to make other players miserable (in a good way of course).  There are also complaints that the any theme is completely pasted on.  But that is rubbish.  When you start a war between your opponents, watch their kingdoms become fractured ruins, and you rush in to plunder what is left behind, THAT is theme.   A genuine masterpiece and a classic.

RATING: 10
Tigris & Euphrates is not as complicated as you might think from reading about it.  Unfathomably deep is more like it.  One needs to try to deduce likely outcomes if kingdoms collide.  [i]Just how might this kingdom break apart[/i] is the key question.

BTW, this is a highly thematic game!  See my geeklist: Thoughts on Theme and Knizia: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/24687/
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I'm not as high on this game as many people, but I do find it enjoyable.  It has a lot more conflict than most Euros, but is way, way more abstract than most conflict-driven games.  There are some luck issues with tile draws, but I'm not sure how big of a deal that is.  The major appeal of the game is being able to do something both clever and game-changing, and you might spend your entire game trying to come up with such a move.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Yes, it's a 10. Perfect game. Albeit, not for everyone as it's somewhat abstract. I've played scores of games on the Geek, and 3-4 face to face. I love this game. Geekbuddies rate it a 7.6. 

10/6/12: I have almost played this game out, but only it's online versions. First it was on BGG, now on iOS. Lowering to a 9 to be true to my current feelings. Still awesome, some of its limitations are now becoming apparent to me after 100 plays: 1. Dry theme does not appeal to any face to face opponents in my circle making it extremely difficult to get to table. 2. Very difficult to catch up to the leader. 3. Experienced players will generally destroy new people - it would take 10  games to really even begin to challenge a couple if veterans. 4. Very easy for a new player to throw the game out of whack by boneheaded plays. 

I have just reached the point where I've almost played this out. 

Still an amazing game and the arc of play and learning was one of the best game experiences I've had. I recommend everyone try this, and savor it.

Oct 2014: I have played a ton of games on the iOS App, and easily more than 50 on the BGG app when it was up. There seems to be very little interest in this game in my gaming groups - it's what I would call a "heavy German-style" game today, and my friends are pretty stuck on Agricola, Power Grid, Pandemic, Innovation/Uchronia/Impulse, Star Realms, and Chess. I don't see the core list changing much, a few new games will be tried now and then. The trend seems to be towards shorter and lighter games these days.

Playtime: ~60-90 minutes

Comment: Love the game but just can't get it to the table. People in my group really dislike this game for some reason. Its got plenty of tension, conflict, theme and a reasonable play time. Honestly one of my favorite games. It gets deeper with more plays and really needs to be played continually to sink your teeth into it. Rules are a bit confusing and hard to explain but the game is actually really simple.

RATING: 8
My score got increasing on and on by playing on BGG: at first it seemed slow, complex, pointless. It seemed there was no way to understand when to put a tile and when to keep it in a hand. Now I feel that it's great, although still very luck-dependant. There are many possible strategies and they depend from your cards but also from your personal mood and opponents' behaviour, making strategic like a wargame without the complexity and coldness of it. Everyone should try it here on BGG.
One note about a under-stimated rule: the fact of changing up to 6 tiles when is needed reduces randomness (although it's still heavy) and increases strategy.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Increased the rating to 10 once I played the digital version against the AI. It is a little difficult to grasp some of the concepts until you see them in action from an experienced player. For instance, all of the following points were lost on me during my first 15 plays of this game:
  - The depth of the warfare scoring aspect as a catch-up mechanism is superbly done. 

  - The monument mechanism as a double-edged sword (creating one making you more vulnerable to warfare, but a rewarding point catch-up mechanism) is well done. 

   -The vulnerability to revolt that comes with playing red tiles, and thus the strategy in blocking them off and using them sparingly is well done.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A combination of Knizia and tiles cannot go wrong.
Somehow this game assumes that everyone will harass each other and prevent from expanding.
The problem occurs if some want to build their kingdom in peace and others are too busy to spare their leaders there.

RATING: 10
Wow! Just an amazing game! Sometimes the "bad" tile draws force a player into a specific strategy.  If the player doesn't play to the unlikely tile draws , they'll say the game is too luck based because they didn't get what they think they should have.I view it as the player needs to adapt to the situation.  The luck may decide a game here and there when someone on defense pulls 5 black tiles from thier hand to win a key external war, but better tactics will still win most of the games.

RATING: 8
A very [b]abstract strategical wargame[/b] that has managed to transform [i]diplomacy[/i] and [i]politics[/i] into [b]tile placement[/b] in the ancient world. There's almost always a [u]sacrifice[/u] in all the [i]good[/i] moves and the cynic pacifist in me loves the fact that the [i]best[/i] way to win is to make the [i]other players[/i] fight among themselves and then finish by grabbing the spoils of war. Still, you have to remember that it is very [u]abstract[/u] and you shouldn't dive into this expecting a real wargame.

RATING: 9.5
Update 6/16/10: having played it about 9 times now, I have come to really love this game.  It's elegantly simple, yet there are nearly infinite possible strategies and tactics to try.  The rise and fall of civilization is so beautifully recreated in abstraction.

Original 2009 comment:  This one is a head trip.  It is so hard not to think of an area as "mine" and realize you can put your pieces anywhere.  I also love that you have no idea how well your opponent may be doing. RATING: 10
(25+ plays)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I own the IOS version of this game. I am glad I have only paid $1 to try this classic out. This game feels like a combination of Knizia's mathy game with an abstract like Go. The game is very much free form so I can see the depth and complexity that comes with such freedom but it also means this game is less forgiving in mistakes made. I got slaughtered bad by the easiest AI in my first game. I am sure it is a great game, but I think abstracts are not my cup of tea. My rating is based on my willingness to play again so this only gets a 5. :)

---- Update ----
I finally got to play this game at my local meetup with the FFG reprint. I can see why this game came back to print because it is an interesting game to play with players and not computer AI. It has an abstract feel to it (duh it's an abstract game) that feels similar to Through the Desert and Go. The scoring mechanism is what makes this game great. In order to win you have to focus on all colors.

The game clicked for me 2/3 way through and I enjoy the ending where it was a big push to the finish and a huge battle at the end. War wins the game! And that comes with careful planning and hand management.

Ratings from 5 -> 7.

RATING: 2
A dismal treatment of an outstanding theme.  When, oh when, will Reiner Knizia get it right?  He's made a half-dozen or so civilization-making games, NONE of which succeed as well as even Settlers of Catan in giving you any sense of civilization building.  I'd rather perform second-derivative calculus than stare any more at the (fairly ugly) abstract pieces while I wonder again why I would care about the utterly abstract and pointless rules for chit-laying which make up 99% of this game.

RATING: 5
Okay, I've played this a few times.  My problem with it is twofold.  #1, I got into this game later than everyone I play it with, and they smoke me. That's not that bad, but I realize that #2, victory is highly dependent on conflicts, which I'm having trouble getting excited about.  You may set up for a conflict, but one of two things seems to happen: a) you lose because your opponent had a bunch of tiles, or b) you win and are weakened for the next player.  The feeling of being susceptible to attack is distressing and keeping track of everyone's score is too much of a pain.  

Plus I never get any red tiles, and explaining the different conflicts and how they're resolved is a pain in the patuckus.  All this is just a way of saying I find the game a bit more trouble than it's worth.

RATING: 6
*Finally* played this.  What a weirdly counter-intuitive game. A bunch of abstruse, abstract rules, with a theme that does nothing to help you through them.  That is, the theme offers no reference points for understanding a very interesting but rather strange system.  So there's no "well, obviously traders would act in such-and-such a fashion, therefore this piece works like this....."  Still, it was a very interesting play, and by the end I was getting the hang of it.  The rating is thus provisional.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a very solid game that doesn't fall on luck as much as some make it out to be.  Yeah, you can get bad tiles but a good chunk of the game is trying to make use with what you have so you don't have to use portions of your turn exchanging tiles.  The only thing that I don't like about this game is I just have a hard time finding people that want to play it.  The group that I play with has of late been in love with deduction games like Secret Hitler, Avalon, and Burke's Gambit.  Partly, due to if we have a large player count we can't play Tigris.  A lot of the play that I now get with the game is against the computer though there are websites like Triqqy where you can play it online.  It is a deep game that I would maybe compare to Go.  The tile component makes the game interesting in that it forces you  to play your hand.  You can't go into the game with a preordained strategy or opening every game.  The flip side though is that occasionally, you will get blown out of the water in a conflict that you were very sure you would win but your opponent just happened to have a bunch of tiles of that color.  That doesn't happen often but it does happen sometimes and if you aren't the sort of person who can live with a little uncertainty, you will feel like the game has cheated you.   That said, luck does play a role in this game but it is very much on the low end.  A good player will have no problems beating a new player, no matter what tile they draw.   The game also plays well from 2 - 4 players.  I find it surprisingly tactical with 2 players.   With 4 players, there is more stuff that can go on outside of your control or you were unable to plan for.  That doesn't make it worse for 4 players but just different.  All and all a great abstract game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very wargamey. I would love to watch someone play this well. I would learn a lot and probably get more enjoyment out of this one. Hopefully I can figure it out because you just know it is there under the surface.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For a long time I had this at an 8. After several two and three player games I have decided to put this game in the 10 spot (I only have one other game at that rank).

If this game is dry then so is the vast majority of Euros. The game is exciting, it is nasty and cut-throat in every wonderful way. The choices are wide open every turn but with the heart breaking limit of actions that you are allowed.

Some complain about the luck of "tile drawing" Poo Poo on that. You may not be able to do what you would most wish you could do on a turn (but it wouldn't be a good game if you could) there are always many other strategic moves that you can make with what you have. Those who fail to grasp that concept, fail to grasp the game itself. Yes, you do have to plan ahead, that is the point as well.

I have never been in a place where I had less then two or three powerful choices to make.

Fantastic game that always ends much closer in scoring then you think.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Acquire's merge mechanics, Ingenious' "the lowest is your score" scoring, and euro style tile-laying a la Reef Encounter combine into this fascinating brain-burner. The concept is simple, but the game provides real depth and fascinating tactics to challenge any player. This is Knizia's masterpiece and a good example of elegant, simple rules that turn into an absorbing and replayable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is by far my favourite game, not only of those I own but of those I have ever played.  The components are fantastic, lots of colours and chunky bits to handle.  Particularly that you can exchange your smaller “1” blocks for the larger “5” blocks, making it a lot easier to count up your score.  The scoring principles are great, where your lowest score in any of the colours is your final score (same as those you find in ingenious).  There are so many different tictacs, many that cause you to play quiet aggressively at times.  Also it is a hidden information game so nobody knows who has won until the very end.  It’s one of the most addictive games I’ve ever played, I always finish wanting to play another game and try a new tactic.  
This game is a must for any boardgamegeeker!!!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Beautiful game, with easy mechanics and really deep strategy. Both my wife and I enjoyed our first play to the point we got a copy of the game the next day. Looking forward to get more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An interesting cross between a civilization building game, territory expansion and abstract wargame.  Some interesting and unusual concepts to learn but once you've got your head around them, the game can be played quite quickly.  Oddly for a relatively lightweight game it can be quite harsh on players who make mistakes or get victimised.  As the game enters the late phases and the board fills up there's a danger of clashing with other players whether you want to or not!

Added after some more plays: I'd like to like this more - there's a lot to like - but there's a significant reliance on the luck of the tile draw which detracts too much from the skill element of the game.

RATING: 10
This is doctor Knizia's Masterpiece.

This is the definition of German Euro war game.

Mechanics are clever, very confrontational and tense moments throughout the game.

The game is strategic and tactical at the same time with lots of player interactions which are what makes this game so great.

This is an absolute classic in board game history.

A must own if you are a fan of board game in general and a true piece of diamond that sees no equal even until this date.

RATING: 8.5
Had this as my 10, but am going to 'be real' and reduce the number.  I don't think anything is a 10 at this point, as I have so many games that I want to play - E&T is a great one, definately worth a 9, but can't say with honesty that 'I always want to play it' as if it's the only game on my mind.  It's great - conflict, city building, intrigue, etc.. but it's being outshined.  Let the dust settle and we'll see where things stand.

When do I play this?:
Not all of the time.  It's best played with my friends who are very familiar with different types of games, who can absorb rules and see patterns well, and who love the subtle, yet drastic, nuances of the game.  It's just a great game, even though it can't be played (or enjoyed, for that matter) all of the time by everyone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Quite unlike anything else I'd played until I tried Reef Encounter, which has some elements that feel similar but they are actually very different games.

The rules aren't too tricky, but it can take several plays to begin to see how to make more intelligent moves and plan ahead properly. The tile draw helps avoid it becoming too chess-like though.

Plays quite differently with only 2 players. There is more board space so it is possible to avoid each other most of the time. However, choosing to play more aggressively can yield better results & is more fun.

NOTE: Own Pegasus Spiele edition published in Germany (April 2007) with double-sided board & rule variants.

RATING: 9
-

An innovative, original design and a classic of early Euro. It is already 10 years old, but it feels as fresh as ever. This is one game whose mechanics don't easily lend themselves to copying. Knizia's best, and deservedly at #2 right behind Puerto Rico. Although, depending on my mood Caylus could occupy the #2 position sometimes.  How about a draw at #2 for both?  This is a good example of why any single list of "Best of..." anything can not tell the whole story and can even be misleading.  Back to the game... yes, one of my all-time favorites. With two, it is as engaging as Chess.

There are two reasons I have not given it a 10. The first is the small amount of luck introduced when drawing tiles. The second is the player-induced chaos present in 4-player games (and to a lesser degree in 3-player games). Nonetheless, it is indisputably a masterpiece. 

-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Good game. This is one of Knizia's better designs.  The strategies are deep.  The game works very well for 2,3 or 4 players but requires different strategies for each number.  This is the closest Knizia has come to presenting a war game and it works well. (If Avalon Hill had written the rule book wouldn't 'internal conflict' and 'external conflict' be described as 'revolution and war?)  Only drawback ( and it is significant) is the tile draw - it is actually worse than rolling massive numbers of dice as the laws of probability suggest that the die results would balance out. Unfortunately there are so few tile draws during T&E that the game can be decided by the draw alone. This reduces the value of the game from a potentially great strategy game to a serious beer and pretzels game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
My last, and only other play of this game was in 2011, so I didn't really remember anything about it. This time I absolutely hated the experience. It feet wild, chaotic and random, although end game scoring proved that it wasn't, as each of my three opponents had nine points with me sitting at 5.

In this game, you are laying down tiles in a big grid. There are a few placement rules, but the focus is on the fact that when you put a tile down into a chain of tiles, a player who's marker is a part of that chain, with the matching color, gets a cube in that color. When two cities connect, or when a player puts a marker down in the same city as a matching opponent's marker, then players battle by spending randomly drawn tiles from behind their player screen of the color of the conflict, with the most tiles winning. In some cases you also count tiles around your marker, and in some you don't but I found the combat incredibly frustrating. My opponents might win a combat without spending any tiles behind their screen, and then I lost a combat where I had a +5 advantage to someone revealing 5 matching tiles. The winner of the combat gets some cube payout in the matching color as well.

When someone loses a combat, parts of the city flay off, which means your positions can get messed up even through no participation of your own.

I'm sad to say I hated every minute of this game. I know it's one of the big revered games out there, but I found it completely intolerable.

:star: Art, Iconography and components functional
:nostar: Clever or interesting mechanisms
:star: Reasonably low downtime between turns with mildly AP players
:nostar: Multiple plays stay interesting
:nostar: Low or mitigatable luck elements
:nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Raw enjoyment

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Knizia's masterpiece? I've been waiting forever to get my hands on the reprint of T&E, having loved pretty much all the Knizia games I've played. And I'm certainly not disappointed. The first game I had absolutely no idea what I was doing, and then I won. The second game strategies began to present themselves, and the third game I was totally hooked. It's amazing how the whole game is driven by that simple but elegant scoring mechanic, and how games can range from quick grabs for treasure to epic slug-fests. Some complain about the luck of the tile draw, but I think there are enough ways of mitigating it.

UPDATE AFTER 40 PLAYS (plus hundreds on iOS): What can I say? This is The One, my Desert Island Game, everything I'm looking for. Unlike any other Euro I know, it feels like it could have been invented thousands of years ago and rediscovered in a Mesopotamian excavation. The perfect combination of chess-like spatial strategy and poker-like bet and bluff. A match between four experienced players is my greatest gaming joy, and I'm so grateful that my group provides sufficient opportunities for me to experience that. To those who say it's all luck, I recommend playing a few times against the iOS AI on its hardest setting. Once you can win 75% of your 4-player games, let me know what you think. I will be playing this game until I die.

RATING: 9
Shifan has it
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A surprisingly thematic entry from Dr. Knizia. Players do not control individual kingdoms, as is usually the case with games of this type, but instead control leaders that may be spread across several different kingdoms. Increasing a kingdom's size and power in one of the four realms of influence will result in a scoring cube in that color for the appropriate leader. Players must try to keep their influence spread as evenly as possible since it is the lowest of the four scores which is a player's final score. This rule in and of itself makes for the greatest dynamic in the game, since a player may find it easy to score points in one area of influence, but without any real benefit from it. Diversity is key, and this game is an amazing embodiment of that. It is also fun seeing the kingdoms grow and absorb one another after they inevitably cross borders. In this respect it feels a little like Acquire with its merger.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
A Gamer's game, it's appeal is far from being universal, and you'll either love it or hate it. It makes me suffer every time I play it. It's a very aggressive game (that's why my wife doesn't like it), and you have to keep a balance between your own planning and scoring and twarthing your opponent's plans as well as his own scoring.

Edit: After a while, it becomes uninteresting... You're too much at the mercy of the tiles, and there are too many variables to successfully plan or strategize efficiently... It's more tactical, and reactive... and it begins to feel a little bit boring after  a few months.

Edit: I've grown to dislike it a lot. I'm trading it or selling it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
It's taken me a long time to accept that this is a game I [i]want[/i] to like more than it's a game I actually like. 

There's a lot about it I love. It's a high-interaction game, and it has hand management (although with tiles and not cards). It takes experience to play well, the rules are just a description of the levers you can pull (how to pull them and when is completely up to you), and the game has no artificial catchup mechanism--better players will win. An extended run back when BGG hosted an electronic version of the game remains a true highlight of gaming for me. 

My major hangup--aside from the plain fact that I am terrible at the game--is that I do not retain any knowledge or strategy or insight if enough time passes between plays. It's not a Bicycle Game for me where I just pick up where I left off. It's like a language, where the longer I go without using it, the more it atrophies. Where you get together with other fluent speakers and they notice your accent, and wonder why you're unable to express a simple thought in your mother tongue, why you conjugated a verb like a preschooler. This game requires practice and repeated exposure. I can give it neither. 

So I don't see it. I see the game with no clarity, and when I do, it gets hastily scribbled on a piece of paper with disappearing ink: a week later I dig a wad of paper out of my pocket and can make out the faint lines of a once-important thought, but what was it? T&E is yet another game (like Brass) that I'd play a lot in person if I could, but it's never gotten any traction with anyone nearby, and so despite being one of my most-played games, it's fading, a vocabulary I'm slowly losing. Eventually I'll be sitting in a crowded room, everyone conversing, and I'll only be able to make out a few words here and there. "Red tiles," I'll hear over the din, otherwise lost in indistinct babble. "External conflict," from the other side of the table, floating on laughter. "My turn," I'll think to myself, smiling politely and desperately trying to guess at the missing context while everyone waits for my reply...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a very confrontational tile laying game.  In many ways it gives the feel of an agressive pseudo-war game (like Risk) while being completely in the "German" style with regard to rules and mechanisms.  

Knizia is often accused of pasting on theme, and though I agree in some cases (Taj Mahal) I feel the rules are very thematic in the case of T&E.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dec 2016: Raised from 7 to 10. Wow. 25% less convoluted than you current typical Euro, 400% deeper, 800% more interactive!

Dec 2007: UPDATE: Raised from 6 to 7. I finally played this game with competent players! This is the biggest problem of the game: The basic tactics of the game are not readily apparent, which must be fully understood before you can play this game quickly under an hour.

These tactics include the fact that having a temple is not necessarily a good thing, and ensuring that colours you're weak in do not break up your kingdom if someone happens to attack it -- and fully understanding the possibilities of breaking up a kingdom.

Another reason why this game is so unapproachable is its themes. There are games that the theme is well integrated with the mechanics (which is ideal). There are games in which the theme is pasted on. That's still OK to me; you can simply ignore the theme. Then there are games like T&E (and Stephenson's Rocket) that are in the middle: the theme makes sense in relation to other elements in the game, but not in relation to reality. For example, it makes thematic sense for the four types of tiles to have different purposes. But in reality: having a trader leader in a kingdom allows you to grab a treasure? Or internal conflicts in which simply being adjacent to a particular tile -- even a tile your opponent is using -- is a form of defense? This game has very complex and integrated mechanisms that do not have much connection with reality. But you can't approach it as an abstract strategy game because the rules aren't particularly elegant.

=====

I greatly admire this game but it never comes out anymore. The rules are just too fiddly. I really wanted to like this one as well. I tried this about half-a-dozen times with my dad and unfortunately the game didn't "click" with us.

RATING: 6
Yes, this is a good game, yes it deserves all the praise it gets, yes it is great abstract game with a pasted on theme. I consider this game rather an oddball in my collection.  I bought it because of the geek recommendations, because it's designed by Knizia, and because the pasted on theme seemed cool.  I was not disappointed in the game play...very clever and thought-provoking.  The theme...well, it helped me with some of the game concepts (it actually helps to view the tile aggregates as "kingdoms", and internal conflicts as "insurrections"), but at the heart of it, your fighting for little colored blocks. Still, it's pretty to look at (always a plus in my book), relatively easy to teach (the rules anyway, grasping strategy is another thing altogether), and my wife likes it!  

Edit: Had to sell it. With so many other thematic options out there, there was nothing compelling to get me to bring this abstract to table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The importance of luck in tile draw hurts this otherwise fine game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

And he was the only one who had played it before.  Still, I had a lot of fun with it, even while I thought I was losing badly, and I'd love to play it again.

RATING: 9
Played at Expo 2015 and was impressed straightaway (despite the rather poor teaching by the volunteer from Fantasy Flight). Reiner Knizia really is the master of creating depth out of a minimalist ruleset and I really admire that. I like the theme, the components and the decisions that this offers. It is fun to look at a new hand of tiles each turn and think "what am I going to do with this lot?". The game poses a fresh puzzle each turn, each of which can sit neatly in your longer term strategy. My rating for this could go up.

RATING: 10
Easily one of the best games I have played.  The game is tactical and strategic with layers of depth.  There are an overwhelming number of options per turn, but can be narrowed down if a player focuses on what they need.  The comments about the lack of theme are somewhat incorrect... There is a very deep theme in the game, but it is a little unexpected.  Players must go in expecting lots of direct conflict without moving armies on the board and they will see the theme shine through!

Started playing this game online at boardgamegeek.com/tigris.  I get way more plays of this in now, as my gaming partners live over an hour away.

RATING: 6
Nice strategic depth for a tile laying game. It provides several different methods of scoring points, with no one standing as completely superior to the other. (pressing your advantages is key)

That said, the rules feel unintuitive and clunky. For that reason, I don't enjoy it as much as Samurai the card game. Additionally, some players are turned off by the random tile draws which, admittedly, can throw off your game completely.
