=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Danny has this now...

Players 2-4, best with 4.  Weight 3.53.
Only played once-- a little hard to learn; may get a higher rating with more plays... 
Tile placement, area development, and conflict in an abstract war game. Balance matters -- only your lowest set is scored, and there are two types of conflict (internal from the placement of two same-colored leaders in a single region, and external from the merging of two regions). All of this means there is a lot to keep track of, and many ways to win or lose the game. Building monuments early can lead to a steady stream of points. Players who do not protect their positions will find all their hard work is stolen by a swift maneuver from an opponent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I didn't know what to expect when starting this game.  As the rules were explained to me I began to realize this was not going to be a game I would enjoy.  I enjoyed it more than I thought I would, but still not great.

I don't like games where other players can mess with my plans.  This game is designed to have conflict.

I also don't particularly care for abstract games.  This game is very abstract in the way tiles and leaders are placed.  You want optimize your limited actions and things can get a bit thinky.  Sometimes it's fairly easy to see your optimum choice, but sometimes analysis paralysis sets in.  I try to stay away from games that promote AP.

I did like the scoring mechanism.  You must balance the points from every color as the lowest of the group is your final score.  In our play the scores were 11, 10, 9.  Very tight!

This game is one where people will really gang up on the "leader".  If you make a brilliant move then the next few rounds are going to be horrible as everyone tears apart what you were able to build.  I prefer games that reward you for playing cleverly, not ones that allow the other players to quickly gang up on you.

I don't like the hidden information for scoring.  You can only speculate as to which color an opponent is needing to increase their final score.  If this information was public knowledge then the decisions for making a turn would be much faster.  "Oh, they need more red.  I'll just block red."

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: [b]Components[/b]
:star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Artwork[/b]
:star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Mechanics (general gameplay "fun")[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Rules (well written and easy to learn/teach)[/b]
:star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: [b]Replay Value[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Player Uptime[/b]
:star::star::star::star::nostar: [b]Meaningful Decisions (luck factor)[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Total[/b]

RATING: 8
Rating for online multiplayer iOS app.

An intriguing Euro that abstracts civilisation development, and conflict with rival civilisations. The simple and clever mechanisms - tile laying and score calculation based upon highest lowest score in one of four spheres - belie the ruthless and cut-throat nature of the game.

I have played a number of times - both multiplayer and via AI players - and still uncover different facets of play.

RATING: 8.75
Tile placement, area development, and conflict in an abstract war game. Balance matters -- only your lowest set is scored, and there are two types of conflict (internal from the placement of two same-colored leaders in a single region, and external from the merging of two regions). All of this means there is a lot to keep track of, and many ways to win or lose the game. Building monuments early can lead to a steady stream of points. Players who do not protect their positions will find all their hard work is stolen by a swift maneuvre from an opponent. With more plays the rating will surely improve.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really enjoy this game.  It's marketed as "watching kingdoms rise and fall", but it's basically an abstract tile laying game mechanic.  There are so many strategies and different ways to play each turn that some folks may be overwhelmed, but I rather like it that way!  It can be played 2 players (I own the Mayfair version, which lists it as 3-4 players), but with 2 there tends to be much less conflict.  Rules are simple and short, if a bit on the vague side.  I recommend reading through the GameGeek comments and reviews, as this helped me understand some of the rules more than I would have just reading them.

RATING: 8.9
I would rate this a 9 or even a 10 but it has a real problem with the learning curve. There is something conceptually different about each of the different rules that is used for resolving conflicts/victory points which makes it counter-intuitive. The result is that it takes several sessions to actually get a grasp on what is happening - and that just seems more than it should be for a game of this type.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Interesting but very dry game.
Would be good to have a way of mitigating a poor tile draw.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(2014-12-04) I've played this a few times now and while I can appreciate its brilliance, I don't find it fun. I hate to use the word dry to describe my experience of the game but it certainly qualifies. I'm glad I got this (both the physical and iOS versions), and I've learned some neat mechanics from it. I find it absolutely fascinating that this game can play well with more than 2 players. It may be that I'm perceiving this as an abstract game (and this is not a knock - I love abstracts). I also love the way the game winning conditions force us to be a generalist instead of a specialist. This runs counter to the way many other games are designed. So. A lot to like - just not my cup of tea. 

UPDATE (2015-07-15): Wow. Out of boredom I fired up T&E on my iPhone to play - and totally loved the game. It's still a bit dry but I find it engaging now.  What I like about this is the need to evaluate when to shift my priorities to generating cubes for my weaker leaders.  My games also have more of a 'give and take' quality. I might lose a leader in an area, but if that leader has 2x the cubes of another leader, I might not even bother bringing it back into play, and focus on boosting the weaker leaders.  I also find it a challenge to decide when to force the game end (by aggressively swapping tiles) - that alone has helped keep my interest up, and I wonder if I didn't like it earlier because they ran longer than I had patience for. I want to start playing this more against other human players to see what the experience is like.

RATING: 7
A Euro heavy with direct conflict.

My most important epiphany regarding the strategy of this game: a player doesn't "own" anything on the board. He's simply a leech, drawing strength from whatever organisms he can. When he's removed, he can simply affix himself to some other warm body.

This was an impressive mechanism to someone whose most complex game played was Settlers of Catan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I am still poor but enjoying the game much more now than I did at first.  Almost as much as trying to win the game it is fun just to see how civilizations emerge, collide, and reform. Highly recommended for those willing to invest.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
http://www.ronkkonen.com/boardgames.html#Tigris
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Four things:  First, this is a game that rewards creativity.  There are SO many ways of getting what you want in the game, and very often you have to look carefully to figure out the right way to do it.  The tactics are incredibly delicious.  There's about 5 ways to make points, and every move you mave involves consideration of all 5 of those methods.  

Second, this is a dramatic game.  Beginners tend to play in a non-dramatic fashion, slowly building up 'their' kingdoms, but once you get the hang of the game, the best play is usually quite aggressive, and you are constantly destroying armies of others, usurping power, gaining possession of treasures and monuments.  it's not an incremental type game of, "let's try to balance my budget."  No!  It's a dramatic game about the rise and fall of civilizations, playable in about an hour!

Third:  it's beautiful to see kingdoms start, florish, grow, decay, and rebuild.  At the end of the game, you have before you a territory with a rich and complex history, and you can marvel at how a particular piece of land had been once part of a glorious society that had sadly been sacked by a vicious intruder, but now was slowly getting back on its feet under new leadership.  The feeling is analogous to the feeling after playing carcassonne, where you can admire the map that you had collectively built.

Fourth: It should be noted that this is a wargame, full of conflict.  If conflict is not your thing, this probably isn't a game for you.  That being said, Tigris and Euphrates is a "german" wargame, meaning that it the following nice attributes: 

No one is ever eliminated from the game.
There's tension right up to the very end (hidden scoring makes it difficult to determine if someone is blowing out everyone else).
Decisions are more difficult than your average grognard-style wargame.
The game is short (60-90 mins)!
Rules are (comparatively) simple

So there you have it.  Rise and fall of civilizations in an hour, lots of creative, difficult decisions, very very dramatic.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Nº de Jogadores : 2−4
Tempo de Jogo   : 90 minutos
Subdomínio      : Jogos de Estratégia

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tigris and Euphrates feels like a game heralding an ancestry as ancient as its thematic premise. Here we find a clear rise and fall of kingdoms, where religion is the source of internal conflict, where your kingdom's followers are the crux of your military might, and where you, in tandem with others, are constantly striving to develop the pillars of civilization: religion, government, agriculture, and trade. In the vein of classic Knizia design, your civilization is only as strong as your weakest link. 

This game's various aspects quintuple-check *almost* all the boxes that characterize my ideal board game. It just lacks the 'pizzazz' I like to have, that feeling of a carefully crafted clever move that forces another player to act in a way that is unavoidably detrimental to them. I can be antagonistic in that way, but it is my preferred way to play. Beyond playing with two (which plays very differently, mind you), the game becomes a bit too wild and chaotic to effectively set up any one individual. That is not to say three and four player counts are not an engaging experience. Oh, they most certainly are.

The game seems to revolve more around subterfuge and big swing turns rather than posturing for a grand interlocking strategy. Paradoxically, it feels as though you need to have a semblance of both in mind to win. You hope that you can be left to your devices (unlikely) and simultaneously pray that your offensive efforts are not stymied. Tensions are often heavy as the game constantly challenges you to find an effective balance between strategy and tactics.

T&E is a triumph in design and easily a timeless staple. Bravo, Dr. Knizia.

(+) Simple mechanisms, dynamic and open-ended space with high depth.
(+) Player-driven gameplay, high interaction and conflict.
(+) Mind-bendingly thematic despite being, in skeleton alone, an abstract game. Never a sought out criterion, personally, but Knizia somehow pulls it off. 

(-) A bit of clunker to teach, and the complexity lies in the maneuvers available to you and the reminder to new players to track all sources of point earnings. A minor hassle, at worst.
(-) Not particularly great with two players, which is something that most abstracts achieve.
(-) A poor run of luck spanning multiple turns can cripple you, though not excessively so, and it can be somewhat mitigated.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Enjoyed playing and have many more strategies I would like to try out.

(Comment from 11-6-2006)

Neat game, and my favorite of the Knizia tile-layers, but I don't particularly love the Knizia tile-layers the way other people do. They all seem like different versions of go that have been castrated in different ways. I appreciate the game, I appreciate the variety of strategy, but they don't call to me like Knizia's auction games or some of his nuttier stuff like Taj Mahal.

I was bigger on this game in the past, but lately I keep putting this game up to, I don't know, Acquire in my head, and finding this one just a little... less beautiful.

RATING: 9
 To me it's a 9 for the standard game. A lot of direct interaction, nice scoring system that keeps the game interesting till the end, plenty of space for strategic planning and perhaps a little bit too much luck for the tile drawing mechanics. The board landscape changes fast when resolving external conflicts, leading to a nice thematic effect of fallen and reborn civilizations. Probably most thematic Knizia's game alongside Modern Art.

 But a 7 for the advanced version. The game becomes very static because there are too many ways to score points without clashing with other players, specially in the three players version, as external conflicts lose significance.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
The deepest "gamers game" that I enjoy playing.  A sense of civilization and empire building, though more abstract than I would like.

I like the fact that the game accommodates playing styles; you can be very aggressive and interactive, or you can be very non-aggressive and try to avoid conflict.  Both approaches can result in victory.

The key for beginners is to figure out the difficult difference between an "internal conflict" and an "external conflict" -- once you understand that, then the game has been unlocked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
A clear case where I think the pasted-on theme makes it harder to teach and learn.  I generally don't like the screening of victory points - it's not too hard to keep track of how many of each color your opponent(s) have collected if you want to, especially with just 2p, but that then takes a lot of the fun out of the game if you're trying that hard.  I do see that this game could bog down with a lot of AP for some if victory points were visible. Lastly, using cubes for victory points just feels weird, compared to how they are used in every other Euro I've played. I think I would always recommend Ingenious (no attempt at pasted-on theme, simplified but similar feel, less conflict) over T&E.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my earliest acquisitions, and still one of the best games I own. EASILY a 10. Brilliant design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
----------

I dislike T&E's scripted openings, but beyond the first few moves, the game develops differently each time.  I can see the rise and fall of civilizations as the board matures, so it's not a dry, theme-less experience for me.  I like that the random tile draw keeps things fresh and that it limits your strategic capability.  I do recognize the power of red tiles in the late game, but I think that unknown of each new round breathes life into the game.  Incredible tension with several options on each turn.  I don't really like playing the game on BGG because the competition of the league spoils the fun of the game for me. 

I find my desire to play this game slowly dwindling, but it's a fantastic game nonetheless.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A very interesting game. A communal board area which looks fascinating and acts as a giant puzzle. The victory point system is unique and encourages varietal gameplay (can't just do one thing all game and win like with many strategy war games). Feels like playing chess but with a fun twist. Have yet to play with more than 2 players but I would expect the the game to only get better.

Edit: I have since played with multiple players, both 3 and 4 player counts. The game changes dramatically with that many people on the board as the timer (bag) goes by quicker so you will have overall less moves and the landscape can change massively between one turn to the next. While I enjoy the game greatly, its definitely one I have to be in the mood for as this type of thinking can take a lot of energy and the simplicity of the mechanics, while great for strategy, can come off as dry compared to some other games out there nowdays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A well-balanced game, that appears abstract at first, but really does evoke a theme well. Plenty of player interaction; no multi-player solitaire here! Reminds me of Go sometimes.

My big complaint is: stop trying to make private variables (score) that you declare publicly and then increment publicly! This really drives me nuts, both from a logical perspective, and from the fact that it means that optimally each player would continuously take notes with pen & paper. Either you're doing that (which is obviously stupid), or you're not playing properly, which bugs me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This has quickly become my number one favourite game. Amazing. Plays well with 2,3 or 4.

A variant 2p rules suggested by BGG user: Michael Kandrac (Gamegrunt)

For a tight, shorter two-player T&E try this...
- Remove the four corner Temples
- Remove 14 Red Tiles
- Remove 9 Blue Tiles
- Remove 8 Green Tiles
- Remove 8 Black Tiles
Play game normally except game ends when 1 temple treasure remains.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very Accessible Complex Euro 

An early acquisition of mine...I didn't understand it. I mean, I understood the rules (they were pretty easy & accessible), but the strategies remained opaque to me, even after 3 or 4 plays, so I sold it. I was heavily into Go at the time, so I figured that if I didn't get it, there wasn't much there--how could an abstract game remain opaque to me after I had cracked open the mysteries to the Master Abstract?

Played again many years later, and saw glimmers of what I had been missing. Was intrigued enough to re-purchase, and at this point I feel confident in saying that this is a very good game. Took me a while to get there, though.

The FF version is the best, guys. Don't stand on euro v. Ameritrash prejudices, just get it. I love wood pieces as much as the next guy, but this version just feels more right, somehow. I think by saying this I'm classifying the game more as a euro than an abstract. THe Mayfair bits signaled that it was an abstract. It's not. It's a euro that does better with more euro-ish bits.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Je me rends compte que j'avais oublié de laisser un avis sur Tigre & Euphrate. Pas grand chose à ajouter à la cascade d'avis positifs sur ce jeu. Des règles d'une simplicité exemplaire (même si la notion de conflit interne/externe semble inexplicablement difficile à faire comprendre à des débutants) pour un jeu à la fois thématique, riche et avec juste ce qu'il faut de hasard pour rendre les parties accessibles et passionnantes, sans compter les conditions de victoire, favorisant un jeu équilibré et donc subtil.

Plus qu'un jeu, une œuvre d'art ludique, comme il y en a encore bien peu et que seul un grand nom comme Reiner Knizia pouvait s'en rendre l'auteur.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Just a tad chaotic for me. I must confess that I don't really get why this game is rated so highly. I have played it some more to try and understand it, but it just seems to me that with players of roughly equal skill the winner is the one who's lucky enough to draw the most red tiles and stays out of conflict the most. To initiate conflict and lose is disasterous both in terms of the initial waste of tiles and your turn, but also because of how it (depending on your new tile draw), opens you up for attack. Hence the luck of the tile draw seems overwhelming to me. Others say they see a theme and I'm happy for them. I'd rather play something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After a bad first impression playing the game online against the bot, I could try it recently live and my thoughs changed drastically.  This is, without a doubt, one of the best Knizia designs, together with [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/21882]Blue Moon City[/url][/i] and [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/503]Through the Desert[/url][/i].  Nevertheless it could be label as an abstract game, the theme is convincing and adds an unique flavor.  At the end, you feel surprised cause, after all, you really felt being in Mesopotamia struggling for power.  My rating could be even higher, but the luck involved in the resolution of conflicts is very high for a game of this weight.

RATING: 9
It's all about taking those scoring opportunities when they arise, isn't it?  It's the anti-civ building game in some ways.  While its great to build a colossal kingdom, it's hard if not impossible to maintain.  I see it almost like a game of sniping points here and there.  Maybe that's why I'm so terrible at it.  Very tactic heavy and very dynamic, so your strategy must remain flexible.  Gives rise to interesting philosophical discussions when the question of whether the game is abstract or well-themed is raised.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wonderfully complex strategy game with a seemingly infinite amount of strategies to play on any given turn. Brilliant in the sense that your WEAKEST category determines the winner. The constant conflicts in this game keep the game lively & keeps all the players on their toes -- while you're trying to plan ahead for the future, you realize that ANYTHING can happen at any given time. Took us about 90 minutes to comprehend the instructions the first time we read them, and our first game was 4 hours long. So the game is on the longer side, but it is WELL WORTH the investment. I am addicted. This game reminds me a lot of chess, but whereas chess bores me, this game excites me. This is a great game... one of my favorite board games I have ever played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Picked up like new from gamer on Craigslist.  Interesting tile laying and conflict game.  After one play I definitely do not feel like I have a clue how to win this game.  But it is a fun and challenging game and one I would play anytime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've only played this game twice. I'm not entirely sure what I think about it yet, but I'm leaning towards positive. It's a bit dry and I don't really have a grasp on how to play the game well, but I suppose the important thing is that, unlike some games, I [i]am[/i] interested in playing again to see if I [i]can[/i] learn how to play well; I like how the scoring system works to force players away from specialization, and I think the theme works very well as a mnemonic if not as aid to immersion. I also like how the landscape of the game can change radically after a conflict has been resolved, creating the potential for swings in momentum or control between the players. In this sense, the game has some of the feel I associate with Reef Encounter, as dominant species of coral spread out and consume their weaker neighbours. Between the two games, I prefer Reef Encounter, primarily because I find the theme more interesting and its application more transparent. Given the choice, I would more often opt to play Reef Encounter, so I sometimes wonder if I need to own this game. For now, I think it's different enough that I want to give it a chance to grow on me some more.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game is definately abstract with a thin veneer of a theme, but it did not seem as dry and mechanical as most abstract games. In fact, to me, El Grande feels more abstract than this. 
I can see the expanding/contracting tile groupings as kingdoms wracked by civil war and invasion. New leaders emerge and fight for power. The "luck" of the tile draw for me is an integral part of the game. It simulates both fog of war and limited resources very elegantly. A really great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Knizia's magnus opus stands alone: there's no other game like this. You're trying to score the 4 colors in a balanced manner, but the mechanisms set you up such that it is easy to specialize only in one or two, and the route to strengthening your kingdom is often not the route to balanced scoring.

I am a bit leery that heretofore, most games (including on Tigris) have been decided by having the right colors at the right time to win swing-y external conflicts in the somewhat unsatisfying combat system. But there are many options to consider on your turn to outweigh this slightly more luck-dependent component, and this brings up some fine opportunities to bluff/deduce.

RATING: 5
Interesting solid mechanics, but THE THEME IS A LIE. I really enjoy Mesopotamian history, but the theme was a hindrance to the game play. It would be much better as a cloak and daggers type game. After all, for a third party to place a random tile to connect two other disconnected kingdoms to have the effect of starting a war in which that third party is not involved in any way is nonsensical in a Mesopotamian context but is understandable if the theme were to be one of espionage and terrorism. The poor choice of theme spoiled it for me. For a superb marriage of theme choice and mechanics, just look at "Chaos in the Old World."

RATING: 7
Great game but definatly has some issues (otherwise I'd give it a 9+ rating).

Small mistakes can result in huge changes in the board.  Often random luck determines what you can do.  Generally that means you have to try to maximize whatever options you have, but often the best you can do with yours is way inferior to your opponents options.

RATING: 8.5
I ... like it. 

I like how it reminds of old timey abstracts, yet isn't. (and in Pegasus edition it also looks very nice). It's strategic, interactive, yet has a lot of luck involved and reminds of traditional card games in this regard. And the results are never quite predictable, though you think they should be (like in good cardgames).

Surprisingly to Knizia there's a definite narrative arch to the game - kingdoms rise, fall and empty monuments remain. I don't think there is a minus to the game, maybe it's needing repeated plays and probably not nongamer friendly. But if you have a space for that kind of game in your collection (and want to impress people who love or respect traditional abstracts) this is the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

i find that the luck element of the tile draw has thrown off my strategy too often for me to ever like this game.  i find myself competing with the tile bag rather than my opponents.

generally, when somebody suggests this one, i try to talk them into something fu ...

it's kind of sad too because there's so much interesting stuff here.  the scoring system is really interesting and the competition for territory works really well.  maybe if there was a variant that fixed the tile draw, i would be willing to try it again.

RATING: 9
Brilliant game, actually much closer to Go in terms of skills than Through the Desert, but very different, of course. The object is not to surround or capture, but to protect and expand four different pieces at once against multiple types of attacks, and to figure out a way to expand quicker than other players.

A mind-reeling joy.

RATING: 10
[18 plays, many as a 2 player.] The time zips right by when you are playing this game. The last time I've been so addicted to the rush of playing an abstract game was 30 years ago when I couldn't get enough chess. 

The contest seems largely tactical as strategies can evaporate on contact with reality. But the tactics are complex and intriguing. In a 4 player game, it becomes almost purely tactical, as players just have to do their best to keep up with the rapidly evolving landscape.


Most recent play 10-7-11 with Donovan, Carter, and Corey.

RATING: 10
The ancient civilizations theme is so thin that I tend to forget about it while I'm playing. Nevertheless, this is an excellent game that rewards planning, calculation, and flexibility. And it hasn't gotten stale even after repeated play. So simple and yet so deep. I have no doubt that E&T deserves it's high ranking.

Update 10 years later... This game has been sitting on the shelf for a while, but I recently returned to discover how much fun it continues to be. Should I be surprised that T&E has sunk from #1 to #61 in the rankings? Like chess, it's relatively dry, cerebral, and conflict oriented. With today's geeks all about theme and bling, Tigris doesn't fit the BGG zeitgeist as well as it used to. Nevertheless, it will always have a home in my game collection. I have the old Mayfair edition-- I can't stand the Fantasy Flight Games treatment for this game.

RATING: 7
Of all the "heavy-weight" European games I have played, this is my favorite. Excellent with 2, 3, or 4, there are many different strategies to pursue. I love the fact that a player can come from behind to win - with the right strategy. The scoring mechanism is also ingenious, and keeps the game tense to the end. It's just excellent when everyone thinks player X is going to win, and then, when the victory cubes are revealed, little ol' player Y wins! The game has nice components and great player interaction, but seem a little mean-hearted and suffers from weak thematic elements. I DO like the theme here, but if I had to rate theme as a separate component, it would get a 7, whereas the rest of the game would get a 10. The confrontations can also get a little too nasty (for some players). That's code for: my wife will never suggest this game (although she will play it). Despite these gripes, I must rate this an 8 - it is incredible. I will also add that only this game (and Knizia's Durch Die Wuste) have actually gotten my wife mad during a game. I haven't decided yet if that is a mark for or against them. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like this game, though I think it's best with 3 or 4.  Once you get your brain around the mechanics, it can be an interesting tactical game.

RATING: 10
My first eurogame and still the best experience with the genre. It's tense, dynamic and everybody is engrossed till the end. The mechanics are geniously innovative and constitutes a highly aesthetic element in their own right, adding to an already beautiful looking game. 4 players is a must though, luck does play a role and new players always seem to win for some strange reason.   

After many, many plays: the game actually works great with 3 players too, if you don't camp too much (which is a beginners strategy). The game still amazes me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[2011-05-07]
1997-es játék, de a játékmenete zseniális. Talán az egyik legizgalmasabb, legjobb játékmenet, amivel találkoztam. Annyira elvarázsolt ez, illetve a szép második Myfair kiadás táblája és lapkái, hogy kevésbé zavart a játék két hibája. Az egyik, a szerencse szerepe egy ilyen komoly játék esetében abszolút felhozható probléma, de én aki a kis szerencsét bőven elviselem emiatt morgolódtam a legkevésbé. A királycsinálás nagymértékű megjelenése viszont kevésbé jó dolog. Sajnos kevésbé hozzáértő játékos simán csinálhat olyan lépést, amivel megnyeretheti egy másik játékostársával a partit. Illetve a játék sokat gondolkodós játékosok mellett nagyon elhúzódhat. De az igazság az, hogy ebben a játékban muszáj sokat gondolkodni egy-egy lépésen.
A játékosok négy színben próbálnak kockákat gyűjteni, lapkalerakásokkal és vezérekkel, akinek a játék végén a négy fajtából a legkevesebb darabszámúból a legtöbb van az a nyertes. Ez a pontozás a Genialból lehet ismerős és nagyon fekszik ebben a játékban is. A játék sava-borsát a kétfajta konfliktus adja. A belsőben piros kockáért és vezérelzavarásért megy a harc, a külsőben viszont jó sok kocka begyűjtésért is.
Nagyon jó játék a Tigris, azonos szintű játékosokkal az egyik legjobb játékélmény lehet a társasok világában. Akik nem félnek egy-egy hosszabb gondolkodású körtől mindenképpen próbálják ki.

[2011-05-14]
Továbbra is zseniális játéknak tartom a második parti után, de a királycsináló effektus miatt egyszerűen nem tudok neki magasabb pontszámot adni.

RATING: 9
Falling somewhere between a pure-abstract game and a Martin Wallace-style tactical economy-builder, Tigris and Euphrates is just about perfect. Beginners always have trouble distinguishing the internal and external conflicts, but a few examples usually clear this up. T&E can be very boring if everyone tries to be too nice, and it can be extremely frustrating if everyone is too aggressive. Once the group finds a workable balance, though, it just works.

RATING: 8
It was apparent from my first play that this is an outstanding game.  There is a truckload of conflict in this struggle for dominance.  There is a significant random element in the draws, but you have to learn to play what you get well.  It plays well at 2, best (I imagine) at 3, and I hate it at 4.  The 2p game gives you a chance to really understand what does what, as you can string together moves to achieve a strategy.  This is largely absent in the 4p game, as the board can change so much between turns.

RATING: 9.5
Four types of leader, two types of conflict, never enough blue tiles, and eighty-three kinds of pain.  I've never won a game where I didn't force at least one conflict that scared me.  (Of course, that's lost me a lot of games, too.)  Unlike many games with only one path to victory, the winning strategy in T&E changes every game (or every turn) according to your opponents' actions.

RATING: 9.5
Given my experience in playing this game, I think I've overrated it, but I'm giving it the benefit of the doubt on its potential.  We had very little conflict in the game I did play, and the experienced player totally destroyed us (not in a malicious way; he did his best to explain what we needed to do).  I'd like to play it again and see if I have more fun with it.

UPDATE: Dropping this to a 6 to reflect my true feelings about this.  If this gets on the table again, may change the rating again.

UPDATE #2: Played this again.  I finally understood how the conflicts and monuments worked and we had a game with interesting ebb-and-flow.  There's a lot to this game, and I look forward to playing it again.  I think it's different enough that I recommend at least a couple of plays before deciding that it's not one's cup of tea.

UPDATE #3: After my third play, I now fully follow how the game is supposed to be played, and I have a bit of an idea for strategy.  There's plenty of depth to this game, and I look forward to my next play.

Also a note that the second edition is well worth it: the white background of the first edition really is quite lousy.

RATING: 10

It is amazing how much game there is for a relatively simple set of rules.  You must be adaptable, relentless, and clever to do well.  And take chances.  And hide your intentions. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After studying the rules and thinking about them forever, finally I taught T&E to three gamers who also wanted to play. I quickly crushed one of them, stealing his kingdom and its monument, installing all of my leaders in choice positions within it. After establishing a sprawling, well fortified kingdom, I set my sights on others. A large war with who I perceived to be winning left me with even more territory and another monument. I ended up winning, left with an empire as secure as anyone could expect. Everyone walked away satisfied. I've lost games since, but I've always walked away wanting to play again.

Critics charge that T&E lacks theme. That's nonsense. There are revolutions, wars, and better civilization building than in any board game I've played. There are dramatic moves, decisive swings, and Machiavellian strategies. After a mistake, you'll see where you went wrong and you'll think about how best to improve for next time. When you triumph, you'll feel that you earned it. Like Twilight Struggle and Cosmic Encounter, T&E tells a story. Each player has one, their own arc, telling the tale of their own clan, but they're part of a larger story too, united by a shared board.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I tried this many times, some face to face and a lot here on BGG. It's OK, but I don't share the love for this game that so many others seem to have. It seems largely tactical, which I generally prefer - plays are almost completely dictated by your hand of tiles and the current board layout (makes it great for PBW with open cubes). But there is certainly more here than just tactics: spatial play on the board (one reason why this is better than the E&T Card Game), bluffing, timing the end of the game, etc. But after years of having the game sit on the shelf unplayed, we finally traded it off. After all, I can always play it on BGG, and buy a newer copy (with extra map) if I somehow fall in love with the game!

My rules summary (old, with not-so-great audio quality!): http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/11372/audiorules_euphrat-mp3

RATING: 2
I've tried really hard to like this game and I don't understand exactly why I don't.  Maybe I'm trying too hard!  It's clearly well-designed, to say the least, and surely deserving of the heaps of praise showered upon it.  For some reason, it doesn't hold my interest.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm not usually a fan of tile-placement or overly abstract games but even though this is heavily in both of those camps I absolutely love everything about Tigris and Euphrates.  The design is just so amazingly elegant.  The interaction of the different leaders, different types of conflicts, need to collect points across all colors evenly because you are scored on the lowest, and so much more offers such a breadth of strategy that this is one of the most thinking games I've ever played and I absolutely love every second of it.

The one sorta criticism I have is that despite the simplicity of this game it is difficult to teach to others.  Certain concepts like that you can put your leader in another kingdom and that a kingdom is never really "your kingdom" are difficult to grasp for new players, it's not the average gaming mindset.  And even when you have a firm grasp on all the rules it is a game that is difficult to master, although that's an attribute of a lot of overly abstract games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
I like the game a lot. I really don't know if it's Knizia's best but I love the game. The mechanics is excelent. Very competitive and very heavy. Maybe it's too heavy. The only thing I don't like that much it's the art and the tile's taking. It really makes the game too much "lucky pick".
Edit: It grows on you.

PORTUGUÊS: O jogo é muito bom. Para mim tem o defeito de ser demasiado pesado. Ou seja, mentalmente é muito exigente. Sempre. Também não gosto muito de ter demasiado trabalho a jogar um jogo que depois, ao fim e ao resto, depende demasiado da sorte em relação às cores das peças que vamos tirando. Em termos de desenho também não é muito agradável. Mas é uma obra-prima de matemática. Lá isso é.

Things change and although this game still is a good game I have to say that at this point of my gaming life T&E is a bit boring, repetitive and dry for what I'm interested in now. The game itself is good, it scales well with 2 to 4 players and it has a good abstract idea but I don't like to play it anymore.

(I)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is fantastic!!  T&E is my favorite game by a country mile.  I've bought two copies and will soon buy the reprint.  I would love a "super fancy kickstarter" version.  I don't think there's a better game for 4 players (preferably equally-experienced players).  Playing with 3 players is very good, but not quite as amazing as with 4.  The only complaint I might have with the 4 player game is that it ends too soon.  I've considered a variant where during a tile discard players (at their option, once per game) disclose their hand and put it back in the bag.   Fans of pure-strategy games may lament the lack of control at times, and some might characterize the game as more of an "experience" game than anything else, but because of the variety of the tile draw every game plays out differently.

RATING: 8
Knizia's masterpiece. RATING: 8

RATING: 5
I've got more than a dozen plays under my belt and stil don't feel like I've mastered anything about it. Also most of my games have been two-player, and I'd really like to get some three and four player games in. Word to the wise, don't try to teach this to non-gamers. The internal vs external struggle will baffle them. My wife won't come near this with a ten foot pole now.

*Update* 12/2008 - I eventually traded this off and don't regret it.

T&E has some nifty mechanics, but in the end, it feels clumbsy to me, players are very much at the mercy of the tile draws. When you get red ones, you can do well, but sometimes you get red tiles and you think you have enough to find out that your opponent either lucked into or saved more than you and you're dead in the water. Perhaps there are hidden mysteries to the game that I'm missing, but after 20 plays I've given up on it.

RATING: 8
[Mayfair Games 'Tigris & Euphrat' 2003 edition] {Civilization; tile-laying; optimal 4p} T&E is a classic Knizia's game but it's hard to find 4 suitable players. It's thematic and full of player interaction and confrontation. It's deep but not highly unforgiving. It supports both strategies and tactical moves. The luck in tile draws is very minor; it will not affect the play, when playing wisely. Actually, I like the tile draw because it makes the game more fun and dynamic.

RATING: 9
5/8/10: 1st play.  Wow!  For a set of relatively simple rules (there are a few too many fiddly exceptions to make them just "simple"), this game seems awfully dynamic.  There's a [b]lot[/b] going on in this 1-1.5 hour slugfest.  I already see layers upon layers going on here, and unlike a game like Chess or Go, I don't feel like it's totally impenetrable.  This is staying in my collection for quite awhile, I think.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the best games I know, without a doubt I think E&T is one of  the single best true board games in my opinion. There is just not enough action points to accomplish everything you would like and the tile draw mechanism limits your ability to make extremely long term plans, therefore your left with a wonderfully long (playing time) game with nearly all tactical decisions. It's not something I would look for in a wargame, but in a board game I think this design is terrific.


 Also despite all the comments to the contrary, the rule are pretty simple.

RATING: 10
I love it.  Though it is esentially an abstract game, the theme helps draw in unsuspecting players, who have invariably (so far) enjoyed themselves.
Yes, bad tile draws can make life hard for a few turns.  However, overcoming the randomness of the draws is the point of the exercise.  Good with 2, 3, and 4 players.  The Hans im Gluck edition is gorgeous.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A truly excellent game. It is simple enough to teach to people with only a weak interest in board games, but has enough strategy to satisfy the hardcore gamer. I don't give this game a 10 becasue I don't think it has realized its full potential. It has the potential to be scaled for different numbers of players. I think it would work better as a series of large tiles rather than a fixed board. The hidden scoring system needs some work. The turn sequence and victory conditions in four players can tend to leave #4 at a bit of a disadvantage. I love the game mechanics and extreme subtlety of strategy. When at first you don't succeed in this game, there is always a new strategy opening to you. This game won't leave a player feeling like they are so far behind they can't catch up. I've seen very few games of this caliber and I would recommend it to anyone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow...This is perhaps the only Eurogame that has really blown me away.  Lots of interesting options, short-term and long-term planning, and...conflict!  Glorious, underrated conflict!  Without a kingmaking problem!  Hats off to RK, definitely my favorite Eurogame with this degree of abstraction.  UPDATE:  OK, it's probably NOT as good as Samurai, which accomplishes a lot of the same stuff in a shorter game with less random screwage.  SECOND UPDATE:  Downgraded again--it IS a terrific game, but I wouldn't elect to play it over several lower-rated games, so I guess I should boot it down.  May just be a bit lacking in the "fun" department.

THIRD UPDATE:  Played twice recently.  No, it really is an excellent game.  Too bad the red tiles are a touch too important, but other than that it's excellent.

RATING: 8
Another classic Knizia game that has stood the test of time. The interesting decisions and confrontations that this game brings out is great. The only reason it loses a couple of points is due to how aggressive the game can get and how kingmaker-y it can be with people who don't know what they are doing. Also, the game can be extremely frustrating if you don't get a decent number of red tiles to use Internal Conflicts. Still a classic and I enjoy it with the expansion (the other map with two "4" space river places) and the Ziggurat expansion (the + building that gives 1 color of your choice).

RATING: N/A
Dio Knizijine 'tile placement trilogije'. Kad bih morao birati samo jednu igru, to bi bila ova. Ultimativni tile placement. Svjetska klasa igrača kaže da je malo nagnuta prema prvom igraču ali rekao bih da je to klasa 'Kasparov'. Nama smrtnicima ipak prije zatrokira mozak kad se iz vreće pojavi neočekivani tajl, tako da je posve ok izbalansirana. Iako je Knizija pomalo kratak s narativom, ovdje je iz nekog razloga baš fino pogodio dinamiku konstantne mijene moći. Svi uglavnom grade, civlizacija stalno raste, samo kad se sudari sama sa sobom brzo dolazi do pražnjenja potencijala kroz sudar vizija i eto ipak se nekako razruši - pri čemu tajlovi/narod odlaze kvragu a bodovi odlaze pobjedničkoj dinastiji. Poražena se dinastija, kao i u stvarnosti, samo povuče do slijedeće prilike...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
Really enjoyed this, keen to give it another go now that I understand the rules and strategy a bit better. The simple mechanic of scoring only your lowest colour is typically fiendish Knizia brilliance, ensuring a rich game of varied strategies, rather than allowing one player to find the most lucrative way to score points and milking that from the first turn.

Might be better to allow the large scoring cubes to represent 3 points instead of 5, since there was at least one occasion in the game that I played where a player was forced to reveal that he had less than five of a particular colour, when there were no small cubes of that colour left, and he was unable to supply 'change' for a large cube. Quite a disadvantage when it's late in the game and everyone is alerted to your weakest colour.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Having finally sat down and played a full 4-player game, I'm upgrading my rating to 7. It was deep, tense, and actually quite bloody. The only problem is how long it takes to play. If you have a few hours, it's an enjoyable game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Super dry and lifeless, it is nevertheless a very smart abstract game that is interesting strategically with four players.  It's not good at two players because it is too easy for one player to avoid interaction and just do their own thing for a large portion of the game.  A major game weakness is that it it is easy to find yourself hopelessly behind if you lose a couple key battles/conflicts early and then you become mostly a spectator.  Also, sometimes those battles come down to whoever happened to get the better draw, which is not known until the battle occurs.  Building temples seems pointless as it takes a lot of build but very hard to hold on to (as it then becomes a major target for other players to acquire).  All this being said, it is a brilliant game.  However, if I never feel inspired to play it, it's hard to give it a high rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't find the rules to be too difficult. If you explain the internal conflicts as <i>coups</i> and the external conflicts as <i>wars</i>, and point out that the king (black leader) needs to build barracks (black tiles) to wage a war, the theme really helps people remember the rules.

RATING: 9
Why do I like this game so much? I think it's that everyone scores by their weakest area. So, you have to have a balanced civilization. Plus, you don't own any tiles (although people get territorial) so you're never down and out. You can always bump another player’s leader out of a kingdom if they are in a better position than you.

RATING: 10
[c]
Fun to Play           Boring [.....x.....] Really Fun!
Engaging          Long Waits [.....|.x...] Fully Occupied!
AP Potential          Low AP [.....|....x] High AP
Puzzliness              Less [....x|.....] More
Variability             Less [...x.|.....] More
Who Playing With.  Less Imp. [...x.|.....] More Imp.

Full vs. Filler       Filler [.....|....x] Full
Paths to Victory         Few [....x|.....] Many
Play Complexity          Low [.....|..x..] High
Rules Complexity         Low [.....|..x..] High
Direct Interaction       Low [.....|...x.] High
Indirect Interact.       Low [.....|.x...] High

RATINGS:
My First Play              0 [.....|.x...] 10
Multiple Plays             0 [.....|....x] 10

OVERALL RATINGS FOR:
Play with Kids             0 [x....|.....] 10
Play with Kids & Adults    0 [x....|.....] 10
Play with New/Low Key      0 [.x...|.....] 10
Play with Group            0 [x....|.....] 10
Play with My Parents       0 [..x..|.....] 10
Play with 'Gamers'         0 [.....|....x] 10
[/c]

Everything about this game is nearly perfect for me. Lots of choices in what to do and never enough moves to do everything you want. Interesting scoring mechanism. Multiple end conditions. Tactical and strategic planning. Different types of conflict. Fluidity of board and pieces. Lots of things to keep track of.

Note for those of you considering this game: I was really frustrated with this game the first time I played because I was overwhelmed and took a long time to figure out what to do each turn. Then, after thinking for a long while, I would go to make my moves and was told that I couldn't due to the subtleties in the rules I had overlooked.

You need to give this game some time to learn the rules and understand what all of your options are. No, this isn't a game for everyone.

RATING: 10
I picked up the iOS version when it was released in November, 2011. Thanks to boardgamegeek's implementation of this game, I've played it a lot over the years. Having AI and easy access to online multiplayer is excellent, and I will continues to play this game for years.

I finally picked up the board game version of E&T, the Mayfair 1st Edition, in a BGG auction.

2013 update:  As you can tell, I rarely give out 10's to a game, and E&T was my first one.  I've played this game more than 1,000 times on the iOS implementation, and thus, have started to wean myself away for a while.  In no way will I stop playing this game, I still enjoy it for all the right reasons!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
No reservations: I love Tigris & Euphrates. It combines the best of board and card gaming into one delightfully confrontational package, and continues to impress more than a decade after release. It's a wonderful tile-laying game that emphasizes territory control, direct confrontation, and balance -- not only (obviously) in the scoring mechanics, but also in knowing when and where to attack. As I continue to play against experienced players, the strategies of this game open up in new and interesting ways. I want to play more and more.

The goal of the game is to collect resource cubes (now cardboard chits in the latest edition -- Boo!), which come in four colors. In what is now classic Knizia fashion, you must collect complete sets of cubes in order to score victory points. So for example, if you have 4 green, 1 red, 5 blue, and 3 black, you still only score one point because you only have one complete set of four. As a result, you are forced to participate in all aspects of the game. You cannot focus on a single color, and you cannot avoid certain confrontations.

Set in ancient times, the theme exudes the feeling of civilizations struggling for dominance and relevance. Yet your turns are a straightforward exercise in placing tiles on a map depicting the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. Some people complain that the game is dry as desert dust. I disagree. However, the theme is not contained in elaborate event cards or fancy miniatures. Instead, the theme arises organically from gameplay. One tile after another is added to the board. I play a farm here, a temple there. On your turn you add a leader and another farm. The board grows into a scene of struggling tribes spreading across the land. Two civilizations merge, and two competing leaders face off in a struggle for dominance. Only one can win, and the loser is wiped from the map (often with a bunch of his followers). What's not thematic about that?! Let go any assumptions about a designer spoon-feeding theme to you. Instead, know that the theme is in the "feel" of the game. If you can do that, you'll get along just fine.

What you are left with is a game that feels tense, with your plans always on the verge of collapse. Timing when and where to place your tiles is a key skill. Moreover, you absolutely must manage your hand of tiles. The number one complaint I hear about T&E is that "It's all about lucky draws. You either get the tiles you need or you're screwed." There is dash of truth in the latter half of the complaint. You do need certain tiles to perform well. But like all hand management games, the key is in knowing how to save the ones you need for the times when they will have maximum impact. It also means reading the board and the other players. If Suzy across the table just played a boatload of red tiles, then the chances are she doesn't have any left. Now might be a great time to launch that attack with red you've been planning. Your patience will be rewarded now that the timing is right.

Do things always work out in your favor? Do you have perfect control over your fate? No, of course not. But the same is true for any number of card games. You must balance luck against odds, timing with knowledge.

The heart of T&E is its focus on a few core mechanics as well as its dedication to balance. From these concepts comes a game that will make you angry, proud, tense, and excited all at once. And it will manage all this in 90 minutes or less. It's a stalwart of boardgaming for a reason, and well worth playing -- especially now that it's back in print with a (for the most part) excellent edition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Tigris & Euphrates just misses out on my top tier of games because it lacks a little of the fun factor that is so important to me.  We haven't played enough to escape that "Oh I won? Really?" sort of feeling at the end of games.  At the same time, I can tell that there is a lot more depth to be explored here.  I suspect that my rating might bump up a point if I can get this to the table a few more times.

RATING: 7
Tigris & Euphrates is one of the pinnacles of the designer's brain-burning, tile-laying efforts, and either you love it or you don't.  Watching the potential conflicts advance towards each other and then explode like a firecracker is fantastic.  Resolving the winners of each is a simple math problem. The whole experience takes on a chess-like gravity.  The new FF edition makes the game slightly more approachable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
T&E encourages ingenuity, aggression, long-term strategic planning, and tactical responsiveness.  There is an incredible variety of strategic actions that can be made each turn, so the game gives the players plenty of opportunity to do something very clever or very stupid.  I appreciate that.  It's an intense (though strangely unemotional) game that doesn't at all try to herd the players into only considering a narrow, obvious path of optimal actions, a fault that many other popular Euros are guilty of.  This is sometimes called Reiner Knizia's masterpiece.  I understand how it got that reputation, even if I don't quite hold it in the same regard (I'm a much bigger fan of his Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation).

I am a bit disappointed with how abstract it feels while playing.  I think the theme is well integrated with the rules set but perhaps has too little influence on the players' actions.  I guess the theme is there in theory but absent in practice.  On the other hand, how many abstracts can boast such a strong theme?

UPDATE 1: I think I've underrated this one.  I'd like to try it again.

UPDATE 2: Yup, I did underrate it.  This is a supreme game.  A very entertaining and intricate brain-burner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Your chances in this game are a tad too tied in to the tiles you choose, but plotting how to maximize the potential of your tiles is an entertaining challenge. The best part of this game is watching the kingdoms slowly slide into each other like tectonic plates, sowing ruin and rueing as the plates either destroy each other or meld into a greater kingdom. All the damage you can create and points you can reap with just one well-placed tile is thrilling. Oh, and the funky wooden monuments are fun too. Kids, collect all eight!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very well balanced game and victory point mechanism. Yet, a little short on options during the game to my concern.

As for me: One of the most overrated games on the Geek!

RATING: 3
I was having a think about why I don't like this game, but I just couldn't put my finger on it. I mean, I can see it's a technically good game. I was having a conversation with one of my game group about it and he said, "Well, the thing is, it's just so *boring*." That sums it up perfectly for me. Dull as dishwater. I thought that maybe it was because my first game was a two player game, which meant there wasn't that much conflict; but my next game was a four player, and we were all underwhelmed. There seemed to be a general consensus of, "Wow, is that it?" and the game was very quickly put away. I guess that if there's going to be conflict in a game, I'd like it to actually be conflict rather than counting how many tiles I and my opponent have. I know I'm missing the point of the game by saying that - it's a very abstract euro and is meant to be - but this game just didn't light my fires at all...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So far I've only logged online plays. This will be a tough sell with the wife because the strategies lie deep and require a few plays to grasp. I'll update when I decide to introduce it to her.

UPDATE AT 9 PLAYS:

I've played three in-person games vs. six online plays. It plays quickly enough that I prefer a face-to-face experience over an online game. But after nine plays I'm lowering from an 8 to a 7.5 in my rating. I was hoping I would start feeling a little more theme as I played more and learned more. I haven't. In fact, I've felt the opposite. Perhaps it's because I've taught it so many times--I have to talk about each of the colors and that's easier than trying to tell new players about what each color represents. Not sure. I like it, and I know there is decent strategy. But I don't feel the long-term strategy I enjoy. This game feels more tactical and has a strong focus on turn optimization, rather than decent long-term strategy planning.

Update: a few more plays in and I have to say I really enjoy keeping this game around for that classic moment. I recently played it at a CON with a few people who could appreciate the nostalgia of a old-game revisit, and I was glad I had kept it on-hand all these years. I'll be keeping it. What's more, with FFG's release, using plastic minis instead of the chunky wooden pieces in my version, I'm super glad I've held onto it all these years.

RATING: 10
This is a very interesting and very dense tile-placement game.  All sorts of ways to play, choosing your aggression level.  And the final scoring system being based on your LOWEST scoring category is a pretty ingenious way of keeping players from dominating in only one of the four areas of the game.  Pretty neat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An incredibly deep, simple, and utterly classic modern strategy game. While highly abstract, the game is actually quite thematic, so much so that it feels like a very, very abstract simulation or model of sorts. It all fits together so well. 

Another great example of a game that takes only a small amount of effort to learn, but will continue to surprise you with new possibilities.

The hidden information aspect and the fact that only the lowest score of the four different categories counts as each player's final score make this game hard to call, even up to the last turn, so it's quite exciting.

This is one of those games that feels older than it is. Ancient, like the theme. A masterpiece game, for sure, that will stand the test of time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
After 1 play (02-15-09): Maybe it's just the amount of research I did beforehand, but after one 2p game I honestly don't understand why people find this so hard to learn.  There are a lot of moving parts but not many rules that are weird outside the context of a handful of core concepts.  The interaction of these parts branches into a crazy number of variables--there's a lot to watch, and a lot to track.  It's also VERY tooth-and-nail.  Very pleased with the components on the 2008 Mayfair edition.

RATING: 7.5
The ultimate in tile placement games. I agree with the comment that T&E is Knizia's masterpiece. RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This feels like four-player chess or something. You've got a few types of playing pieces, a map that will never change (i.e. locations of rivers and treasures), and maybe a half-dozen reasonable options on your turn that could have vastly different effects. I can't think of another game to compare it to. Though, I've played very few tile-laying games.

The tile draw is a little iffy for me. I don't mind the randomness and am actually grateful that it may reduce the number of options you currently have. I really don't like the idea of using your tiles to bid and add to your conflict strength though. That makes it feel very arbitrary who wins a conflict that has potentially huge effect.

I really like the differentiation of the four colors (economic sectors). Nothing seems overly complicated or inelegant.

The theme works well. It's not strictly necessary but it doesn't conflict with the mechanics either.

...If you don't remember to use the tile swapping move and don't attack much, it seems the game can outlast its welcome and leave people with nothing useful to do. There may be room to rise above a 7 rating. Needs another play for me to say unfortunately.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An old favorite!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love this game. I like deep games with simple mechanics..and this one accomplish both. Basically, you have to place 2 tiles in your turn to grab points in 4 colors. You have 3 ways to grab pints...placing just tiles, building monuments and...making conflicts! (and a fourth way in the advanced game with civ buildings)...Conflicts are maybe the most difficult mechanic to learn for newbies, but after 2 games it is not a problem. T&E is an ellegant game, with not fiddly issues, I love the theme (I know others disagree, but I see and like the theme in this game)...it is a very tactical game, with many possibilities in your turn, I like each color having different abilities...and it scales nicely for 2,3 or 4 players. 4 players is mostly tactical, you can´t plan too much your next turns, lots of conflicts and comebacks among the players....ITOH 2 players (my favourite and mostly played) is a more strategic and less chaotic game, with a more quiet and lengthy development phase, where you can plan more carefully your next moves...Many players say 2 players becomes boring games, with both players in opposite corners derivating in non-conflict games...I disagree at all...experienced players know you must be aggressive to win this game, turtling is nearly a defeat vs an experienced player...BTW I recommend to teach this game to a newbie covering the left third of the board (11x11), with only 6 treasures and 2/3 of the tiles, before playing full board. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I just love jumping into this soup. This is not a game you can control but momentarily, the probabilities can collapse into a crazy event horizon that sucks you right off the board and into your lap, and one must have the sort of gumption to pop right back out there. There are opportunities for shared incentive structures, opportunities to suddenly drive the game, passing intricate decisions to the next player, and enough drama to make you weep or scream.

I may like this more than Brass. It has an ability to get 'farther off the books' if you know what I mean. It's very open and such pure spatial thinking it has a direct, raw hormonal charge in every play.

Games like this set up certain moments, a creative play or setting up a skillful cascade that one manages to surf (with always the risk that the wave takes you down). It has such a fine ratio of all the constituents of interactivity. It is an exemplar of gathering them in a ratio that pleases me very much.

I think everyone gets called a bastard at least once. 

Which I think precipitates the whole overhead thing down out of the clouds. By overhead I mean the ratio of qualitative thinking one gets to do in game, the why of a move, versus the tax of how to do something, or solving riddles rather than engaging dynamics. The more of a bastard you can be in a game, the closer you are to the magic, sweet ratio of perfect overhead, whatever the mechanics are.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.25
Possibly my favourite game.
So much depth to the strategy and the way the board changes dramatically from move to move is fantastic. Some very good mechanics (the revolt and only lowest colour scores) stop it from just being the player who builds the biggest empire or having runaway leader problems.
Can be hard to teach though. The rules are simple enough but the strategy can be very counter-intuitive ('but thats my Kingdom!'). After a  couple of games it all makes sense and the depth of the game begins to take shape. Great app version available too (which is handy cause its not the easiest game to get to the table).

RATING: 8
The animals came; their hearts grew light in the waters.
And as for him, Enkidu, child of the mountain,
he who fed with Gazelles on grass,
he drank with the wild beasts at the watering place
and with the hurrying animals his heart grew light in the waters.
-Gilgamesh

Tigris and Euphrates is set in ancient Mesopotamia, but the more subtle qualities of the experience are defined by the game design.  Easy to learn the mechanics yet extremely challenging to master, Tigris & Euphrates is everything a game should be. The components are simple but choice, like a well executed Cacio e Pepe.  This is a must own for anyone wanting a deep thought provoking game with plenty of replay value.

I lowered to a score of 8 because I have only played the app version.  I need to see how much calculation time the board game takes to see where it stands overall.

RATING: 7
A bit of a brain burner.  Clever mechanics, and 4 players, but starts to feel a bit like Chess after a while.  There's not much laughter to it, no trade, but the bits are nice.

There are so many levels here that it can be difficult finding someone (or 3 someones!) on the same level of understanding, which the game needs.  Otherwise you will win convincingly, or be thrashed.  
Also learning that the deciding factor is actually the tiles that you pull from the bag - there is only so much you can do with poor luck...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Great game with phenomenal components. Although quite abstract, each game is involving from beginning to end. This is mainly due to the fact that player turns are short, but seemingly simple actions can have a lot of impact on the situation on the board and the player ranking. There are not a lot of rules to the game, but people find it hard to remember them during the course of their first session. That, however, really is the ONLY drawback I can think of.

RATING: 4
I really, *really* want to play this more now that I fully understand the rules (I didn't know you could play Catastrophes over already placed tiles!).

Edit: After a few more plays, I'm starting to cool to it. It's undeniably an excellent game, but I'm have trouble getting a lock on how to stymie a runaway leader. It all seems to come back to two things: initial placement and luck of the draw. 

There are places on the board that are, quite frankly, better than others. It seems much harder to catch up if you've made the mistake of starting in the wrong area. In the few games I've played since I acquired it, there is definitely a point where further play is futile. For an otherwise excellent game, I find this aspect of it truly horrendous.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow, this game is amazing. Nothing short of brilliant. It's a shame it's taken me so long to finally get this to the table. It's an amazing piece of game design, though that's to be expected from Knizia. 

I can see why people complain about not drawing enough red tiles but I don't think it's really an issue. I haven't personally found myself in a situation where I need to win an internal conflict or go bust, and there's a lot of different ways to go about scoring points. I do think that people get a bit too attached to the kingdoms they build. 

4 player is delightfully confrontational, while 3 player is still good, but not as much. It's one of the few games where you're left wondering how you could improve such a design.

Wonderfully thematic and amazing to play!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Did not get a chance to try it at Origins 04, but wish I did.  I talked to some people about it after playing a different brain burner that I didn't like, and they said this is an even bigger brain drain.  I think they intended it to mean that it is very deep and strategic, but at that time, it didn't sound good.  I had other issues, like having trouble getting 4 player games in, and my group tends to like lighter games.<br/><br/>

Six months later, we have been getting into heavier games, and our friends pick up Tigris and Euphrates.  In preparation, I read the rules, and play a half a game on the Java version to get a feel for it.  After waiting for the stars to align (one player does not make it, everyone is in the mood, etc), we get a chance to play it.<br/><br/>

Well, after one real game between four newbies...  There were downtime issues.  We are a AP prone group, but this was worse than our games of Tikal.  There was so much to learn and consider during this first game that I'm not entirely sure how much I enjoyed it.  I do like it, and I tend to like heavier games.  Also, everyone seemed to enjoy it too, but the real proof will be if they want to play it again.  I also think the downtime issues should not normally be so bad.

RATING: 8.4
Great euro in which the losers do not win. A great Knizian with usual balance but lacking the tacky glued-on theme feel. Great balance between randomness and skill, replayability suffers though as the cowards flee from your superior tactics. Easily the best Knizia game and also one of the best euro games you can spend money on. For anyone looking for checkers on acid.

RATING: 9
I have played the digital version of this game tons of times, unfortunately the physical game doesn't get table time that often. The physical game can be a bit fiddly. I love this game, especially the deep tactical choices and the game end scoring mechanism. Because the 'highest lowest score' wins, you have to chase the points in categories that you are not doing well in, which might demand some aggressive play. Priorities are shifting during the game, which is something I very much enjoy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Excellent game.  The strategy opens before you the more you play to a seemingly endless degree.  Very simple to play, but hard to master.  A little tough on a new player, as it seems more complicated than it actually is.  Plus, the concept of "you are a symbol, not a color" is counter-intuitive to every instinct I have about board games.  If not for those small complaints and minor component issues, it would be ranked higher, because I feel like this is my favorite game, and probably the best overall game ever made.  Even the random element in this game doesn't bother me nearly as much as in other games, as, although it is a pretty fair part of gameplay, the game beautifully wraps itself around chance by making it feel like an integral part of the story and shaping of the game, instead of just arbitrarily rewarding bad play and punishing good play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A little to hard to explain to new players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the best Knizia games but just far too abstract for my taste. Also game-state parsing is very unintuitive and luck of the draw is ever present and plays a big deal in whether you can attack or even defend as well as getting any reasonable scores. I just get the impression that there is basically no way to score in a color unless you draw tiles of that color, because the right tile colors are needed to get the 1 cube placement bonus, in external battle. Only when leeching off monuments and if you would maneuver very carefully could you in theory gain a color without support from good draws.

RATING: 7
Rich game that has the continued capacity to surprise me after many plays.  It's replayable, it's got a perfect amount of chaos and hidden information, and lots of meaty tactical decisions.  You have a modicum of control over your hand, and it's all about getting what you need with what you got.  I enjoy the constant threat of conflict hanging over your head.  You only have so many tiles, so what do you keep?  What do you spend?  When do you refresh your hand?  Fast-moving and consistently throwing new decisions at you, this game does everything a Euro should.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

Strategy is deep and wide open but thanks to the hidden knowledge and random draws there's no need to take it deadly serious. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After playing eight games over the years with different kinds of people, I must say this is a really good game. Understanding conflicts might take a game or two, otherwise the game is quite simple - in a good way. Every game is a little bit different than the others. The latest game was first one for me in ages (same for couple of other players, too) and we made a lots of stupid errors, because we didn't remember all the rules and our tactics were mediocre at best. This only made me to want to play this more.

Good tile game.

Update after ninth game, it was over a year since the last game for me and the others. There were only three players, and I believe the game is better with four.

Another three player play for this year. Four would be better.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
PERMANENT PLACE IN COLLECTION

An amazingly well-designed game that's like nothing else I've played. The closest comparison in my game collection is Eclipse (which also involves civilisation building and attacking). It's reasonably easy to learn, but strategically and tactically complex. Hard to master with lots of replay value.

It's a tile-laying game where you build a city (using different tiles) and attack your city-building opponents. 

The theme is very strong. You feel like you're building a defensible city in the cradle of civilisation and attacking your opponents across the river.

The game's depth means it's hard to play well when tired. For this reason, it gets played less in our house than Dominion or Through the Desert. 

The iPad game is a no brainer. A brilliant way to pass a train journey, especially with a friend using the pass-and-play mode.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Unforgatable game. Great rules.

RATING: 8
Although at a highly abstracted level, I find the rules of Tigris & Euphrates to be thematically evocative. The tactical decisions in this game can be excruciating when conflicts are at hand. The luck of the tile draw is an influence but is also an element to be managed with skill, using the tiles you get to your best advantage and knowing when it would actually be best to spend an action swapping them. Overall a classic of board game design, and unlike any other game.

RATING: 8
