=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Generally speaking, I am usually not a fan of Reiner Knizia's cold, abstract style of game design. Most of his games seem to boil down to set collecting or some other boring numerical calculation. His themes are so pasted on that I often wonder if he even bothers to think about a theme while he is designing. I envision his game lab as a pack of Uno cards and a sheet of graph paper, the genesis of all his creations.

Tigris and Euphrates however, is a very different beast. It's still incredibly abstract, but here the theme is very tightly integrated. T&E uses tile laying to represent the growth and management of an ancient Mesopotamian empire. You aren't playing buildings or claiming roles, there are no money or resource issues to manage, nor are there any technologies to research. Despite this, the civilization theme still comes bubbling up with surprising effectiveness.

The tiles turn the whole concept of an empire building game on it's head by representing all of the various aspects of civilization on a mere four tile types. By following a few placement rules, you start to see empires grow and contract as they encounter other groups of tiles. Again, it is so unbelievably abstract that it should be nonsense, yet I really feel like I am managing an empire when I play. Like other Civ games, there is a need for expansion, but expanding weakens your civilization and opens you up to attack from other competing kingdoms. I'm not sure how Tigris and Euphrates pulls it off, but this giant pile of abstract nothingness tells a fascinating story every time I play.

As a side note, it also features one of the most interesting victory conditions I have ever run across. At the end of the game, everyone compares their score according to the area they were least successful in. The best of the worst scores wins. Like the rest of the game, that doesn't SEEM to make any sense, until you play it. You'll see that it does...and it's brilliant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good abstract game. Waiting for more plays to review the rating.

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
I'm torn on this. I respect it more than I like it. The theme doesn't work well for me, and the luck of the draw invariably produces a moment (or two, or three) of complete frustration for at least one player. But it's an interesting and subtle game, and I'm glad I own it.

I don't really like (and am not good at) inferences based on hidden information, and that's pivotal here. And of course, like poker, you can play "correctly" and still get hosed. Over time, skill wins out, but to me, there's a lot of uninteresting luck here.

Am a bit surprised that the turn order bias hasn't generated too much wrath, and am also surprised that Knizia's purportedly legendary playtesting didn't sniff it out and compensate (pretty easy to do, really).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent confrontational tile-laying game.  The slowest road to victory is peaceful building (unless your opponents let you milk monuments, which they shouldn't), the fastest is ruthless warmongering.  I really love it when games incentivize conflict and interaction over solitary turtling, and T&E does this fantastically well.

The strategy in the game is kind of opaque.  That is, it's hard to see how to play well armed only with the rules.  At first, people tend to think of kingdoms as belonging to them and overcommit to building up and defending their turf.  Kingdoms are really just abstract point-generating farms though, to be abandoned and commandeered, shared and fought over as each player's immediate point needs dictate.  Once you start to figure this out, the game becomes far more dynamic and interesting.  (The flip side of this is that if you're looking for a peaceful Euro-y civ builder, this ain't it.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like this game, it really seems like the game has independent play, but you really have to watch what your opponents are doing!

Is this just a classic because people can feel smart when they understand the difference beetween internal and external conflict?

RATING: 8
The unique mechanism by which one scores with the category where one has the least points is in my opinion one of the best parts of the game in that it changes the entire nature of play. This is a themed abstract with slightly limited information but is definitely a strategy game.

This is for me not one of those games where once gets a rush like the thrill of achieving objectives in a wargame but it's still an excellent game.

Also, it's one of my wife's favorites.

RATING: 8.8

RATING: 10
"I have six red tiles behind my screen."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In general, I don't like games that make me feel like I'm stupid. I've played T&E three times now, and this game makes me feel like I'm a three-year-old trying to solve a quadratic equation. The board is constantly changing, and in a split second, something you do on one side of the board can have a huge impact on what's happening on the other side. The fact that you have to look for symbols rather than player colors and that the players' tiles and cubes are hidden information doesn't help. I'm not saying I hate the game, I'm just saying it's way too complex for me to visualize. For me, playing T&E is like walking into a minefield wearing a blindfold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Masterpiece by Reiner Knizia - in this game players build civilizations by laying tiles that represent religion, trade, farming & nobility.  This is a heavy, strategic game full of conflict, with excellent balance of luck.  When you 'attack' a kingdom there is no way to know what reinforcements they have hidden.  There are also tons of interesting decisions to make, like whether to start a conflict, build a monument, or save up certain tiles for future defense.  The end-game scoring is brilliant and forces players to not neglect their weakest areas.       Despite everything going on, turns are fast with players each doing only 2 actions per turn.  Amazing game!

RATING: 8.5
Excellent blending of wargame mechanics, tile placement, and worker placement.  Negatives are the randomness in the tile draw, and the pasted-on theme.  There is little difference in the four leader types (other than slight advantages for the Trader and the King), and the tile types are also meaningless (other than the red tiles representing Templates which are all-important in the Internal Conflicts.  Despite the lack of theme, it is an excellent abstract strategy game that requires a couple plays to figure out what works and what doesn't.

RATING: 9

The game is very tense, with so many things you would like to do on your turn, and it requires both tactical finesse and strategical planning. The scoring system is a clever idea, and the thematic feel is good enough - at least for me. Luck is a small factor, but in some rare cases, it can unfortunately affect the overall result dramatically.

RATING: 8
En el territorio que está entre estos dos ríos, los jugadores luchan por ser el que más influencia tenga. Se consiguen puntos en 4 apartados y lo curioso de este juego es que al final de la partida, cada jugador solo obtendrá puntos en aquel apartado que peor lleve. Es decir, hay que ir creciendo en todos los apartados sin dejar descolgado ninguno. Uno de los mejores juegos abstractos.

RATING: 9
Often I go months without playing this game only to come back to it and still be amazed.  Despite its complexities in strategy, it can also be a quick light game.  Last session we played 15 second turns (take the bag.  play 2 tiles.  draw 2 tiles.  pass the bag.) and it was a blast.  The mechanics on turns without conflicts are so simple.  Yet I've also played slow analytic games.  This game has great range in play styles which are all enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
There is certainly much depth and replayability in the game and it is achieved amazingly without using cards. Watching how the board develops is key to doing well.

Interaction between players is also high as the design discourages turtling. Scalability of the game is good and it plays well with as few as 2 players.

The theme is subtle but reasonably well-integrated.

The quality of the game components is good. I would have preferred some sort of more thematic tokens for the four categories' victory points, though that is just a minor point.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]ON THE FENCE...[/b]

You give the game an "7" and you're on the fence?
Yep! I am inexplicably drawn to this game-design architecture. There is a mysterious energy that washes over me, whenever presented with a boardgame that uses tile-laying over a grid-like playing surface, as a game mechanic. When playing, I feel like I'm a Roman craftsman, laying down a mosiac for a toga-wearing Praetor in his opulent bathing chamber.

The magic of this game sparkles on even the most starless night, like a glowing mist that snatches ships within the Bermuda Triangle.
My Geek-radar pings loudly, demanding I pay attention to a fat target, zeroing-in my crosshairs, when tile-laying games hove into view. That said, this went down like a torpedoed tramp steamer, leaking oil, clouds of pitch-black smoke belching from a gashes to the hull, on a storm-tossed sea, with my usual group on first play. Second play was much improved.

Will shelve until the time is right, or the stars line up, or something.

Deep. Dry. Long. Abstract.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Color me impressed.  There is a very deep and strategic game in this little box of wonders.  The way how quickly kingdoms can be lost and gained, territories blocked and connected, there is never a dull moment.  The randomness come with the tile drawing could and probably will always be a source of frustration, but for me this can be tolerated in the light of such intriguing mechanics.  Even the scoring itself is interesting, since you compare your lowest color victory points rather than the highest, so it is bad to end up with too many of one sphere.  I really enjoyed my first play of T&E, looking forward to try it again and again.

RATING: 9

Any one who likes Acquire and is not turned off by games that involve direct competition should lke this game a lot.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Remek játék! Nem hiába mondják évtized játékának. Reiner Knizia legjobban sikerült játéka! :whistle:

Mindenki egy népet irányít és megpróbál 4 területen kiegyensúlyozottan minél nagyobb befolyásra szert tenni. Ez egyedülálló pontgyűjtési mechanizmus, ugyanis nem az a lényeg minél több pontot gyűjts összességében hanem mindegyik területen egyformán sokat, ugyanis ahol a legkevesebbet gyűjtöttük az lesz a végső pontérték. 

Különleges élményt ad a királyságok összekapcsolása, vagy éppen széjjelrobbantása. Ügyesen kell birodalmunkat megszilárdítani, ugyanis könnyen kirúghatják a trónt a hátsónk alól (általában akkor amikor emlékműveket építgetünk meg civilizációs épületeket, ezek keményen gyengítik a királyságunkat).

Egyszerű játékmechanika, csupán 4 akció közül választhatunk 2-t a körünkben. Gyors szabályismertetés (kb 20 perc). Könnyű szabályrendszer. Sok konfrontációval, szinte észre se veszi már az ember annyi van (persze a játékosoktól is függ mert lehet békés verziót is játszani). Rövid játékidő (1-1,5 óra). 2-en is élvezetes játszani!

Hasonló érzésem volt mint ha egy logikai játékkal játszottam volna pl malom, vagy sakk. Szóval aki szereti az ilyen jellegű játékokat az nem fog csalódni. :shake:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.6
Andriod
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I like T&E, but my biggest issue has been that the barrier to entry is really high. Because the mechanics are based on a largely abstract game design, it is very hard for people to catch onto the rules well enough to excel unless they play a few times, even if you're playing without monuments or other advanced rules.

If you can get a group together that can fight through those first couple games learning the rules and can deal with the relative lack of theme, then T&E can be a lot of fun. It is a brain-burner at times, so some AP-prone players may not be the best choices to play with.

T&E is better with 3-4 players, as a 2P game turns into 0-sum which typically devolves into each player building their own empires and then attempting one massive conflict near the game's end.

RATING: 9.25
Great abstract civilization game. Lot of thinkwork. Very good game mechanics. Deserves the classic status. 

There may be a minor luck element in getting the tiles you need for your strategy. Or you could look at it from a different perspective and say that the tiles you draw determine your tactics in the short run, but you'll eventually win by clever strategic play and seeking for opportunities to gain the upper hand. For now i'm on the latter thinking side.

RATING: 8
01/27/08 - This game tends to be pretty rough on noobz (I am a reasonably seasoned with it, although with today's play-and-dump gaming scene, that doesn't take much =[), and I have seen a lot of people struggle with it on the first few go-arounds.  Though I admire the game a great deal, I think it's tough for me to want to play it because the hurdles new players have to go through to begin enjoying themselves can be a little rough for me to witness. Of course, there is an outside chance it's me who is causing this....Anyway, I think my rating would jump if I had a dedicated group of live gamers who had a lot of experience with this game.

Previously -- One of a very select group of war-like euros, and arguably the best by a large degree (because it's a fact that Shogun/Wallenstein suxxx).  I try to stick to the 4 player game, since things tend to only get interesting once the board's real estate becomes scarce.  Starting conflicts between two opponents at the right moment is also tons of fun.
